party_tutorial_dialog.title: Charming the Room
party_tutorial_dialog.body:
There are some guests in front of you. Say something to them!
Click on your remarks at the bottom of the screen, then click on the guests to use the remarks.
Try to match the subject of your remarks to their interests, shown in the markers beside them. If they like what you're about to say they'll highlight green and saying that remark will make their opinion of you go up. If they don't like that remark then they'll highlight red and their opinion of you will go down.
However, if their interest bar depletes, they'll get bored and their opinion of you will go down every turn until you speak to them again. Charm them all the Guests in a conversation, and make sure that nobody is bored in order to finish it. Just make sure you don't annoy anyone too much or you could run out of Confidence.
party_tutorial_end.title: Tutorial Complete!
party_tutorial_end.body: Felicitations! You have charmed the host of the Orphan's Feast! As the party winds to a close, you are free to engage any other guests, or make a discreet exit if you so desire. Just click the 'Leave the Party' button to exit the party and see how you did!
invitation_dialog.title: An Invitation Has Arrived!
invitation_dialog.body:
Madame, an invitation from $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION has arrived!

It says you've been invited to attend their $SIZE Party.

I've added the event to your Calendar.
style_change_dialog.title: Style Change!
style_change_dialog.body:
The $OLDSTYLE Style is now out of fashion and the $NEWSTYLE Style is now in fashion!
Adjust your wardrobe accordingly!
pay_day_dialog.title: It's Payday
pay_day_dialog.body:
It's time to pay the help. You're currently employing $NUMSERVANTS.
Their cost of employment this week is $TOTALWAGES.
This leaves you with £$LIVRE
fire_camille_dialog.title: Wait a minute...
fire_camille_dialog.body:
“Camille, what exactly do I pay you for?
“Oh Madame, why do you ask?
“No reason, just thinking about... budget stuff.
“Well Madame, I clean your house, do your laundry, cook your meals, sweep your chimney, manage the household, mend your clothes -”
“Fine! Fine! Forget I asked!”
cant_buy_dialog.title: Oh No!
cant_buy_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, but you do not have enough space in your wardobe to fit this $ITEM.
At this time your Wardrobe can only hold $CAPACITY Outfits. Perhaps there is some way to expand your closet space?
cant_make_dialog.title: Oh No!
cant_make_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, but you do not have enough space in your wardobe to fit a new Outfit. I can't create anything when you have no room to store it.
At this time your Wardrobe can only hold $CAPACITY Outfits. Perhaps there is some way to expand your closet space?
set_trend_dialog.title: Style Change!
set_trend_dialog.body:
You hear audible gasps as you exit your carriage. Your expertly coordinated Outfit, combined with your significant social stature, seems to have taken everyone aback. You can see the wheels turning in their minds as they rethink their stylings and choice of attire.
You have started a new fashion trend. The $OLDSTYLE Style is now out of fashion and 
the $NEWSTYLE Style is now in fashion!
reputation_wine_dialog.title: For you, Madame
reputation_wine_dialog.body:
Madame, thank you for joining us tonight. $HOSTNAME asked me to make sure you were taken care of when the Party began.
<Your Wineglass is now full>
refill_wine_dialog.title: Let's Top That Up
refill_wine_dialog.body:
Madame, I noticed you were running a little low on refreshment. As per $HOSTNAME's request, I'll check in occassional to make sure you have enough to drink.
<Your Wineglass is now full>
feature_incomplete_dialog.title: Pardon Our Dust!
feature_incomplete_dialog.body:
Sorry, that feature hasn't been completed yet, and is thus, unavailable.

Thank you for playing and thanks for your patience while we get the game completed!
sell_gossip_dialog.title: Are you sure, madame?
sell_gossip_dialog.body:
Are you sure you’d like to sell this $GOSSIPNAME for $GOSSIPPRICE?

If you do this, there should be $CAUGHTODDS chance of the public finding out.
peddle_influence_dialog.title: Are you sure, madame?
peddle_influence_dialog.body: This $GOSSIPNAME? For free? Merci beau coups madame! How would you like me to present this to my loyal readers? If you do this, there should be $CAUGHTODDS chance of the public finding out.
peddle_influence_dialog.increase_power: Increase the power of the $FACTION by $SHIFTAMOUNT
peddle_influence_dialog.decrease_power: Decrease the power of the $FACTION by $SHIFTAMOUNT
peddle_influence_dialog.increase_allegia: Push the $FACTION towards the Crown by $SHIFTAMOUNT
peddle_influence_dialog.decrease_allegia: Push the $FACTION towards the Revolution by $SHIFTAMOUNT
move_through_dialog.title: $ROOMNAME
move_through_dialog.body:
You've entered the $ROOMNAME.

Would you like to 'Work the Room' and engage the party goers in Conversation, or would you like to 'Move Through' and hope nobody notices you?
moved_through_dialog.title: Moved Through the $ROOMNAME!
moved_through_dialog.body:
You've succesfully moved through the $ROOMNAME unnoticed.
Now you can back to your real mission uninterrupted.
conversation_over_dialog.title: Conversation Over!
conversation_over_dialog.body:
The Conversation is over, you managed to Charm $NUMCHARMED Guests and $NUMPUTOFF Guests felt Put Off after speaking with you.

Your Reward for Clearing this Room is $REWARD.
charmed_host_dialog.title: Conversation Over!
charmed_host_dialog.body:
The Conversation is over, and you managed to Charm the Host!

Your Reward for Clearing this Room is $REWARD.
failed_host_dialog.title: Conversation Over!
failed_host_dialog.body:
The Conversation is over, but the Host was unfortunately Put Off by your behavior.

Your Reward for Clearing this Room is $REWARD.
out_of_confidence_dialog.title: Oh No!
out_of_confidence_dialog.body:
It appears that you ran out of Confidence during that Conversation. You just started stammering before suddenly leaving to 'Get Some Air'.

You've spent an hour here in the Vestibule collecting your wits but your sudden disappearance was considered quite rude.

You've lost $FACTIONREPUTATION Repuation with the $FACTION and $REPUTATION Reputation with society in general.
out_of_confidence_tutorial_dialog.title: Oh No!
out_of_confidence_tutorial_dialog.body:
It appears that you ran out of Confidence during that Conversation. You just started stammering before suddenly leaving to 'Get Some Air'.

You've spent a few moments here in the Vestibule collecting your wits but your sudden disappearance was considered quite rude.

Fortunately, the patrons at the Orphan's Feast are much more forgiving than the rest of the society. Give it another try!
missed_rsvp_dialog.title: Missed RSVP!
missed_rsvp_dialog.body:
You didn't RSVP to the $PARTYNAME.
The Host is rather upset with you and you've lost $REPUTATION Reputation.
caught_gossiping_dialog.title: Merde!
caught_gossiping_dialog.body: Madame, it appears that you've been found out. While 'Le Mecure' does its best to conceal our sources, some members of the $FACTION seem to have figured out that you were out supplier. This has damaged your Reputation both with them and with society in General.
caught_gossiping_third_estate_dialog.bod:
Madame, it appears that you've been found out. While 'Le Mecure' does its best to conceal our sources, some members of the $FACTION seem to have figured out that you were out supplier. This has damaged your Reputation both with them and with society in General.

Thankfully your contacts in the Third Estate have minimized the effects somewhat.
redeem_quest_dialog.title: Gossip? C'est Magnifique!
redeem_quest_dialog.body:
Thank you Madame, this is exactly the kind of sallacious trash our esteemed readers require!
We'll take care of your reward of $REWARD immediately.
rsvp_dialog.title: RSVP
rsvp_dialog.body:
You've been invited to a $PARTYSIZE Party being held by $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION.
$PROMPT
party_enemies:
It appears that some of your enemies will be in attendance:$ENEMYLIST
Would you still like to attend?
party_no_enemies:
It appears that none of your Enemies will be in attendance. Magnifique!
Would you like to attend?
rsvp_choice_dialog.title: Which Party?
rsvp_choice_dialog.body:
There are two parties being held on this day.
Which party are you interested in?
rsvp_cancel_dialog.title: Cancel Your RSVP?
rsvp_cancel_dialog.body:
You've already agreed to attend the $PARTYSIZE Party being held by $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION.
Cancelling will harm your reputation.
Would you like cancel?
rsvp_cancel_dayof_dialog:
The $PARTYSIZE Party being held by $HOSTNAME of the $FACTION is tonight!
Cancelling the day of will seriously harm your reputation.
Are you sure you want to cancel last minute like this?
no_outfit_dialog.title: You Have Nothing to Wear!
no_outfit_dialog.body:
Madame, it's not a figure of speech.
You literally have nothing to wear to this party. If we check in with the Merchant she might have something, but otherwise you may have to cancel.
out_of_money_dialog.title: Oh No!
out_of_money_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, you appear to be completely out of money.

It looks like you'll have to borrow money from your various friends just to stay solvent.

This will cost you 20 Reputation but it will also get get you 200 Livres.
after_party_dialog.title: After Party Report
after_party_dialog.body:
The Party was hosted by the: <faction>
Your reputation changed by: <amount>
Did they like your outfit?
What was your RSVP bonus?
Big Event?
Novelty decay on your Outfit?
after_conversation_dialog.success.title: Félicitations!
after_conversation_dialog.success.body_c: You've managed to charm all of the guests!
out_of_money_and_rep_dialog.body:
I'm sorry Madame, you appear to be completely out of money.

Unfortunatley, it appears that you don't have enough Reputation to actually get the loans you'd need to continue.

I'm sorry Madamme, but I think this might be the end.
ambush_dialog.title: Ambushed!
ambush_dialog.body:
You've been Ambushed in the $ROOMNAME!
Prepare for Conversation!

conversation_intro.3: Oh, I've heard so much about you!
conversation_intro.4: You simply must meet my friends!
host_remark_intro.0: Have you enjoyed yourself so far?
host_remark_intro.1: What do you think of the new king?
host_remark_intro.2: Has the music been to your liking?
host_remark_intro.3: Have you seen latest opera yet?
host_remark_intro.4: Wherever did you get that dress?
reputation_text.1: Level 1: Pierre will approach you with special Gossip Requests
reputation_text.2: Level 2: You can get Reparte Bonuses in Conversations
reputation_text.3: Level 3: +5% Chance to Seduce a Party Host
reputation_text.4: Level 4: Your Remarks now a 25% stronger effect on your Enemies
reputation_text.5: Level 5: You now have 10% more time in Turns against a Host and to reply to their Remarks
reputation_text.6: Level 6: You're invited to all Decent Parties, regardless of Faction
reputation_text.7: Level 7: Another +5% Chance to Seduce Party Hosts (+10% Total)
reputation_text.8: Level 8: Attending a Party with a coordinated Outfit and Accessory may cause Fashion to shift your way
reputation_text.9: Level 9: You're invited to all Decent Parties, regardless of Faction
proceed_without_rsvp: You have unanswered invitations to parties tonight! Are you sure you want to skip them?
party.description.default: This party is being hosted by some dude or dudette. This segment will later have randomly generated Text describing the party. It should be pretty damn funny.
party.description.tutorial: The Orphan's Feast is a small social gathering spot for people of every class of society, though almost everyone who comes here does so alone.
party.intro.tutorial.body:
Bonjour Madame and Welcome to the Orphan's Feast!

You're alone? Don't worry! You'll find some of our other patrons in the next room.

In fact, we even have a some truly esteemed individuals here here tonight. They're getting drinks in the back room. You simply MUST talk to them before you leave!
party.intro.tutorial.title: Welcome!
party_crown_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Crown. They like outfits that are both luxurious and modest.
party_church_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Church. They like outfits that are both humble and modest.
party_military_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Military. They're a bit of a wildcard when it comes to outfits.
party_bourgeoisie_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Bourgeoisie. They like outfits that are both luxurious and revealing.
party_revolution_likes_and_dislikes: This party is being held by the Revolution. They like outfits that are both humble and revealing.
party_objectives:
• Your rival, Catherine Uzes, will be there
• Collect Gossip concerning the Church
• Speak with Ferdinand Foix
• Charm Mme. Agnes Taillefer III
party_invitation: Requests the attendance of $PLAYER to $PRONOUN $PARTY on $DATE. This $SIZE party is sure to be $FLUFF.
rsvp:
Skip this Party and you will suffer 
Backbiting: -50% to Seduction Chance
wardrobeTutorialStep: Click on a drawer to try on an outfit.
tutorial_go_step: Click here when you've found an outfit you like!
tutorial_intro_step:
This is the party map. You always enter parties via the vestibule.

Click on the lobby to go there.
tutorial_punchbowl_step:
Now that you've charmed the first room, let's move to the next one.

This room has wine in it, and will refill your glass whenever you enter it.
tutorial_host_step:
This room has some important guests in it.

If anyone knows where Armand is, it's them!
tutorial_remark_step: These are your remarks, click on one to select it.
tutorial_guest_step:
Click on a guest to say your remark to them.
Try matching this remark's subject with what one of the guests is talking about.
tutorial_leave_party_step:
Now that you've made an impression on the host,
you're free to leave whenever you want.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_selltab_step00:
I don’t just sell incredible outfits here, I also buy them! Right now, you’re looking at what I have in stock, but let’s see what you have first.
Select the selling button to look at your own outfits.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_outfitstats_step02:
Every outfit has four traits: modesty, luxury, novelty and style. Different factions prefer different looks.
For example, the Crown likes things that are luxurious and modest, but the Revolution prefers you look understated and racy. 
Dressing for the occasion make you more confident, and give you more remarks will give you more confidence at parties.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_outfitstyle_step03:
You should also make sure that your outfit is in style.
The popular style changes every week or so, so make sure that you stay current!
Having an in-style outfit will help you get new remarks faster at parties.
tutorial_lepetitmogul_buytab_step04: Now, let’s see what I have in stock!
tutorial_lepetitmogul_buyoutfit_step05:
Select one of my lovely outfits to see if it’s to your liking.
Remember my stock changes every day, so be sure to visit often!

commodity.gossip.name: Some Cheap Gossip
commodity.reputation.name: Reputation
commodity.reputation.crown.name: Reputation (Crown)
commodity.reputation.church.name: Reputation (Church)
commodity.reputation.military.name: Reputation (Military)
commodity.reputation.bourgoeisie.name: Reputation (Bourgeoisie)
commodity.reputation.revolution.name: Reputation (Revolution)
commodity.livre.name: Livre
stat.credibility.name: Credibility
stat.peril.name: Peril
crown1power: The Queen was recently seen bedecked in a spectacular new diamond necklace. Is it a sign of royal power, or unnecessary excess?
crown2power: A group of aristocrats have been trying to secure foreign sources of grain. Is it, as they claim, to distribute to starving farmers, or to hoard it for themselves?
crown3power: The Queen plans to grant a title to one of her closest female friends. Is the Queen recognizing merit or merely giving honors to her personal favorites?
revolution1power: A book salesman was recently arrested for printing profane criticism of the royal family. Is it punishment for vulgar slander, or repression of necessary criticism?
revolution2power: A trio of Third Estate delegates, in Paris for the Esates General, were detained by the Guet Royale. Were the Guet harassing honorable men, or forced to act against boorish provacateurs?
revolution3power: An aristocrat challenged a prominent revolutionary thinker to a duel of honor, who dismissed the challenge as barbaric. Is the thinker a enlightened man discarding old, unlawful traditions, or simply a coward?
bourgeoisie1power: A coalition of members of the Bourgeoisie have been investing large amount of money in hot air balloons. Are they visionaries, or just wasting money on ridiculous fancies?
bourgeoisie2power: A lawyer recently got in a fist fight with an aristocrat, who tried to claim his seat at the opera. Is this a sign of abuse by the nobility, or the lawyer's unnecessary impudence?
bourgeoisie3power: Some of the Paris's foremost industrialists have been trying to deregulate the price of bread. Is to allow bakers to have the money to make more bread, or is to profiteer off of hunger?
bourgeoisie1allegiance: Some representatives from the Third Estate have gotten free rooms to stay in from a prominent hotelier. However, they've been staying for a long time. Is this a sign of friendship, or are the representatives taking advantage of their host?
bourgeoisie2allegiance: A group of vinters are preparing a petition to reduce taxes on wine. Are they trying to make things affordable for the common man, or just increasing their profit margins?
bourgeoisie3allegiance: A wealth financier thinks the revolutionaries need to focus their efforts on drafting a constitution. Is he a pragmatic friend of the revolution, or a dismisive boor?
military1power: An older veteran, who stands accused of murder, has been discovered to be recieving care packages delivered by soldiers to his jail cell. Is this a sign of loyalty, or corruption?
military2power: A Captain in the Garde Royale was recently caught engaging in an utterly staggering number of extra-marital affairs. Is he a vulgar cad, or a romantic rogue?
military3power: There's been a sudden increase in soldiers taking second jobs throughout the city. Is this a dereliction of duty, or a sign that they need to be paid more?
military1allegiance: The King plans to weigh in on a legal case where an enlisted man struck an officer during an argument at a local theater. Is this attentiveness from the King, or an infringement on military discipline?
military2allegiance: They say that the King has been discussing changes to how the army pays its wages. Is the new pay schedule a necessary reform, or a way to pay troops even less?
military3allegiance: The King's ministers are begging him to supplement the army's presence around Paris with more foreign mercenaries. Is this meant to relieve exhausted troops, or is the nobility unsure of their loyalty?
church1power: A country priest, in Paris for the Estates General, has been granting asylum to accused criminals. Is he intervening on behalf of the people, or obstructing justice?
church2power: A bishop has recently intervened on behalf of a group of accused prostitutes. Is he protecting the virtue of innocent women, or trying to cover his own vices?
church3power: A group of priests are raising money to buy large parcels of farmland from destitute farmers. Is it an act of of relief or just expanding the Church's ownership of France?
church1allegiance: A bishop has called for the censorship an opera critical of the Church. The king has signalled his assent, but has taken weeks to make a pronouncement. Is the king taking the request seriously, or ignoring it?
church2allegiance: Representatives from the Third Estate have been calling on priests to rally in favor of land reforms. Is this a recognition of the Church's authority, or crude sabre rattling?
church3allegiance: The King has been sending personal representatives to Rome to negotiate with the Pope. Is he moving closer to the holy Father, or snubbing the clergy of France by ignoring them?
exhaustion_level_1: Exhaustion Level 1: Tiny credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.
exhaustion_level_2: Exhaustion Level 2: Small credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.
exhaustion_level_3: Exhaustion Level 3: Significant credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.
exhaustion_level_4: Exhaustion Level 4: Large credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.
exhaustion_level_5: Exhaustion Level 5: Major credibility penalty at your next party or rendezvous.
well_rested: Well Rested: Small credibility bonus at your next party or rendezvous.

incidents.transitions.credibilitycheck.m: This choice requires a medium credibility challenge
incidents.transitions.credibilitycheck.h: This choice requires a hard credibility challenge
incidents.transitions.perilgain.smalltoo: This choice will increase your peril by a small amount
incidents.transitions.perilgain.mediumto: This choice will increase your peril by a medium amount
incidents.transitions.perilgain.largetoo: This choice will increase your peril by a large amount
Yvette.name: Yvette Decaux
18152.A Promenade.node.6: This is the perfect place to go with someone who wanted to get some fresh air, without the oppressing crowds of the city.
18152.A Promenade.node.5: You head home immediately, taking a detour through some of the more lively parts of time in order to get your energy back up again. Hopefully, you won't have occassion to visit the gardens too often.
18152.A Promenade.node.4: After lingering a few minutes further, you head home. Hopefully, you'll be able visit the gardens again soon.
18152.A Promenade.node.3: Pulling out your journal, you jot down the location. (Jardin Des Plantes is now an available rendezvous location)
18152.A Promenade.node.2: Looking around at the well manicured greenery, you realize that you've arrvied at the Jardin Des Plantes. It's beautiful and tranquil. A lush respite from the bustle and cacophany of the city. Couples stroll the paths, arm in arm. Furtive glances and nods of respect are exchanged between passing groups, as people put forth their best efforts to see and be seen.
18152.A Promenade.node.1: Just as you cross the street, you spot a verdant clearing ahead of you.
18152.A Promenade.node.0: Deciding to explore the 5th arrondisement today, you stroll along the southern banks of the river Seine. Barges sail up and down the river, jockeying for position with the pleasure crafts of the wealthy, and the ocassional floating bathhouse. A merry patron of one such bathhouse waves to you from the comfort of his tub.
18152.A Promenade.link.5: "Walking in circles doesn't feel like my idea of a fun evening."
18152.A Promenade.link.4: "It's nice to get a break from Paris sometimes."
13228.A Lively Place.node.6: With a shake of your head you turn and start the long walk home. The music fades into the distance and you welcome the hustle, bustle, and sophistication at the heart of Paris.
13228.A Lively Place.node.5: The entertainment may be on the coarse side for some, but it's perfect for those that just want to relax and have fun.
13228.A Lively Place.node.4: After a spending a few hours taking in the crowds and bobbing in time with the lively music, you decide to head home, but you have a feeling you'll be back there soon.
13228.A Lively Place.node.3: Sitting down at one of the rustic tables, you note down the guinguette in your journal. (Guinguette Paradis is now an available rendezvous location)
13228.A Lively Place.node.2: Turning a corner you stumble upon an idyllic looking establishment named 'Guinguette Paradis'. A band plays music, while the patrons drink wine and dance.
13228.A Lively Place.node.1: Passing through a checkpoint at the city's outer wall, you hear the sounds of music and raucous laughter.
13228.A Lively Place.node.0: Feeling like you could use some fresh air, you decide to take your travels to the edge of the Paris. As much as you like the city, the change of pace is appreciated.
13228.A Lively Place.link.5: "If I wanted drunk strangers and rustic music, then I would have stayed back in the village."
13228.A Lively Place.link.4: "Everyone here seems to be having a great time, and I can't blame them. This is a lot of fun."
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.164: You get drawn into a conversation about the Revolution and the Military. Nationalists are upset that the military has been disbursing protests and other political gatherings. Soldiers claim they following their orders from the king, as required by law.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.163: You get drawn into a conversation about the Revolution and the Military. Nationalists are upset that the military has been disbursing protests and other political gatherings. Soldiers claim they following their orders from the king, as required by law.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.162: You get drawn into a conversation about the Bourgeoisie and the Revolution. Times have been hard for the poorest people of Paris and some believe that the richest members of the common people have a duty to provide food and other assistance to the poor. Others are saying that without the nobility or the church paying taxes, the wealthiest commoners are already paying the lion's share of taxes and can't afford to keep giving away their money.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.161: You get drawn into a conversation about the Bourgeoisie and the Revolution. Times have been hard for the poorest people of Paris and some believe that the richest members of the common people have a duty to provide food and other assistance to the poor. Others are saying that without the nobility or the church paying taxes, the wealthiest commoners are already paying the lion's share of taxes and can't afford to keep giving away their money.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.160: You get drawn into a conversation about the Military and the Church. Given the rising tensions, patriotically minded people are asking where the loyalties of French priests lie. After all, the Catholic Church is a foreign government with its own laws. More pious citizens are saying that even asking that question is blasphemy, and that a priest's first duty is always to the people of thier parish.

13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.42: Having reasoned that the Church is the most powerful of the minor factions in Paris, you glance over your notes and instantly come to the conclusion that they’ve put their entire support behind the King and the aristocracy.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.41: Opening your eyes, you switch your focus to something more specific. You scan the room, looking at the way everyone is dressed, and at their body language. You’re looking for more subtle hints about where everyone’s allegiances lie. More notes quickly scratched into your journal.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.40: Opening your eyes, you switch your focus to something more specific. You scan the room, looking at the way everyone is dressed, and at their body language. You’re looking for more subtle hints about where everyone’s allegiances lie. More notes quickly scratched into your journal.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.39: It doesn’t take long to realize that the Revolution isn’t just more powerful than the Crown, but that the difference in power is massive. The royal family and their loyal aristocrats have quite a fight ahead of them if they want to resist the Revolution’s demands.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.38: After a few minutes, it becomes obvious that the Revolution is significantly more powerful than the Crown. While it might be possible for the Crown to resist the Revolution’s demands, they would have to build strong alliances with the other factions in order to do so.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.37: It takes a while before you come to the conclusion that the Revolution is more powerful than the Crown. The difference in power, however, is not that large. In fact, it wouldn’t take a great reversal of fortune for the Revolution to find themselves on their back foot. Maintaining strong alliances from the other factions will be important to their success.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.36: Opening your eyes, you switch your focus to something more specific. You scan the room, looking at the way everyone is dressed, and at their body language. You’re looking for more subtle hints about where everyone’s allegiances lie. More notes quickly scratched into your journal.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.35: You listen for what feels like an hour and you still can’t draw any solid conclusions. It seems like the Crown and the Revolution are so evenly matched that you can’t determine which one would prevail in any sort of conflict. The victor would most certainly be determined by the strength of their alliances.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.34: It takes a while before you come to the conclusion that the Crown is more powerful than the Revolution. The difference in power, however, is not that large. In fact, it wouldn’t take a great reversal of fortune for the Crown to find themselves on their back foot. Maintaining strong alliances from the other factions will be important to their success.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.33: After a few minutes, it becomes obvious that the Crown is significantly more powerful than the Revolution. While it might be possible for the Revolution to make the Crown give into their demands, they would have to build strong alliances with the other factions in order to do so.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.32: It doesn’t take long to realize that the Crown isn’t just more powerful than the Revolution, but that the difference in power is massive. The nationalists in the Third Estate have quite a fight ahead of them if they want to make the Crown give into their demands.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.31: Taking out your journal and a traveler’s pencil, you close your eyes and relax, just focusing on listening to the whole bustling cafe. Not focusing on one individual conversation, but just letting the sum total of the room flow into your ears, and then assessing it all together. Occasionally, you open your eyes to jot down a quick note.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.30: She favors you with a quick curtsey before leaving. You sip at your drink and get settled in. It feels familiar in a way, like a louder and livelier version of ‘Le Cygne’, a tavern you used to frequent back home.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.29: She favors you with a quick curtsey before leaving. You sip at your drink and get settled in. It feels familiar in a way, like a louder and livelier version of ‘Le Cygne’, the tavern you used to frequent back home
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.28: “Now, if you can excuse me madame, I must get back to my other tables.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.27: “After that? You head home with a little more energy, a little more knowledge, and hopefully you’re a little more well liked. That’s all there is, really!”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.26: “Once you’ve listened for a while, you’ll probably get dragged into one of the debates. Be carefully with your answer, as news travels fast. Depending on who you support in the debate, you can earn some favor with one faction, and lose some reputation with another.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.25: “After you get your drink, you can settle in and listen to our patrons here. Everyone here is obsessed with politics, so it’s a great place to find out who among the high and mighty is doing particularly well at the moment. Everything is always shifting in Paris, so it’s nice to come in regularly and stay on top of things.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.24:
“First you come in and sit down, and order something. While we can’t make you order anything, we would strongly prefer that you order some coffee.” She stops to stare at you significantly for a moment. 

“The coffee also perks you up, and makes you less exhausted, if you’re feeling tired. It’s no substitute for sleep, but it’s a start!”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.23: “Oh, the cafe!” the woman exclaims, suddenly understanding your point. “Don’t worry, everything here is pretty simple, I’ve watched it play out with our patrons the same way everyday, for the last few years.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.22: “Is there anything else you’d like to know about?”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.21: At the sound of fresh giggling from Monsieur Boehmer’s table she leans in close to you and whispers behind her hand “He’s not actually that funny, the laughing is just good for business.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.20: As for the women, they are... prostitutes.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.19: Instantly, the woman is all smiles, once again. “Oh yes, an excellent choice madame!”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.18: With a scowl, she skulks away to attend to the other customers, while you applaud yourself for your thriftiness. She shortly returns with your water, which is surprisingly cool and refreshing.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.17: “Is there anything else I can get you?”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.16: “Oui, madame. I shall fetch you free water, while you occupy a table in our busy cafe.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.15: “If you insist, madame, I’ll leave you to your refreshments.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.14:
Before you mix in anything, you decide to taste the coffee by itself. It’s bitter and acidic, but also full and potent. Very potent. You now understand why the customers are all so energetic.

(You have lost one level of exhaustion!)
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.13:
She returns with your coffee, steaming and hot. The porcelain cup clinks lightly as she sets it down, along with containers of sugar and milk. 

“Enjoy, madame!” she says before curtseying again and leaving to attend to the other customers.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.12: She gives you a quick curtsey before she checks in with another table, taking their order as well. You sigh deeply and take in the cafe around you. The whole place hums with excitement. Voices ebb and flow likes the waves of the ocean as patrons make new pronouncements and trade verbal barbs with their compatriots.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.11: You gesture around the cafe as you ask the question, and the woman follows your gesture as it accidentally points towards a portly older man surrounded by a group of politely giggling young women. “Oh, that?” she asks. “That man is Monsieur Boehmer, he’s a regular.”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.9:
“Oh, certainly madame!” she replies happily.

(You have spent 3 Livres)
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.7: “Bonjour madame, my name is Anne and let me be the first to welcome you to Cafe Principe!”
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.6: Finding a seat at an empty table, you’re approached by the woman from before.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.5: Inside, the coffee house is packed with customers engaged in animate conversation and gesticulating wildly with cups of steaming coffee. Growing up, you were often told that religion and politics made for poor conversation, but it appears that none of these people got the same message.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.4: Sensing the hostility in this rhetorical question, the students quickly dissipate. Satisfied, the woman in the apron heads back inside. With the doorway cleared, you happily enter Cafe Principe.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.3: However, before you can give up on this venture, a woman in a coffee stained apron emerges from the door. She loudly asks if any of the students are actually interested in buying anything, or if they’re just hanging around to look important.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.2: Eventually, you arrive at a bustling coffee house with large glass windows. The sign outside reads 'Cafe Principe'. Your heart sinks at the site of the massive crowd of students milling around outside the cafe. It doesn’t look like you’ll be able to get in at all.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.1: Your nose picks up the scent of fine coffee and you find yourself subconsciously gravitating towards the origin of this delightful smell. The closer you get to the source of the scent, the thicker the crowds become.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.node.0: Strolling through the 6th arrondissement, you weave your way through crowds of excited students, pontificating intellectuals, and agitated artists. It feels like every corner is home to another gallery, or part of the various academies strewn throughout the district.
13180.Coffee and Conversation.link.255: "The Military is right. Titles don't place one above the rules. They should be proud to wear the King's uniform."

13180.Coffee and Conversation.link.9: “May I just have some water, please?”
18778.Fine Dining.node.7: Without even so much as a 'bonjour' to the proprietor, you decide to head home. Already, you're looking forward to one of Camille's home cooked meals, which you can eat however you like.
18778.Fine Dining.node.6: This feels like the perfect place to visit with someone who cares about fine food, and prefers a formal setting.
18778.Fine Dining.node.5: You spend a few minutes chatting with the staff and perusing the menu before you head home, visions of a feast dancing in your head. Perhaps you'll be able to return, sometime soon.
18778.Fine Dining.node.4: You pull out your journal and jot the address down. (La Grande Taverne de Londres is now an available rendezvous location)
18778.Fine Dining.node.3: Inside, you find a dining room brightly lit by crystal chandeliers, and furnished with mahogany tables draped in fine linen tablecloths. A few aristocrats look up from their table at you, and you suddenly feel rather underdressed in your day clothes.
18778.Fine Dining.node.2: Quickening your pace, you find a sign that reads 'La GrandeTaverne de Londres'. This is slightly puzzling, as it looks nothing like the rustic taverns you've seen elsewhere in France.
18778.Fine Dining.node.1:
Just as you feel you've become used to the city's myriad smells, your nose manages to pick up a new, suprising scent. Flavorful, yet subtle. Layered, but restrained.

You've smelled good food before, but this is something else entirely.
18778.Fine Dining.node.0: Deciding to spend the day exploring Paris, your wanderings take you to the 12th arrondisement.
18778.Fine Dining.link.6: "I'm sure the food is good, but this is a little too stuffy for my tastes."
18778.Fine Dining.link.5: "Exquisite food and an elegant atmosphere. This is exactly what I was looking for."
18066.Frivolous Follies.node.6: This must be Parc Monceau, created by the fabulously wealthy Duke of Chartres. Taking note of your surroundings, you jot the location down in your journal. (Parc Monceau is now an available rendezvous location)
18066.Frivolous Follies.node.5: Turning on your heel, you head home. While you're not particularly enthralled by the gardens and the gaudy attractions therein, you wonder who you know that would possibly be interested in that sort of thing.
18066.Frivolous Follies.node.4: After a quick loop around the gardens, you head home. Already you're dreaming of excuse to head back, and trying to figure out who else you know that might appreciate Parc Monceau as much as you do.
18066.Frivolous Follies.node.3: It's fun and tacky, the kind of place to take someone that doesn't take themselves too seriously.
18066.Frivolous Follies.node.2:
A massive garden, dotted with all sorts of fantastic buildings. Small Egyptian pyramids, Roman columns, Turkish tents, and more all cluster around a sparkling lake. People in costume strut about the different buildings, enthralling tourists with fantastic tales of dubious authenticity.

Still, it looks like everyone is having fun.
18066.Frivolous Follies.node.1: The sight that greets your eyes is nothing short of surreal.
18066.Frivolous Follies.node.0: Travelling the northern section of the 8th arrondisement, the sky is clear and the sun is shining. The crowds in this part of the city are picking up and, out of curiosity, you head in the same general direction.
18066.Frivolous Follies.link.3: "I don't think I could take too much of this for very long."
18066.Frivolous Follies.link.2: "This is absolutely ridiculous, and I can't wait to come back."
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.10: Her next words are a quiet mumble. “My mother gave it to me.”
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.9: “Oh… that…” her cheeks flush with embarrassment. “That’s lucky incense, I light it on slow business days.”
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.8:
At those words, she looks giddy to the point of bursting, but tries to play it off as a knowing smile. This deception is only half-successful. 

“Oh, I think I can help with that.”
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.7: Her eyes light up. “Madame, you have come to the right place!”
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.6: “Bonjour Madame and welcome to Le Petit Mogol!” a woman, presumably the owner, calls out to you. “How may I help you?”
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.5: As soon as the door swings shut behind you, you hear a sudden rustling of fabric further in the store. “A customer? Hamdullah!” a surprisingly young voice calls out.
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.4: You open the door and walk into the tiny shop, which seems even smaller due to how absolutely full it is. This isn’t just a boutique, it’s a workshop for whoever works here. Rolls of gorgeous fabric cover every available surface. A cloying smoke hangs in the air. The scent is pleasant, but wholly unfamiliar.
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.3: “Le Petit Mogol” you mumble to yourself idly, trying to make sure you remember the name of the shop. Eventually, you find a small boutique tucked between some far grander buildings.
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.2:
And now you’re here. Back home, they sigh and dream of places like this, then quietly get back to their little lives.

Not you. 

Your circumstances may be less than ideal, but you’re still here.
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.1: Paris may be a city swimming in fashion and finery, but this is the source. This street is home to all the major fashion houses in the country, and to Rose Bertin, personal dressmaker to the queen herself.
13408.Le Petit Mogol.node.0: It’s a long walk to Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, but the trek to the narrow street is worth it. Every block hums with a vibrant energy, bursting with life. Porters and social climbers wind their way through the streets, festooned with brightly colored parcels.
13408.Le Petit Mogol.link.12: "All of this is so new... what can you tell me about outfits and fashion?" <Tutorial>
13408.Le Petit Mogol.link.11: "I have an important party soon, and I need to look amazing." <No Tutorial>
13408.Le Petit Mogol.link.7: "All of this is so new... what can you tell me about outfits and fashion?" <Tutorial>
13408.Le Petit Mogol.link.6: "I have an important party soon, and I need to look amazing." <No Tutorial>
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.16:
Maintaining his look of indignity, he glances into his dripping wet snuff box.

“You take coins, right?”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.15: “I suppose you could say that, yes. Our social pages are our most popular section, and we’re always looking for new material. Keep it believable, I’m not wasting my money on fabrications.”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.14: You come upon a man in grubby finery, up to his knees in the fountain. His shoes have carefully been placed at the water’s edge. He does a little jig as he drops a wet coin into his snuff box, which is clutched tightly in his other hand.
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.13:
Suddenly flush with embarrassment, he pauses to look into his snuff box.

“I do hope that coins are an acceptable form of payment...”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.11:
A devious smile crosses his face. 

“New to this, are you? Don’t worry, it’s much easier than you think.”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.10: He raises an eyebrow conspiratorially and leans in closer to you. His breath smells like cheap brandy. “You are in luck Madame, because we are always willing to pay for such valuable… information.”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.8:
The stranger’s smile sours and he marches out of the fountain.

“I shall have you know, that fundraising is far more difficult than it appears. Even the most noble of men must occasionally stoop low to accomplish great things.”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.7: His smile broadens and the man bows, his manner suddenly as elegant as the finest courtiers of Versailles. “Why, in fact I am, bonne damme! My name is Pierre Renaudot.
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.6: Noticing your presence, the main in the fountain turns to you with a nod and a smile that attempts to be ingratiating. “Bonjour madame.”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.4:
It’s at that moment you realize the splashing in the fountain is getting louder, accompanied by some of the most inventive profanity you’ve ever heard.

Against your better judgement, you decide to investigate.
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.3:
“Office temporarily closed. Engaging in emergency fund raising efforts. We apologize for the inconvenience

- Management

PS: Fear not this setback, the light of journalism shall never fade!”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.2: The door is locked, so you give it a knock. Nobody answers. Looking around, you find a hastily written note lodged in the door frame. It reads:
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.1: Suddenly, the alleys open up into a wider street near a square. You can hear the splashing of a fountain nearby. You finally find the sign for ‘La Trompette du Peuple’, the paint appears to be fresh, but the office seems awfully small.
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.node.0: You walk through the city, following Camille's directions. Eventually, you find yourself threading through narrower and narrower streets. The alleys, packed with refuse and the occasional vagrant napping in the shade, feel almost oppressive in their closeness.
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.link.8: “If I wanted to sell some gossip, how would that work?” <Tutorial>
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.link.4: “If I wanted to sell some gossip, how would that work?” <Tutorial>
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.link.3: “I have some valuable… social information for sale”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.link.1: “Are you serious? This is your emergency fundraising?”
16866.That Most Reputable Paper.link.0: “Are you Pierre, the esteemed editor of ‘La Trompette du Peuple’?”
16882.The Limits of Taste.node.6:
With the address noted down, you hurry home before the crowds start forming outside. You wonder if they'll ever figure out how to control that monkey.

Probably not.
16882.The Limits of Taste.node.5: This feels like the perfect place to visit with someone that loves to laugh. Someone that isn't afraid of liking things that are a little bawdy or lowbrow.
16882.The Limits of Taste.node.4:
With the address noted down, you start the walk home, already eager to see one of their shows. Maybe they'll have figured out how to control the monkey by then.

Part of you hopes not.
16882.The Limits of Taste.node.3: When you finally tire of watching the monkey shreik at is handler and pelt them with scraps of fruit, you take out your pencil and journal to jot down the address of the theater. (Les Grands-Danseurs du Roi is now an available rendezvous location)
16882.The Limits of Taste.node.2:
Out of sheer curiosity, you step inside. There isn't a production going on at the moment, but you see actors and carpenters rushing around to ready the theater for its next show tonight.

The frantic energy is only amplified by the sight of a hapless young man trying to corral a dancing monkey back into its cage. The monkey doesn't seem interested in cooperating.
16882.The Limits of Taste.node.1: Strolling down the wide, tree lined street, you finally find what you're looking for. Les Grands-Danseurs du Roi. It's the best known theater in the city, specializing two things: comedies, and skirting the absolute limits of good taste.
16882.The Limits of Taste.node.0: Today, you decide to explore the Boulevard du Temple between the 11th and 3rd arrondisments. It's the place in the city best known for its theaters.
16882.The Limits of Taste.link.5: "This just feels like vulgarity for the sake of it. I'd rather not."
16882.The Limits of Taste.link.4: "This is absolutely delightful. I can't wait to see it in full swing."
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.14: The walk home is short and uneventful, much like your time at La Place Royale.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.13: The walk home is short and uneventful, save for your daydreams of what secrets you may find in that place.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.12: The socialites in the square are starting to filter out to their dinner appointments and other social commitments, and you decide to head home as well.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.11: After you feel a little a more comfortable with how things work here, you stroll about the square. Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you pretend to be a traveller just admiring the apartments and gardens.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.10: It all feels so tense. Artisocrats and courtiers merrily flit from conversation to conversation with a practiced ease, but you can never lose the feeling that nobody has really let their guard down. Everything they do is a kind of public performance, reinforcing an image they're trying to create.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.9: Stepping back, underneath a shady awning, you take some time to really take it all in.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.8:
After an hour or so, you manage to overhear something useful. Pierre will be very interested in this.

(You have acquired some new Gossip)
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.7: Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you stroll about the square, pretending to be a traveller just admiring the apartments and gardens.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.6: Everyone here is either well dressed, or dressed so casually that it only draws attention to how powerful they must be. After all, only the truly powerful can afford to downplay their importance.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.5:
Of course, without the benefit of a title or an introduction, you can’t approach any of these people directly. 

However, there’s nothing to stop you from overhearing things as you just ‘pass by’.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.4: You see the elegantly dressed aristocrats strutting about the gardens, stopping briefly to chat in hushed tones.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.3: La Place Royale, the favored social spot for all the aristocrats in the city. The hub of all gossip, social news, slander, and scandal. If there was ever a telling secret, or a salacious rumor, this was the place to find it.
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.1: Growing up, you read incessantly about Paris, devouring any book or map you could find. Yet for some reason you can’t remember what makes this area special, beyond nice homes and some buildings built in the 1300s…
17958.The Rumour Mill.node.0: Crossing between the 3rd and 4th arrondissements, you’re struck by the beauty of the buildings around you. Some of the oldest buildings in city are here, surrounded by the homes of wealthy aristocrats. The entrances of these elegant homes are blocked by garishly dressed doormen, who honestly look more bored than imposing.
17958.The Rumour Mill.link.14: "Well, that was dull. At least I got something valuable out of it."
17958.The Rumour Mill.link.13: "This could be a nice way to replenish my funds if things become difficult."
17958.The Rumour Mill.link.7: "Interesting, but I'd rather observe a little first."
17958.The Rumour Mill.link.4: "It's like being in a gold mine. Time to take my share..."
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.35: "I'm sure that if you ask around, you'll be able to find your fiance in no time!"
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.34: That was something you were looking forward to. A chance to be something more.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.33: Back in your provincial hometown, you were engaged to Armand, before he moved north to Paris to participate in the Estates General. He dreamed of changing the country, and this was the political event of the century. You mailed love letters soaked in perfume, he replied with volumes about how much he missed you. The romance of it all helped make up for the inconvenience.

13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.27: She favors you with a devious smile "Find guests worth talking to, and try to say the right things to the right people. You'll never have time to talk to everyone, so try to use your time wisely."
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.26:
With a grunt of irritation, the coachman flicks at his reins and the carriage surges forward, sending you lurching back into your seat. The city blurs by as you wind your way towards The Orphan's Feast, a tavern where Armand said he would meet you.

As tired and rumpled as you are, you're glad that he arranged to meet you in a place with ample food and wine.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.25: Not that your parents cared much about the romance. At first you'd been afraid to tell them their youngest daughter wanted to move far away. Instead, they nearly threw you onto the carriage to follow Armand to Paris.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.24: When she puts it that way, it suddenly sounds so easy…
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.23: The barmaid pauses to think. "I haven’t heard that name before, but I just started working today. If you ask around, some of our patrons might know where to find your fiance."
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.22: “Don’t worry, while the rest of the city can be rather… cutthroat, the Orphan’s Feast is a relaxed place for getting your feet under you.” The woman puts down the lantern she was polishing.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.21: “How may I be of service?” She asks.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.20: Inside, a woman polishing a lantern looks up at you as you enter, and her face breaks into a bright smile. "Bonjour Madame and welcome to the Orphan's Feast!" Her eyes linger expectantly on the door for a moment, before settling on you. You're suddenly reminded of how rare it is for women to travel by themselves.

13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.13:
Before you know it, the carriage starts slowing down. You must be here!

Armand arranged to meet you at tavern named The Orphan’s Feast. As tired and rumpled as you are, you’re glad that he planned to meet you in a place with ample food and wine.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.12: Though part of you is worried by your unfamiliar surroundings, you mostly feel excited. This place is to be the stage for your new life.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.11:
You crane your neck out the window to peer at Paris. It’s even more than you imagined. The streets are a riot of color and energy as people go about their days. Elegant persons of fashion strut like brilliant peacocks. Students stumble under the weight of their books. Beggars alternate between pleading for alms, and shouting invectives at passers-by. 

Everything feels significant, like world’s next act hinges on all of their choices.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.10: Though part of you is worried by your unfamiliar surroundings, you mostly feel excited. This place is to be the stage for your new life.

13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.7: When you arrive, the coachman helps you out of the carriage and you find yourself outside a glowing, friendly looking tavern.
13382.Yvette's Prologue.node.6:
After a quiet sigh, the coachman obediently flicks at the reins and the horses up their pace to a brisk trot. The city blurs by as you quickly make your way towards The Orphan’s Feast, the tavern where Armand said he would meet you. 

As tired and rumpled as you are, you’re glad that he arranged to meet you in a place with ample food and wine.

19872.Thomas' Lead.node.28: You stop to think about this new information. A mystery servant, who left Maximin’s employment suddenly, and under murky circumstances. It seems fruitful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.27: Thomas stands and gives you an exaggerated bow. “Au revoir, madame.” With that, he turns and leaves.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.26: “I couldn’t find this servant’s name, where they live, or even the position they held in Maximin’s home.” Thomas pauses to leave some coins on the table for the wine. “While you don’t seem the sort to give up easily, I wanted to make sure you understood the difficulty of the task ahead of you.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.25: “Besides, I’ve been in a… similar situation. Of course, back then, I never had anyone to help me. If I can make it so that nobody ever faces such misfortunes alone again, I will have changed the world for the better.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.24: “However, I don’t see anything dishonorable about what I’m doing. Maximin has slandered your good name, and that of your fiance. Given his position, you have no means of recourse against him. It’s only right that I help you defend your character.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.23: “Well, you’re right! You’re quite the keen judge of character, madame.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.21: “Unfortunately,” Thomas pushes out his chair and stands. “I’m needed back at the barracks. Before I go, I must warn you that this mystery servant has gone to great pains to conceal their identity…”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.20: “No matter how justified that vengeance might be.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.19: “While my position grants me it’s fair share of privileges, it also means I can’t go much further than providing you with information. If I was caught actually helping you exact your revenge, it would reflect very poorly on the royal family.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.18: “We’ve known each other less than a few days? You really think I’m a man of honor?”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.17: “Unfortunately madame, I have no next step.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.16: “A servant who leaves their master, but keeps their reasons a secret… if Maximin has a weakness, then this is it.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.15: “While I couldn’t find a smoking gun, I also couldn’t help but notice that Maximin’s household goes through servants quite quickly.” He reaches into his coat pocket and hands you a list of names, presumably of servants that used to work for Maximin. “Most of them left of their own accord, usually citing things like long hours, skipped wages, and other issues. However, there’s one servant whose leaving was a complete mystery.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.14: “So, seeing a chance to correct a great injustice, I reached out to some friends around the city in order to gather intelligence. Does Maximin actually lead by example, or is all of his revolutionary talk just that... talk?”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.13: “However, if you’d prefer discretion, there’s a tavern nearby, which is always empty in the middle of the day. We can step inside there to talk.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.12: “At least when I’m wearing the Queen’s colors, people get out of my way.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.11: He throws back his head and laughs. “I don’t know if you noticed this madame, but I have a tendency to stick out, even when I’m not in uniform.” He stops to glance pointedly at the passers-by staring at him, who struggle to avert their gaze in time.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.10: “I take it that you’ve read my letter, so you know how much I regret what happened to you that night. From what I know, Maximin’s always been a bit of a prick, but I never would have suspected him to stoop so low.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.9:
Thomas leads you to the tavern and you take a seat with him. The barmaid seems to recognize him, and brings over some wine and two glasses.

“Don’t worry, I’ll cover the cost of the wine,” he assures you with a wave.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.7: “Magnifique! There’s a tavern nearby that’s always empty in the middle of the day. We’ll discuss things further there.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.6: “Should we stay here, or discuss this somewhere in private?”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.5: Not long after you’ve settled in, Thomas appears from around a corner and strides up to you. The uniform draws some attention, but people seem to make an effort of getting out of his way, so it must be useful for something. “Bonjour madame!” he calls out pleasantly. “My sincerest apologies for being late.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.4: You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with a member of the Queen’s Dragoons to learn more about your hated enemies. If anything, they must have been good decisions.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.3: Looking around, you can’t spot Thomas anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that he’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.2: Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.1: Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.
19872.Thomas' Lead.node.0: You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Thomas mentioned in his letter to you.
19872.Thomas' Lead.link.18: “I must say, I’m shocked that a man of honor like yourself is getting mixed up in all this.”
19872.Thomas' Lead.link.7: “You couldn’t be a little more discreet?”
19872.Thomas' Lead.link.6: “Let’s go somewhere away from prying eyes.”

Thomas leads you to the tavern and you take a seat with him. The barmaid seems to recognize him, and brings over some wine and two glasses.

“Don’t worry, I’ll cover the cost of the wine,” he assures you with a wave.
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.7: “Magnifique! There’s a tavern nearby that’s always empty in the middle of the day. We’ll discuss things further there.”
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.6: “Should we stay here, or discuss this somewhere in private?”
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.5: Not long after you’ve settled in, Thomas appears from around a corner and strides up to you. The uniform draws some attention, but people seem to make an effort of getting out of his way, so it must be useful for something. “Bonjour madame!” he calls out pleasantly. “My sincerest apologies for being late.”
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.4: You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with a member of the Queen’s Dragoons to learn more about your hated enemies. If anything, they must have been good decisions.
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.3: Looking around, you can’t spot Thomas anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that he’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.2: Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.1: Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.
15390.Thomas' Clue.node.0: You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Thomas mentioned in his letter to you.
15390.Thomas' Clue.link.19: “I must say, I’m shocked that a man of honor like yourself is getting mixed up in all this.”
15390.Thomas' Clue.link.7: “You couldn’t be a little more discreet?”
15390.Thomas' Clue.link.6: “Let’s go somewhere away from prying eyes.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.30: (You have gained a little favor with Louis Antoine de Saint-Just)
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.29: (You have gained a little favor with Louis Antoine de Saint-Just)
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.27:
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have lost a little favor with Louis Antoine de Saint-Just)
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.26: Eventually, with an exchange of polite nods, you part ways with your erstwhile friends in order to explore the rest of the party.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.25: After a few awkward attempts to restart the conversation, the two of them walk away, leaving you with your thoughts. You take a few moments to collect yourself before rejoining the rest of the party.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.24: “You believe we won’t succeed without violent radicals like Saint-Just to make the Crown listen to us. Yet, we’ll be able to convince our own violent extremists to stop, just with words? Both of those can’t be true at the same time.” The woman shakes her head.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.23: Well, it sounded a lot better in your head than it did out loud.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.22: You spend a few more minutes with these guests, exchanging banter and political ruminations. Eventually, with an exchange of polite nods, you part ways with your erstwhile friends in order to explore the rest of the party.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.21: Mulling over your point, he nods affably, but his friend is the one to speak first. “You’re saying that the more unflinching and dire Saint-Just becomes, the more reasonable we seem. Maybe we should encourage him.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.20: He doubtfully cocks his eyebrows, and you can feel your point start to slip away. “Then, once we won, we'd just… convince the violent uprising to stop.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.19: After your toast, you spend a few more minutes with these guests, exchanging banter and political ruminations. Much of it is unfamiliar to you, but by the end of the conversation you find yourself able to keep up pretty easily.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.18: “Agreed! To a new, harmonious France!” His friend raises her wineglass and you toast together, and drink deep of the red wine you obtained from a servant earlier.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.17: She stalks away from you as well, leaving you with your thoughts. You take a few moments to collect yourself before rejoining the rest of the party.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.16: “I hope you’re happy.” His friend hisses to you, surprisingly angry. “That kind of talk doesn’t benefit anyone.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.15: “There’s something dark in that boy, and it worries me.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.14: “It’s that zealous part that I’m worried about.” The older man replies, furrowing his brow. “I’ve never met him, but I know a few men that have. Saint-Just is very open to the idea of violence in order to secure freedoms for the Third Estate, and is quite cold to those who don’t agree. One isn’t supposed to treat politics like a religion.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.13: “Doubts? What have you heard? All I’ve heard is that he’s young, zealous, and handsome. A charismatic firebrand.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.12: “Quite right!” The man agrees with you. “The Estates General is soon, and we need to stay focused on what’s important, and what we can all agree on. Taxing the nobility, engaging in land reform, and beginning a constitutional monarchy.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.11:
“Ah, I see… you are one of his ilk.” The older man replies to you, taking a sip from his wine glass. “Another who can’t imagine progress without violence. I’m sure Saint-Just will love your fervor, give him my regards.”

He walks away from the conversation without even excusing himself.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.10: Nodding along, the older nationalist replies. "So, you saying that if we let Saint-Just to form his own movement, we'd give the first and second estates an easy choice. They must either negotiate with our peaceful reforms, or fight Saint-Just's uprising."
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.9: The woman grimaces. “I hadn’t heard that part. What about you? Do you think it was right to invite Saint-Just?”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.8: “I’m not. I’ll concede that Saint-Just’s a charismatic boy, that much is true. However, don’t forget that he led a student revolution at his own university. He tried to put the whole school to the torch! I’m all one for building alliances, but I don’t think Maximin should have invited him. The Third Estate doesn’t need people like that.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.7: A wry smile creeps across the woman’s face and she pats her friend reassuringly on the arm “A maniac? Surely, you’re just exaggerating.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.6: Before you can answer, her friend interrupts you “Of course she is. That maniac is the only person anyone here is talking about.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.5: “Louis Antoine de Saint-Just” the older man whispers to you as he steps to the side and lets you into the conversation circle. “Our host, Maximin, invited him from Blérancourt. Maximin thinks the young man would make a fine revolutionary, but I have my doubts.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.4:
“Well, that’s certainly a good start.” The woman admits, and makes some room for you in conversation circle.

“Are you looking for Monsieur Saint-Just as well?”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.3: The woman stares are her friend incredulously “How, exactly, does one spot ‘a penchant for extreme violence’?”
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.2: “I have no idea, though we should be able to spot him quite easily. Keep on the lookout for a remarkably handsome young man with charisma, a hatred for authority and a penchant for extreme violence.” The man replies, a little too loudly, while he pretends to sip from a glass of wine.
18682.The Young Firebrand.node.0: You spot two guests who are talking to each other, but appear to be on the lookout for someone else. Every few moments their conversation breaks off so they can collectively glance around the room. Something about them feels tense.
18682.The Young Firebrand.link.17: “Violence only leads to more violence. France needs civil reform, not a civil war.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.link.16: “If the Third Estate’s freedom is important, then bloodshed must be an option. Saint-Just is right.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.link.15: “Peaceful movements require a violent counterpart. Otherwise, those in power can just ignore you.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.link.11: “Bloodshed only leads to more bloodshed. France needs civil reform, not a civil war.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.link.10: “Saint-Just is the most revolutionary amongst us. We should be trying to live up to his example.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.link.9: “Peaceful movements require a violent counterpart. Otherwise, those in power can just ignore you.”
18682.The Young Firebrand.link.3: “I’d look for the way others treat them. If people keep their distance, then that’s your man.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.121: "And I think that any relationship we have moving forward, would be more pleasurable if you referred to me by that title."
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.120: She examines you carefully before continuing. "Because any relationship with another is about more than who they are. It's also about who that other sees you as."
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.119: (You have gained some favor with Honorade)
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.118: (You have fained a little favor with Honorade)
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.117: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
