18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.112: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.111: (You've gained a little favor with Honorade)
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.110: (You have gained some favor with Honorade)
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.109: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.108: (You have gained a little favor with her)
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.107: “That’s really sweet, and I’m not just making fun. You are a sweet woman.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.106: “Then again, you wouldn’t be the first.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.105: “You’re ruled by your passions. Such things aren’t in vogue in this ‘Age of Reason’, but I feel like if one is going to be controlled by anything, it should be love.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.104: Your mind brimming with new possibilities, you step inside and head upstairs. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.103: You step inside and head upstairs, your mind still reeling from the day's events. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.101: You turn to your home and see that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.100: She helps you down from the carriage and into the street in front of your house.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.99: “Hopefully, we shall meet again soon. Bonne nuit, Yvette.” She says to you before René closes the carriage door. Soon, with a crack of his whip overhead, the coachman spurs the horses into action, and the carriage winds through the streets and disappears into the night.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.98: For a moment she seems disappointed, but quickly returns to normal. “No matter, it was a mere flight of fancy.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.95: “I would much prefer if you called me ‘Madame Gazel’, when you addressed me.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.94: “When I introduced myself earlier, I told you to call me Honorade. Now that I’ve spoken with you a little more, I’ve had a change of heart.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.93: “When I introduced myself earlier, I told you to call me Honorade. Now that I’ve spoken with you a little more, I’ve had a change of heart.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.92: “Yvette, may I ask you to do something for me?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.91: Honorade offers her hand, to help you up as you get out of your seat. When you take her hand, you find yourself looking into her eyes.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.90: You barely notice it when the carriage arrives at your home. Without interrupting you, Honorade signals to René. The coachman silently hops from his box at the head of the carriage and opens your door for you.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.89: Love and loss. Passion and transgression.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.88: Your mind brimming with new possibilities, you step inside and head upstairs. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.87: You step inside and head upstairs, your mind still reeling from the day's events. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.85: You turn to your home and see that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.84: “Hopefully, we shall meet again under better circumstances. Bonne nuit, Yvette.” She says to you before closing the carriage door. With a crack of his whip overhead, René, the coachman spurs the horses into action, and the carriage winds through the streets and disappears into the night.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.83:
With a rustle of skirts, Honorade leans to the carriage door and opens it for you. As you’re helping yourself down into the streets, Honorade peers out at your shabby home and simply shrugs to you.

“Don't worry. Everyone has to start somewhere.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.82: The lurching stop of the carriage jolts you awake. You notice a wet patch of drool on the corner of your mouth, which you furiously blot away with a handkerchief.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.81: Soon, you find yourself struggling just to stay awake. Every blink feels like it lasts an hour.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.80: The journey to your home in Paris lasts for a long time, but it doesn’t feel that way. Honorade plays the part of hostess wonderfully, always managing to guide the conversation in a satisfying direction. Unlike so many other of the persons you’ve met in Paris, she seems completely uninterested in polite small talk, focusing instead on more interesting subjects.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.79: As the journey drags on, the conversation slows down. The darkness, and rocking of the carriage, combined with the exhaustion of the night’s events slow you to a crawl.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.78: “I’m glad to know you haven’t fallen into that little trap, yourself.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.77: “We yearn for a beloved that would do anything for us, and us for them. Yet, the moment we see a pair of lovers actually behaving this way, we tell them that they’re sick or wicked.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.76: “Life is for the living, but feeling is a part of living, even when the emotion is upsetting.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.75: “However...” Honorade gestures to the luxurious gloom about her. “I feel that the trappings suit me, non?"
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.74: Her knowing, devilish demeanor cracks for a moment, and her eyes take on a far-away, melancholy look to them. “That… is exactly how he would have put it. You are both right. One can’t grieve forever, there is so much of life left to live.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.72: “I think so too,” Honorade replies, her lips twisting up into a devilish smile. “How can we say that we love someone, if we’re not willing to defy the rules of decency to do it?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.71: “I can’t say that I agree, or at least I don’t think that mourning’s set length is there for a good reason. I think those rules were set up by those who can’t stand to see others in pain, so they simply demanded that everyone buries how they feel.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.70: Despite her mournful trappings, you haven’t yet seen Honorade look particularly forlorn.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.69: “What do you think? Is two and a half years too long to mourn for lost love?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.68: “You’re very polite. Most, when they hear that, take it upon themselves to chide me for my ‘breach of decency’.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.67: You maintain a neutral expression, but you can’t help but dwell on the fact that two and a half years is far longer than any prescribed period of mourning. You’ve heard of widows wearing a black weeper on their gowns for a few months longer than most, but this is something else entirely.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.66: “You see, as of last week... it’s been two and a half years.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.65: She sighs. “That is a reasonable question, though not one I like answering.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.64: “That’s really sweet, and I’m not just making fun. You are a sweet woman.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.63: “Then again, you wouldn’t be the first.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.61: “Perhaps I am getting ahead of myself, but I imagine the next question you’ll ask me is how long I have been in mourning for, no?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.60: “You’re ruled by your passions. Such things aren’t in vogue in this ‘Age of Reason’, but I feel like if one is going to be controlled by anything, it should be love.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.59: She may only be a few years older than you, but the way Honorade smiles at your answer is almost nostalgic. “Running away to the beauty of Paris? To see and be seen among the philosophers and the persons of fashion?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.58: “It must have been quite an awful, stifling place to make you run half way across the country to be here.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.57: “You left everything behind and travelled far away, all for love?” Honorade smiles distantly and runs her hand along the satin cushion that she’s sitting on. “I like that.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.56: “What made you want to come to Paris?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.55: “Hah! Listen to me. That was certainly more than you asked for. Now, what about you?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.54: “However, when Charles passed, I kept getting invitations. He had so many friends, and I hated the idea of letting him down more than the idea of being in a room filled with people I don’t care about, so I started going.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.53: “Crowds don’t really suit me, you see. I prefer more… intimate gatherings.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.52: “Until a few years ago, I was actually quite the homebody. My husband’s textile mills made more than enough money for me to live a life of leisure, which he was happy to let me do. Though, I’m sure he was frustrated by my unwillingness to attend all the big parties his clients would throw.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.51: “I’m glad to know you haven’t fallen into that little trap, yourself.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.50: “We yearn for a beloved that would do anything for us, and us for them. Yet, the moment we see a pair of lovers actually behaving this way, we tell them that they’re sick or wicked.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.49: “Life is for the living, but feeling is a part of living, even when the emotion is upsetting.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.48: “To answer your question, which I’ve so rudely stated for you: I don’t. Not really, at least.” She chuckles into her glass before taking a leisurely sip. “Of course, now that I know what they did to you, I have no intention of getting to know that conniving wretch at all.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.46: “Forgive me for being rude, but I imagine your next question is that you’re wondering how I know our host.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.45: “However...” Honorade gestures to the luxurious gloom about her. “I feel that the trappings suit me, non?"

18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.27: “Would you believe that I don’t? Not really, at least.” She chuckles into her glass before taking a leisurely sip. “Of course, now that I know what they did to you, I have no intention of getting to know that conniving wretch at all.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.26: She sighs. “That is a reasonable question, though not one I like answering.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.25: “Please, indulge me. What would you like to know?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.24: Honorade interrupts your train of thought “But of course, the best way to fix that, is by not being strangers. Ask me some questions, so you may properly judge my character.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.23: You are slightly uncomfortable, probably because she’s making a good point. You stop to wonder if you’d be any good at leaping from a moving carriage.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.21: She examines you intently while she sips her water. “I assume you are already planning your revenge, non?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.20: “You must be quite strong, to endure such dreadful treatment.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.19: “How vile,” she replies. “To find a person who has been beset by such great misfortune, then to mistreat them so, just to posture among one’s cohorts? That is truly despicable.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.18:
After a long silence, Honorade leans over to the window and looks out through one of the few spots not obscured by black crepe.

“Now, I’m sure you already know just how dangerous it is to accept rides home from strangers. We could be going anywhere right now, and you wouldn’t even know it.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.17: “If you insist…” Honorade replies, looking off to the side while she sips at her water. “However, at the risk of being intrusive, I must caution against carrying all of your burdens alone. It is not healthy.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.16: Honorade doesn’t speak for a while, instead choosing to stare into her glass of water with an expression of surprise and disgust.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.15: “Why were they so dreadfully cruel to you?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.14: “While I saw you a few times during the party tonight, and I know that you’re new to Paris, we never had a chance to properly introduce ourselves. However, I did manage to hear about your most unfortunate run in with our host.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.13: She knocks delicately on the roof compartment, and with a clean crack of the coachman’s whip, the carriage makes way towards Paris.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.12: “Just Yvette it is, then.” She replies with a shrug. “Shall we be off?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.11: “It’s a pleasure to meet you, Yvette Decaux. Shall we be off?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.10: “My name is Honorade, what should I call you? Madame…”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.9: A delicate, pale hand reaches out from the darkness to you. You take her hand and step inside.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.8: With that, René, the coachman hops down from his box and opens the door for you. He wears the same, colorful livery of most servants, but it’s adorned with a black badge on his breast. You squint to peer at the woman inside, but to no avail. Between the swags of black crepe obscuring the windows, and the lack of lanterns within the carriage, the entire inside is shrouded in gloom.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.6: After a few seconds, your eyes adjust to the shadows and you see the woman in front of you. She’s older than yourself, but still younger than you’d expect. Dressed in luxurious mourning clothes, she reclines easily in her seat, clutching a fine glass filled with water.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.5: You hear some rustling from inside the carriage, and she opens the door for you. You help yourself into the carriage.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.4: “How tragic,” replies the voice with a trace of amusement. “What kind of person would I be, if I didn’t take pity on such a helpless soul?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.3: “Certainly, I should be able to help with that.” The voice replies.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.2: “What seems to be troubling you, madame?” calls out a voice from inside the carriage.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.1: Should you knock on the door? Call out? You’ve heard that courtiers in Versailles grow out one of their fingernails, so they can scratch on the door, as it’s considered less disruptive. Locked in this cycle of indecision, you curse the fact that you cut your nails this morning.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.node.0: The coachman pays you no heed as you approach the sumptuously decorated carriage. Normally, you find yourself to be quite fearless in social situations, but something about this whole scenario gives you pause.
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.142: "I don't think I'm comfortable with seeing you that way, Honorade."
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.102: “A very… intriguing woman. One that I’m hoping to see more of.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.101: “A wealthy widow with a fondness for helping strangers. She's kind, in her own way."
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.97: “I’m sorry, I don’t feel comfortable with that.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.86: “A very… intriguing woman. One that I’m hoping to see more of.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.85: “A wealthy widow with a fondness for helping strangers, she seems nice.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.72: “There’s something romantic about casting aside decency, for the sake of grief.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.71: “Mourning has a set length for a reason. Life is for the living.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.70: “One should take as long as they like, but they can’t do it forever.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.59: “I’d always dreamed of being in Paris, it’s a city at the center of the world.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.58: “I was sick of my life in the country, I wanted to get away.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.57: “I came here because I’ll do anything for love.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.42: “I’d always dreamed of being in Paris, it’s a city at the center of the world.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.41: “I was sick of my life in the country, I wanted to get away.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.40: “I came here because I’ll do anything for love.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.34: “There’s something romantic about casting aside decency, for the sake of grief.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.33: “Mourning has a set length for a reason. Life is for the living.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.32: “One should take as long as they like, but they can’t do it forever.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.26: “How long have you been in mourning?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.17: “Please, don’t worry about it, I’ll be fine.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.16: “Apparently, they’re enemies with my lost fiance, and wanted to snub him by berating me.”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.1: “Madame, my fiance is lost, our host denounced me, and my carriage is gone. Can you help?”
18236.The Wealthy Widow.link.0: “May I bother you for a ride home? My carriage left without me.”
14862.The Second Sitting.node.34: Like last time, Elisabeth fetches some pastries and tea. You get the feeling that she does this with all of her clients, but it's nice to have all the same. You chat and joke for a while, which is a lot easier to do, now that you don't have to hold perfectly still.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.33:
"So, instead, I just sit around and wait for work to come to me, even though I know it's unwise. Artists have to keep reaching out for clients, or we'll never get anything."

She sighs. "Yet, I'm so out of practice. What if I make a fool of myself?"
14862.The Second Sitting.node.32:
"I don't think I'll ever get tired of that." Elisabeth sighs.

(You have gained a some favor with Elisabeth)
14862.The Second Sitting.node.31: You follow her inside and Elisabeth closes the door behind you. The studio is exactly how you remember it, though your portrait's canvas has been covered with a cloth.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.30:
"I'm sorry, I just didn't hear you come in."

She flashes you a smile. "Still, I'm glad you took my request seriously."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
14862.The Second Sitting.node.29: "No matter, if anyone asks, I'll just say it was a courier with a message." She says with a sigh. "Come in, come in."
14862.The Second Sitting.node.28:
"Oh, I thought you'd never ask." Elisabeth replies with a sly smile. She helps you out of your dress, and slowly unlaces your stays, hands lingering on you all the while. 

You're pretty sure it took longer to undress with her help than it would have taken to do by yourself, but that wasn't the point really, was it?

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
14862.The Second Sitting.node.27:
You turn your back on the painter and start to disrobe, one article at a time. It's slow, but confident. After all, if you had anything to hide, you wouldn't be here, doing this. 

Languidly, you sit on the couch and remove your stockings, before posing yourself.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.26: With things winding down, you decide it's time to head home. With a wave goodbye to Elisabeth, you take your leave.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.25: Afterwards, Elisabeth provides you with pastries and tea again. You get the feeling that she does this with all of her clients, but it's nice to have all the same. You chat and joke for a while, which is a lot easier to do, now that you don't have to hold perfectly still.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.24:
While the painting is obviously unfinished, it's coming together quite nicely. The colors of the scene are balanced and you can see that Elisabeth has already started on the details of your body. It's not what you see in the mirror, but it's a familiar beauty. A lot of time has been spent on your eyes, capturing something that feels passionate, yet calculating and enigmatic.

It's fascinating to see how you appear through the eyes of another.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.23:
While the painting is obviously unfinished, it's coming together quite nicely. The colors of the scene are balanced and you can see that Elisabeth has already started on some of the details that make you yourself. A wrinkle here, a childhood scar there. The minor flaws of your body, quite literally laid bare.

Yet still, there's an honest beauty to it, if you do say so yourself.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.22:
While the painting is obviously unfinished, it's coming together quite nicely. The colors of the scene are balanced and you can see that Elisabeth has already started on some of your details, but everything is smoother. Cleaner. The kind of unreal beauty that you've seen in so many portraits of great men and women.

It's not you as you are. It's you as you aspire to be.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.20: "Here it is!" the painter says as she waves you over to her easel. The wooden floor creaks under your bare feet as you walk over.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.19: "Do you want to see what I've done so far?"
14862.The Second Sitting.node.18: "Alright, my hands are starting to cramp up, so I think we're done for the day."
14862.The Second Sitting.node.17: The conversation trails off and you spend the next hour simply posing and watching Elisabeth paint. She seems more relaxed, as if a weight has been lifted from her mind.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.16:
"Thanks Yvette! I'll send out letters to some of the business leaders in Paris tomorrow."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
(The Bourgeoisie's allegiance to the Crown has been improved)
14862.The Second Sitting.node.15:
"Thanks Yvette! I'll send out letters to some of the military officers in Paris tomorrow."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
(The Military's allegiance to the Crown has been improved)
14862.The Second Sitting.node.14:
"Thanks Yvette! I'll send out letters to the bishops in Paris tomorrow."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
(The Church's allegiance to the Crown has been improved)
14862.The Second Sitting.node.13: "That definitely makes sense." She admits, already considering the idea. "What I need right now is clients, and I'd rather have ones that can pay well than ones that can't."
14862.The Second Sitting.node.12: "You really think so?" She asks, already considering the idea. "I guess that makes sense. It's a lot easier to pitch yourself when you have something different to offer."
14862.The Second Sitting.node.11: "You really think so?" She asks, already considering the idea. "I guess they would, and none of my commisioned work is truly immodest, so maybe they really might like my paintings."
14862.The Second Sitting.node.10: "At this point, I don't even know who would appreciate my work."
14862.The Second Sitting.node.9: An hour into the sitting, she laughs. "I like how easy it is to talk to you. Much easier than trying to reach out to new patrons. Half of the critics in the city already paint me as a conniving narcisist, and I'd hate to prove any of them right."
14862.The Second Sitting.node.8:
This time, she starts with her paints, filling in the colors that define the scene. While you can't see what she's doing, she tells you about the process.

Getting the balance of colors is important to making a scene feel authentic, even to an untrained eye. Subtle details like the color of the light reflected off a wall can make all the difference in the world.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.7: Elisabeth heads to her canvas and throws off the covers, while you strip down and position yourself on the couch, the same as you were before.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.6: "Alright, I already have everything I need set up. Let's begin, shall we?"
14862.The Second Sitting.node.5: Entering the room, a startled Elisabeth practically jumps when she sees you. "Mon dieu!"
14862.The Second Sitting.node.4:
The door opens a fraction and you can see Elisabeth through the gap.

"What did I say last time, about staying quiet?" She whispers to you through her teeth. "We need to be discreet."

(You have lost a little favor with Elisabeth)
14862.The Second Sitting.node.3: Remembering Elisabeth's need for discretion, you simply walk inside. The studio is exactly how you remember it, though your portrait's canvas has been covered with a cloth.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.2: You knock lightly on the door, and wait. Listening closely, you hear some frantic movement inside.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.1: Having been to her studio before, you arrive without any trouble.
14862.The Second Sitting.node.0: It's another warm, sunny day as you walk to Elisabeth's studio. A fresh breeze off the river Seine prevents the heat from becoming overwhelming.
14862.The Second Sitting.link.41: "Of course, just stand back and watch."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.40: "Of course, just stand back and watch."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.39: "Of course, just stand back and watch."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.38: "Of course, just stand back and watch."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.37: "Of course, just stand back and watch."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.36: "Of course, just stand back and watch."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.35: "Of course, just stand back and watch."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.33: "I'd appreciate some help getting ready, if you have the time."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.19: "Actually, I'd rather be surprised by the final product."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.9: "You're an artist trying to make a living. The Bourgeoisie have the money, go to them."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.8: "Try the Military, most of their commisioned artists are men, so you'll be sure to stand out."
14862.The Second Sitting.link.7: "Have you considered the Church? They'd value your more natural style."
19446.The Royal Painter.node.23:
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Le Brun)
19446.The Royal Painter.node.22:
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Le Brun)
(You have gained a little peril)
19446.The Royal Painter.node.21: (You have gained a little favor with Madame Le Brun)
19446.The Royal Painter.node.19: After a few minutes, with an exchange of polite nods, you part ways with your erstwhile friends in order to explore the rest of the party.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.18: You spend a few minutes with these guests, slyly passing judgement on various prominent members of high society.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.17: For a moment you feel close to these strangers, as you all laugh together at the expense of someone who isnt here. It is a joy as old as time.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.16: “The real question is, if she falls out of favor, would she even notice?” Her friend asks with an arched eyebrow.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.15: The two of them hurry away to another part of the party. While that certainly didn’t make you any friends, you know that Madame Le Brun is a far more important person to be on the good side of, than two random hangers-on at a party.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.14: “We should go.” The woman interrupts, taking her friend gently by the elbow and leading him away.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.13: Finally, the man manages to say, “Ah, I see that Madame Le Brun has quite the fan. I must concede that there are few portrait painters who have so superbly captured the image of the Queen, God preserve her. I suppose that-”
19446.The Royal Painter.node.12: After a period of awkward silence, the guests depart to explore the rest of the party. As they leave, you watch them whisper to each other and glance back at you, pointedly.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.11: "She's alright because she makes pretty pictures? What an insightful defense!” the woman replies with such fluid sarcasm that you almost mistake it for a genuine compliment.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.10: With an exchange of polite nods, you part ways with these guests in order to explore the rest of the party.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.9:
Slowly they nod, and their faces break into polite smiles. “My, my, I didn’t realize we had such a fan in our midst. I suppose one can forgive an artist for being so eccentric, as long as their work remains beautiful.”

That qualifier at the end of her statement feels unnecessary, but it’s an improvement.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.8: The once snide guests stand quiet for a while, considering your point.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.7: “Haha, yes, I think we’ll all see that soon enough.” The woman titters, trying to laugh behind her hand.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.6: Your surprising forwardness leaves the room quiet for a few moments. The man and the woman both glance back and forth between each other for a while, trying to figure out what to say.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.5: Surprised, the man turns to you with a cocked eyebrow. "Oh? You really think making beautiful work can justify her transgressions?"
19446.The Royal Painter.node.4: The woman turns and asks you furtively “Ah! What do you think of Madame Le Brun and her… eccentricities?”
19446.The Royal Painter.node.3: “You assume that Madame Le Brun knew much about social niceties to begin with,” the man quips, and the two of them share a sly chuckle at the absent artist’s expense. “You’d think that someone who worked on commision would care a little more about what others thought of her.”
19446.The Royal Painter.node.2: “I have no idea.” the woman replies, glancing furtively around the room. “Ever since Madame Le Brun started painting portraits of the Queen herself, she seems to feel that’s she’s above normal social niceties. It must have cost a fortune just to make an opening in Madame Le Brun’s schedule.”
19446.The Royal Painter.node.1: “Do you have any idea how Marcelle managed to get this?” A man asks, his face the picture of shock, not taking his eyes off the painting for a moment. He must know the Viscountess de Foix very well in order to use her first name so freely.
19446.The Royal Painter.node.0:
In one corner of the party, you find two guests clustered around a painting hanging on the wall. They’re talking in low voices to themselves.

You pause to examine the painting yourself. It’s a beautiful piece that show the hostess standing in a field, posing with her dog. The eyes and lips, in particular, look marvelously lifelike.
19446.The Royal Painter.link.6: “Nobody is above the consequences of society, not even great painters. Le Brun will have hers yet.”
19446.The Royal Painter.link.5: “I think Madame Le Brun can be as rude as she pleases. Her skills speak for themselves.”
19446.The Royal Painter.link.4: “Personally, I've always admired her willingness to strain against convention.”
18056.The Royal Household.node.21: (A new piece of gossip has been added to your inventory. You'll be able to use this later.)
18056.The Royal Household.node.18: (A new piece of gossip has been added to your inventory. You'll be able to use this later.)
18056.The Royal Household.node.17: They disappear off into a different corner of the party, judging you all the way.
18056.The Royal Household.node.16: “I think this conversation would best be continued somewhere more discreet.” The other woman intimates to her companion.
18056.The Royal Household.node.15: “Oh, I’m sorry, did we interrupt something?” One of them asks, arching a single eyebrow imposingly.
18056.The Royal Household.node.14: You listen to them go back and forth for a little while, and you hungrily soak up all the details to this story that you can. Eventually, you realize that you’ve been admiring this vase for a suspicious amount of time.
18056.The Royal Household.node.13:
“I’m not so sure, a handmaiden told me that the Queen privately vowed not to leave her son’s side until he slept through the night, but she’s been with him for over a week. He keeps waking up in fits of coughing.”

Vows. Specific details. Lives in the balance. Now that’s what makes good gossip!
18056.The Royal Household.node.12: Guiding her friend gently by the elbow, they disappear off into a different corner of the party, judging you all the way.
18056.The Royal Household.node.11: The other woman suddenly steps in between the two of you and cuts off her companion. “I’m sorry, but this is a private matter. I’m glad your brother is doing well, please give him our regards.” Her smile is cold, and her posture stiff.
18056.The Royal Household.node.10: Eventually, you part ways with each other, so you can explore the rest of the party.
18056.The Royal Household.node.9: You continue to chat with them as they dance around the issue of who, exactly, you’re talking about. You helpfully offer up some home remedies for coughing fits that you’ve heard in the past, and they act as grateful as ettiquette requires.
18056.The Royal Household.node.8: “Well, our… friend’s son has been sick for quite some time now, and-” one woman starts cautiously.
18056.The Royal Household.node.7:
“Well, our… friend’s son has been sick for quite some time now, and she’s been taking it quite hard. I recently heard that she privately vowed not to leave her son’s side until he slept through the night, but she’s been with him for over a week. He keeps waking up in fits of coughing.”

You nod with the appropriate look of concern, while hungrily memorizing details. The Queen swearing vows. Lives hanging in the balance. This is what makes quality gossip!
18056.The Royal Household.node.6: You decide against engaging them in conversation, or listening in. While it’s nice to have some reliable gossip, you don’t need it that badly right now. Instead, you spend some time wandering about the party, sipping at your wine, taking in the sights and the sounds.
18056.The Royal Household.node.5:
You sip your wine and pretend to be admiring a nearby vase, while keeping your ears perked up and focused on the womens’ conversation.

They don’t seem to suspect a thing.
18056.The Royal Household.node.4: Your brother never actually came down with the illness, but he’s not here to contest that fact. You smile and pretend to be oblivious as to who they’re discussing, so as to mask your intent.
18056.The Royal Household.node.3: “He’s overcome the condition before, perhaps he’ll do it again?”
18056.The Royal Household.node.2: Your ears perk up at this. The Queen’s eldest son is only seven years old, but he’s been afflicted with consumption for years now. Rumors don’t have much value, but if there’s some evidence to this claim, then this could be valuable Gossip indeed.
18056.The Royal Household.node.1: “It’s been days since the Queen has made any official appearances at Versailles.” One the women fiercely whispers to the other. “It is said that the Dauphin’s health is worsening, and she spends every minute by his side.”
18056.The Royal Household.node.0: You approach a pair of women who are already in the midst of conversation, speaking quickly in low voices. They don’t seem to have noticed you.
18056.The Royal Household.link.3: “I’m sorry to barge in, but I heard you mention that somebody has consumption, my brother suffered from it as well.”
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.43: Once you're certain he's not going to be ambushed, you head back to your own home, with Hansel in tow. It's a rough world out there, but that's exactly why you hired a bodyguard.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.42: You and Hansel escort Pierre back to his office, mostly to make sure the journalist's new enemy doesn't try to finish the job he started.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.40: He shuffles through his pockets, and hands you a handful of coins as a 'bonus' for your help.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.39: "The dangers we risk for exposing the truth, non?" Pierre asks with a massive smile. "I'm sure he would have torn me to ribbons, had you not intervened."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.38: With a string of curses, the enraged man storms off, unsatisfied. Dusting off his worn coat, Pierre rejoins the conversation.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.36: Pierre laughs. "Don't worry monsieur! It's a surprise to me as well!"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.35: The man leans around Hansel to yell at you indignantly. "Are you serious? You're really going to defend this Pierre, of all people?"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.34: "Hurf... that could have gone better, non?" Pierre asks through a forced smile. "I'm sure I would be in far worse condition, had you not intervened."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.32: The assailant glares at you before he departs. "If you're associated with this wretch, I would advise that you watch yourself."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.31: Suddenly, he turns on his heel and swiftly punches Pierre in the gut. The journalist doubles over in pain.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.30: The fire of his ire dying, the enraged man starts to walk away. "He's all yours."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.28: Absolutely beside himself, the man growls. "I have half the right mind to thrash the both of you, but I will be merciful for now. "
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.27: Pierre's smile quickly melts away, as does your ruse.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.26: The assailant walks away, disappearing into the crowd.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.24: "... now that I've acquired my own satisfaction" He gestures generously to Pierre, who is bent double in the road. "He's all yours, madame."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.23: Suddenly, he turns on his heel and swiftly punches Pierre in the gut. The journalist doubles over in pain.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.22: "Non, non..." The man replies, shaking his head in disbelief. "This scum looks far too happy to see you. You're one of his compatriots aren't you?"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.21: "Well, I am a gentleman, and I will let you have your satisfaction." He says, starting to walk away.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.20: Once you're certain that he's not going to die of his injuries, you head back to your own place. It's a rough world out there.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.19: You help Pierre back to his office, which is also where he lives...
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.17: He shuffles through his pockets and hands you a few coins as a 'bonus' for your help.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.15: The assailant glares at you before he departs. "If you're associated with this wretch, I would advise that you watch yourself."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.13: "Hurf... the indignities we suffer for exposing the truth, non?" Pierre asks through a forced smile. "I'm sure I would be in far worse condition, had you not intervened."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.12: Suddenly, he turns on his heel and swiftly punches Pierre in the gut. The journalist doubles over in pain.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.11: Take aback by this situation, and the fire of his ire dying, the enraged man starts to walk away. "He's all yours."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.10: Pierre shrugs and grins. "If it's any consolation, this is all a surprise to me as well."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.9: He sneers at you. "Honestly, I just can't believe there's anyone left in Paris who would willingly defend this man."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.8: Roughly pushing Pierre aside, Hansel steps close and looms over the enraged stranger. "Anything you do to that man, I will do to you, only a lot harder."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.7: The man looks at you, aghast. "Madame, are you absolutely serious?"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.6: "What?" The man says, noticing you for the first time. "This scoundrel has wronged you as well?"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.5: Now, this is a problem. If Pierre gets thrashed to death, there'll be nobody left to buy your gossip!
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.4: The man grabs Pierre by the shirt collar and drags the diminutive journalist closer. "How about I knock some sense into you? Will you remember then?"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.3: Pierre laughs nervously. "Monsieur, I'm afraid you're going to have to be a little more specific as to your identity..."
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.2: "How dare you? You salacious cur! You've aired my private matters for all the world to see and I've been nearly ruined!"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.1: As you grow less distant, you realize exactly what's familiar. It's a certain overpowering cologne. There's only one man in Paris who's snorted so much snuff as to think such a vile concoction was a good idea. In fact, someone is screaming at him, right now!
15554.The Perils of Journalism.node.0: Travelling about town you find yourself, once more, in a fountain square. You're not sure if you've been to this particular one before, but something feels distantly familiar.
15554.The Perils of Journalism.link.7: "Hansel, I need Pierre in one piece. Handle this." <Requires Hansel>
15554.The Perils of Journalism.link.6: "Step away from Pierre, or there will be hell to pay!"
15554.The Perils of Journalism.link.5: "Monsieur, you can't kill him! Not before I get my chance to hurt him..."
18938.The Orphan’s Feast.node.4: When she puts it that way, it suddenly sounds so easy…
18938.The Orphan’s Feast.node.3: The woman pauses to think. “I haven’t heard that name before, but I just started working today. Perhaps he’s in the back?”
18938.The Orphan’s Feast.node.2: “Don’t worry, while the rest of the city can be er… cutthroat, the Orphan’s Feast is a relaxed place for getting your feet under you.” The woman puts down the lantern she was polishing. “Talk to the guests in the different rooms, make sure you say the right things to the right people, and make sure nobody gets bored. Once you charm all the people in a room, you should be fine.”
18938.The Orphan’s Feast.node.1: “How may I be of service?” She asks.
18938.The Orphan’s Feast.node.0: A woman polishing a lantern looks up at you as you enter, and her face breaks into a bright smile. “Bonjour Madame and welcome to the Orphan's Feast!” Her eyes linger expectantly on the door for a moment, before settling on you. You’re suddenly reminded of how rare it is for women to travel by themselves.
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.1:
Nothing is going to make last night go away. 

The only option is deciding what to do next.
“They’d have to get their stories from somewhere, why not you? In fact, I bet you’d be great at that, Madame!”

Camille taps her chin thoughtfully. “Well… when I was at les Halles the other day, someone mentioned something about a newspaper with these amazing society pages. I think it was called ‘La Trompette du Peuple’. ” (La Trompette du Peuple is now available to visit in the Paris map)
Maybe someone would be willing to buy this gossip. Is that a thing people do?

You take a few moments to finish your drink in silence and collect your thoughts. Something that keeps coming to mind is all the gossip you’ve heard during your time at the party. Most of it was idle prattle, but some of it felt scandalous and valuable. Without an inheritance or a job, you’ll need a way to make some money.

You drink the wine slowly, taking in the aroma between sips. Armand was always the sort to keep a few, particularly nice bottles on hand to impress important guests. The wine smooths the edges off of last night’s memories, and you feel a little more ready to face the new world that you’ve entered. 

*Wine Buff*
A few minutes later, Camille returns with a decanter of red wine and the least chipped wine glass in the house. “Por vous, Madame.” She pronounces, before serving you.

Camille returns so quickly with the tea that you’re certain she made it ahead of time. It’s piping hot, fragrant, and not too bitter. You drink the brew in silence, the gears of your mind slowly getting up to speed. The tiredness fades. Your anger does not.

*Tea Buff*
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.8: “Still, I can’t let you start your morning without something to drink. It wouldn’t be healthy! What can I get you Madame?”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.7: “Now, if you wanted me to clean up after a murder... That, I could do!”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.6: “While you wait, I must insist on getting you something to drink. Going without wouldn’t be healthy!"
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.5: “Certainly Madame! What can I get you?” Camille asks with a smile.
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.4: “Unfortunately Madame, the only things I’ve killed are rats, fish, chickens, and one porcupine. Those didn’t look very accidental either. I don’t think I’ll be able to help with a murder.”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.3: “I’m sorry Madame, the other cushions are waiting to be washed. We can’t have you end your life with a dirty pillow. It would be improper, for a woman of your station.”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.2: “It looks like you had quite an active night. Is there anything I can get you?”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.1: Camille pops into your room, already dressed and ready for the day. “Bonjour Madame!” she beams.
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.node.0: You awaken the next morning, in a bed that still feels unfamiliar. In the process of waking up, you start to recall the last nights humiliations, and wish that they were merely the product of your fitful dreams. Unable to go back to sleep, you spend some time tossing and turning in bed before finally sitting up.
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.link.2: "I've gone from Baroness-to-be, to gossip monger. Great. Just great."
"Merci, Camille. I think I'll do just that."
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.link.1: “I’ll have some wine. The sooner I can numb last night, the better.”
“I’ll have some wine. The sooner I can numb last night, the better.”
“I’ll have some wine. The sooner I can numb last night, the better.”
“Tea, please. I need to keep my wits about me.”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.link.9: “Tea, please. I need to keep my wits about me.”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.link.8: “Tea, please. I need to keep my wits about me.”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.link.2: “I’m not sure… do you know how to make a murder look like an accident?”
16890.The Morning, After Disaster.link.1: “Please find a spare pillow and smother me.”
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.32: "Well madame, at least we didn't get arrested." She says with a shrug.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.31: With that, he stomps away into the crowd, leaving you and Camille alone.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.28: Musket at the ready, the watchman runs off into the crowd, yelling after an imaginary cutpurse. The moment you lose sight of him, the two of you start hurrying away.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.27: He pinches the bridge of his nose, trying to stifle an impending headache. "Look, I am going to let this drop, but I swear that I'll be keeping an eye on you two."
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.26: Suppressing the powerful reflex to comment on the irony of that statement, you point him in a random direction. To sell the illusion, you provide a believable, yet suitably vague description of your imaginary assailant.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.24: Noticing that the crowd is finally starting to pay attention, the watchman simply glares at you. "Fine, I shall trust you for now. However, I swear that I'll be keeping an eye on you two."
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.23: "I'm not a known criminal! I shop here every week!" Camille yells out, over your shoulder. The watchman's eye twitches in anger.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.22: "I'm not harassing anyone." He spits at you. "I'm merely keeping an eye out for known criminals."
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.21: You spend the rest of the day escorting Camille about on her daily errands. It takes a few minutes for her to completely feel comfortable again, but it comes eventually.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.19: "Wow madame, that was amazing!" She gushes. "Normally, I remember to bribe the authorities, but something came over me and I completely forgot."
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.17: With that, he shuffles off into the crowd, leaving you and Camille alone.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.16: "Ah, I'm so glad to be of help." He says with an enormous grin as he tips his hat to you. "Now, if you fine ladies may excuse me, I need to find more citizens in need of public service."
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.15: He sighs, somehow angrier than ever. "Do you really think you're the first person to try such a ruse on me?"
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.14: "Which way did he go? We don't allow criminals here! Not on my watch!"
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.13: The watchman stares at you, absolutely startled, as you suddenly interpose yourself between him and Camille. "What? You've been robbed?"
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.12: Raising yourself to your full height, you step between Camille and the Watchman. You feel a slight tug as Camille starts holding onto the back of your skirts.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.11: Stepping between the watchman and Camille, you stealthily slip a few coins into his outstretched hand. He glances down, and immediately, his mood changes for the better.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.10: Ah... so that's what this is about.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.9: "You're going to have to give me a very good reason not to haul you away." He growls, and one of his hands extends out, low, with his palm up.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.8: "Well... I don't... I can't..." Camille starts and stops, looking ashamedly at the ground.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.6: Camille's eyes dart from side to side, and she turns her feet away from him. Something about this line of questioning is making her very uncomfortable. "I... uh... I never get receipts, monsieur."
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.5: "I saw no such thing!" He says, blistering at the suggestion that he could have been paying attention to his surroundings. "Where's your receipt?"
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.4: "Quoi? But monsieur, you saw me buy these. I got them over there." She says, pointing in the direction of a market stall.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.3: "Where'd you get those?" He demands, gesturing to all of her groceries.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.2: You stumble upon Camille, her arms full with a basket full of the day's gorceries. However, she's been stopped by a member of the Watch, one of the infamous 'archers'. He's berating Camille in the middle of the street.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.1: You ears suddenly perk up at the sound of a familiar voice, and you start slipping through the crowd in its direction.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.node.0: You spend the day walking through the city, exploring the neighborhood near a marketplace. The air is pungent, a rush of scents from crisp vegetables, to fresh fruit, to less-than-fresh fish.
19360.The Maid and the Archer.link.12: "Monsieur! Monsieur! A man has stolen my purse!"
19360.The Maid and the Archer.link.11: "Excuse me monsieur. Don't you have better things to do than harass my servant?"
19360.The Maid and the Archer.link.10: "Monsieur! I'm so glad you found her! Please accept this payment for my thanks."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.54: (You have gained some favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.53: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.52: (You have gained some favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.51: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.50: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.49: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.48: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.47: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.46: You turn to your home and see what Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.45:
With a nod, Ludovico steps into his carraige, and disappears into the night.

You turn to your home find that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.44: “Heaven help you, if you do,” he chuckles, “And please madame, call me Ludovico.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.43: “Please, call me Ludovico.” He says with a nod before stepping into his carriage and disappearing into the night.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.42: “Hopefully, we’ll meet again under better circumstances.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.41:
The carriage rolls to a stop, cutting him off mid sentence. You hear the crunch of hobnailed boots on cobblestones as the coachman walks to the door, but Father Sidotti opens it first. He steps down and offers you his hand.

“This has been a rare pleasure madame,” he says as you step into the street.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.40: Your mind brimming with new possibilities, you step inside and head upstairs. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.39: You step inside and head upstairs, your mind still reeling from the day's events. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.37:
“Until we meet again, madame!” He calls cheerily before the carriage drives off into the night. 

You realize that Camille is already waiting for you at the door.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.36:
The carriage stops and the coachman opens the door. As you step down into the street, Father Sidotti leans out of the carriage to look at your home. 

“Ah, I see you have chosen to live humbly. It’s good for the soul.” He muses aloud.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.35: The conversation continues apace for the rest of the carriage ride. Most of your free time growing up was spent reading, and ignoring your parents, so you both seem to have a lot in common. When this evening started, you didn’t expect to find yourself in a carriage, discussing Voltaire and Goethe with a Catholic Priest.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.34: Eventually the conversation dies down, the adrenaline rush of the night’s disasters and indignities giving way to simple exhaustion. Father Sidotti settles into his books, and you occupy yourself with watching the scenery go by, and trying not to fall asleep.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.32: “But what about you? Are you alright?”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.31: A flush of color darkens the young priest’s cheeks. “While I appreciate the offer, please don’t feel obligated to make enemies just for my sake. I might not always be around to save you.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.30: He shrugs. “Well, at least we’re on equal footing.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.29: “Would you believe that it’s the first time I’ve shared my carriage with an enchanting woman?”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.28: “Really?” he coughs awkwardly and looks away. “You are too kind, madame.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.27: “Sorry, I didn’t mean to bore you with my life story. I ramble when I’m nervous.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.26: “You see, sending a bishop or a cardinal here, with all their retinue, would arouse too much suspicion. It’d make people think something bad was going to happen. A single priest? Nobody notices that.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.25: “A few months ago, I was pulled aside and told that I would be sent to Paris. There’s been a lot of… unrest here. My superiors in Rome wanted an outside opinion.” He pauses for a moment to fiddle with his rosary.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.24: He blushes for a moment and stares out the window “Though, that made holding mass a little difficult for me. A lot of awkward silences.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.23: “The seminary wasn’t bad, it was the first time in my life that people were happy that I spent all of my time reading. I was ordained a few years ago and shuffled around to help with various parishes in Rome. All the older priests liked me because I didn’t talk too much.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.22: “I can certainly understand why.” Father Sidotti replies. He gestures, not at you, but at your situation in general. “I hope, at least, that I’ve managed to make things a little more bearable.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.21: “Resilience is good…” he replies trailing off for a moment. “Just make sure to give yourself time to rest. Even the most minor of injuries can wear on the soul, if left uncared for.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.20: “You’re right. I was born and raised in Rome. My family’s about as traditional as it comes, so when my parents had three sons, they knew what to do with us immediately. One man of arms, one man of letters, and one…” he gestures broadly to himself, “man of the cloth.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.18: After a few more giggles, his face turns more serious. “I heard that you were searching for your fiance, and that our host thought it would be good sport to ridicule you in front of their friends. Utterly barbaric.” He follows this up by muttering something decidedly unchristian to himself in Italian.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.17: “I’m guessing then that you must be the one I’ve heard about. I’m sorry that our host felt it acceptable to treat you so poorly.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.16: “While I wasn’t present for it, I heard about what our host put you through. I’m sorry you’ve had to endure such a dreadful humiliation.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.15: You’re not so sure if you actually feel unflustered, but it’s good that you can project it.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.14:
The young priest laughs loudly.

“I must be very fortunate, to have a martyr in my presence. I’m glad to see you made it without any extra holes in you.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.13: He raises his eyebrows. “What a worrying turn of events. A missing fiance, sudden enemies, and now a missing carriage. It sounds like you’ve been beset by quite the number of misfortunes.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.12:
With a slight smile he exhales, looking less tense than before.

“I’m glad to see that you’re taking this setback in good humor. Not everyone would be so unflustered by such a turn of events.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.10: He stares at you for a while and almost starts talking, before thinking better of it. This process repeats a few more times, before he finally speaks.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.9:
The inside of the carriage is very similar to the outside. It’s simple, but lovingly crafted. Father Sidotti sits across from you, his eyes darting between you and the small stack of books on the seat next to him.

He signals the coachman by tapping the ceiling of the carriage, and you head off towards Paris.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.8:
A smile flashes across his lips before he glances away.

“‘Ask, and it shall be given you’. I’m sure we can make a stop.” Father Sidotti steps down from the carriage and offers you his hand. He helps you inside.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.7:
For the first time today, you see someone look at you with genuine concern. “How terrible! Please, come aboard, it’s no trouble at all.”

He puts down his book and waves you inside.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.5: “Buonasera Castigated Woman. I am Father Sidotti. It’s a pleasure to make your acquaintance.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.4: “Hello Madame Decaux! Do not worry, I’m sure there’s something I can do for you.”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.3:
Behind the door you hear a sputter of barely suppressed laughter.

He opens the door.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.2: “Oh my!” the voice behind the door calls out. After some fumbling, he parts the curtains on the carriage windows.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.1: An accented voice calls out to you. “Uh… who is it?”
12976.The Lovesick Priest.node.0: You reach out and knock on the door of the carriage. The silhouetted figure jumps in surprise.
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.44: "Are you sure, Father Sidotti? I can always make more enemies, if you'd like."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.43: "Thank you, Father Sidotti. Until we meet again."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.41: "A most intriguing young priest. Hopefully someone I'll see again."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.40: "Just a nice man, doing the Lord's work."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.35: "Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon as possible."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.34: "I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.33: "Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon soon as possible."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.32: "I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.30: "Maybe I'll have to get thrown out of parties more often."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.29: "Don't worry Father, this is new to me, as well."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.27: "It's fine, I thought it was interesting."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.21: "Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon as possible."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.20: "I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.19: "I get the impression that you're not from Paris. What brings you here?"
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.14: "Imagine St. Sebastian, but with insults instead of arrows."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.13: "I'm looking for my missing fiance, but it turns out this party was held by one of his enemies."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.12: "It appears that Parisians have a very different way of entertaining their party guests."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.7: "My carriage is gone, and there's no way I'm walking home in these heels. I need a ride."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.6: "May I trouble you for a ride home? My coachman was tricked into leaving without me."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.2: "It's me, the woman who just got castigated by the host, then thrown out."
12976.The Lovesick Priest.link.1: "Father, my name is Yvette Decaux, and I am a common woman in need."
15876.The First Sitting.node.39:
You glance back down at the paper, then at the number on the house. You're here. 

The studio feels like a seperate building that's been attached to her house, and while you assume that her husband is at work, you can see the shapes of servants through the home's windows.
15876.The First Sitting.node.38:
Eventually, she breaks into a broad smile. "I think I'd like that very much."

(You've gained some favor with Elisabeth)
15876.The First Sitting.node.36: "I have the framing and positioning set, how would you like me to depict you?"
15876.The First Sitting.node.35:
"Are you sure you've never done this before?"

You give no reply, other than an appropriately enigmatic smile.
15876.The First Sitting.node.34: Keeping that in mind, you stride over to the couch, slowly disrobing as you walk. The line of discarded clothing forms a trail behind you until finally, you drape your corset over the back of the couch, and slowly recline into a comfortable position.
15876.The First Sitting.node.33:
Your skin slides along the cool satin, as you get settled into place. Elisabeth gently arranges your pose, one limb at a time, helping you settle into just the right position.

"Alright, you're doing your part just fine. It's time for me to do mine!"
15876.The First Sitting.node.32: "To be specific, I've spent so much time painting clothed figures, that I feel like I'm losing touch with my fundamentals. This will let me practice my anatomy rendering, and the satin on the couch will let me keep current on my fabric skills."
15876.The First Sitting.node.31: "Get in, get in!" She whispers to you, motioning you inside.
15876.The First Sitting.node.30: After spending an hour chatting and looking at your figure sketched out on the canvas, you decide to head home. Out in the street, your footsteps feel lighter, the world seems brighter, and more in focus.
15876.The First Sitting.node.29:
When you finally break for the day, Elisabeth takes off her canvas apron, makes some tea, and brings out a few small pastries while you get dressed. 

In the midst of devouring said pastries, you realize that you're suprisingly hungry for someone who's spent the day sitting in one place.
15876.The First Sitting.node.28: Still, you can tell that she's keeping your request in mind. She spends the next few minutes correcting a few lines of her charcoal.
15876.The First Sitting.node.27: She looks you, seemingly with fresh eyes, and starts scribbling furiously on her canvas. Judging by the sounds of her muttering, she's enjoying the challenge.
15876.The First Sitting.node.26: She starts drawing again with a fresh energy, scribbling with her charcoal all over the canvas.
15876.The First Sitting.node.25: Elisabeth doesn't reply at first. Instead she stares at you quizzacly, as if she's uncertain that you're serious.
15876.The First Sitting.node.24: "Oh, I wouldn't recommend that. Painting Queens only seems to lead to trouble for me."
15876.The First Sitting.node.23: A few hours pass, punctuated only by the occasional break to get up and stretch. Elisabeth won't let you look at the canvas on your breaks, so instead you content yourself with staring out the window, at the way the sunlight plays with the leaves on the vines.
15876.The First Sitting.node.22: Eventually, like the water, it just feels calm and refreshing.
15876.The First Sitting.node.21: A few minutes pass and you realize how comfortable you are, despite your vulnerable position. Being naked no longer feels different. Like plunging into cold water, the initial shock is really the most noticable part
15876.The First Sitting.node.20:
She walks to her easel and using a piece of charcoal, starts to sketch out your position on the canvas. You can't see what she's doing, but you can hear her mumble to herself while she works.

From the sounds of it, the sketching is going well.
15876.The First Sitting.node.19: She reaches out and gently takes you by the hand. "There's no need to be shy. I've painted hundreds of people before."
15876.The First Sitting.node.18:
Taken aback by your comment, her face flushes a rose red.

"Well, perhaps I had some ulterior motives..."
15876.The First Sitting.node.17: "That's why you should be naked, laying on my beautiful couch."
15876.The First Sitting.node.16:
"If you're feeling nervous, then just think about the fact that you're one of the most beautiful people to ever grace this furniture." She says with a sly grin.

You take a seat, feeling more at ease, despite the unfamiliar situation.
15876.The First Sitting.node.15: After spending more than a few moments admiring you, Elisabeth gives you some specifics on how to pose. A wrist here, an ankle there, laying your head back in order to better catch the light on your face.
15876.The First Sitting.node.14: "That was... something else." Elisabeth manages to stammer to you.
15876.The First Sitting.node.13:
Finally, you undo your stays and with a sigh, let your linen chemise fall to the floor. You take a deep breath, your lungs freed from the restrictions of corsetry.

"Do you feel better?" Elisabeth asks, leading you over to the couch.
15876.The First Sitting.node.12:
Shutting the door behind you, she says "I'm sorry for that, I'm just worried my husband's servants heard you."

Taking a moment to compose herself, she smiles. "I'm really glad you've decided to do this."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
15876.The First Sitting.node.11: "Well, it's a nude portrait of you reclining on that couch, though I think you figured that part out already." Elisabeth says with a giggle as she sets up her canvas and paints.
15876.The First Sitting.node.10: If you're going to do something, you might as well do it right.
15876.The First Sitting.node.9:
Nervously, you begin to fumble with the ties and toggles of your dress.

As you strip down to your foundation garments, you utter a silent prayer of thanks to the fact that it's a warm day, so at least you won't be shivering on the couch.
15876.The First Sitting.node.8: She leads you to a couch, upholstered in satin. "I'll need you to undress and pose for me here."
15876.The First Sitting.node.7:
The door suddenly opens just wide enough for you to see Elisabeth's startled face.

"Yvette, is that you?"
15876.The First Sitting.node.6: Not wanting to make too much noise, you open the door and step inside the studio. The place is clean, though it's still spattered with dried paint. Shrubs and ivies growing over the windows provide some privacy, but still let the sunlight filter in.
15876.The First Sitting.node.5: You rap your nuckles against the door, elegantly but firmly.
15876.The First Sitting.node.3:
Every time you pass a stranger on the street, you expect them to know, somehow. To know that you're on your way to a beautiful, fascinating woman's studio so that she can paint a nude portrait of you for her private collection.

You feel nervous. You feel anticipation.
15876.The First Sitting.node.2: Elisabeth walks in, wearing a paint spattered apron, and carying a freshly stretched canvas, while you're still in the middle of your inspection. "Salut Yvette! Please come in, and close the door quietly, I don't want my husband's servant to hear us." (You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
15876.The First Sitting.node.1:
"That's very brave of you." Elisabeth says with a smile. "I normally spend so much time trying to flatter my clients that the truth might be an interesting challenge." 

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
15876.The First Sitting.node.0: A warm breeze caresses your skin as you check the address that Elisabeth gave you a few nights ago, confirming that you're heading to the right place.
15876.The First Sitting.link.39: "Paint me as you see me. That way, it can be about both of us."
15876.The First Sitting.link.38: "Depict me as I really am. There is beauty in honesty."
15876.The First Sitting.link.12: "Are you sure that's why you chose to do this?"
15876.The First Sitting.link.8: "Wait, what kind of painting is this going to be?"
15876.The First Sitting.link.6: "Alright, I suppose I can do that..."

16992.The Good Soldier.node.163: You wrap your knuckles gently against the carriage door.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.162:
Before you can reply, he has already bounded onto his carriage and sailed off into the night.

You turn to your home and see that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.161: “The next time that we meet, please call me Thomas-Alexandre,” He pauses to stare into your eyes, “Or simply Alexandre, if you like.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.160:
“The next time that we meet, please call me Thomas-Alexandre,” He pauses to stare into your eyes, “Or simply Alexandre, if you like.”

(You've gained some favor with Alexandre)
16992.The Good Soldier.node.159: “And while we accept no payment, I must ask of you a favor, madame.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.158: He helps you down effortlessly and favors you with a theatrical bow. “After braving all manners of danger, we have arrived at your home, safe and sound. The Queen’s Dragoons are proud to add another great victory to their name.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.157: You’re surprised by the carriage coming to a stop. You were so lost in dialogue that you hadn’t even realized that you managed to make it home. Before the coachman can even hop off of his box, Corporal Dumas opens the door and steps down. He offers you his hand.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.156: Your mind brimming with new possibilities, you step inside and head upstairs. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.155: You step inside and head upstairs, your mind still reeling from the day's events. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.153:
“Until we meet again, madame!” He calls from carriage with a quick bow, as they drive off into the night. 

You turn to your home and see that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.152:
The coachman opens the door and waves you out. As you’re stepping down, Corporal Dumas looks out the door at your home and whistles to himself. 

“You’ve chosen quite the place to live. Well, if nothing else, the rent will be cheap.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.151: Your conversation with Corporal Dumas continues for the entire ride. He’s polite, forward, and seems to have a healthy respect for you. However, you find that he dodges your questions whenever the subject of his family comes up. You try to not let it bother you. Everyone has their secrets, after all.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.150: Your conversation dies down as fatigue overtakes you both. Soon, there is only the sound of the carriage’s wheels and the horse’s hooves as you wind your way through Paris to your home. You’ve almost drifted off to sleep before you’re jolted awake by the carriage coming to a stop.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.149: He smiles. “Oh really? Perhaps I should be taking lessons in safety from you.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.148: “Perhaps I do. All the same, I hope you stay safe.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.147: “Je vous en prie” He replies with a nod. “Thank you for taking my warnings seriously.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.146: “I’m not trying to frighten you, I just want you to exercise due caution.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.145: He sighs and shakes his head “Je suis désolé, I’m being an awful conversationalist. Please forgive me. What I mean to say is that Paris is beautiful, but life here can be just as harsh and dangerous as anywhere else, if not more.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.144: “Yet, in a city holding a world’s worth of riches, people here still starve.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.143: His expression becomes grave, “However, a word of caution. There’s more to this city than luxury, love, and knowledge. We’re at the center of an empire, goods and treasure from colonies all over the world, flowing in to benefit one point.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.142: He stares out the window at the city. “Sometimes I feel like that’s why I fell in love with this place. It does not love unconditionally, it can be infuriatingly fickle. Still, here you can climb to heights greater than any other place in the world.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.141: “If it helps at all, please remember that first impressions, while important, rarely tell the whole story.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.140: “I’m glad you’re enjoying yourself. I think I’d have a hard time believing someone who felt no joy from being in Paris.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.139: “Finally, someone who gets it!” Corporal Dumas slaps his thigh and laughs with excitement. “Amazing! I’ll have you know that it took me over a year in Paris to fully fully grasp that fact.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.138: “I’m sorry to hear that,” Corporal Dumas replies “I happen to love this city very much, but I understand why the events of the last few days would leave such a bitter taste in your mouth.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.134: “When you find him, are you planning on winning him back, or simply getting revenge?”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.133: “How tragic” Corporal Dumas replies dryly. “He certainly wouldn’t be the first man to abandon a good woman.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.132: “You’re a woman on a mission, then?” Corporal Dumas grins, offering a mock salute. “When you find him, I’m sure he’ll appreciate your loyalty. At least, I can’t imagine a man who wouldn’t.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.131: “Let me turn the question around. What was a commoner like you doing at that party?”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.130: “Despite my considerable talents, I think they’re really just inviting my father’s memory, not me. Still, I attend because I’d hate to insult the host by turning them down. A comrade of mine was nice enough to arrange for me to have this carriage for the evening.” He waves around to your conveyance, which is probably only meant for officers.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.129: “You’re not being rude, it’s a fair question,” he replies, flicking his rank insignia for emphasis. “Every now and again, someone remembers my father and sends me an invitation as a courtesy between nobles.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.126: He sighs, and looks out the window at the passing scenery. “You made the right move. There’s a certain kind of person that sees sport in hurting the vulnerable, whether that vulnerability comes from circumstance, ability, or birth. They’re all the same craven creatures, that feed on feeling powerful. You can never let them see their barbs land.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.125: “Disgusting,” Corporal Dumas replies, his lips curling into a sneer. “I have no idea what our host was thinking, doing something so mindless and cruel. They should be ashamed.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.124: Corporal Dumas nods approvingly “I saw your ‘performance’ outside, right as you left. You don’t seem very shaken.”

16992.The Good Soldier.node.90: He chuckles. “Well, you’re here in my carriage, so I have no choice but to believe it. Unless this is some new sport, where beautiful women see how many rides they can get from gullible do-gooders like myself.”
