16992.The Good Soldier.node.5: He glances off to the side and shuffles his feet slightly. “That does sound terrible. How can I refuse?”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.4: He nods appreciatively, breaking into a warm smile. “Ah, straight to the point Madame Decaux. Certainly, we can drop you off.” He looks towards the coachman, who gives an affable shrug.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.2: He bows to you, formal and precise. “Corporal Dumas of the Queen’s Dragoons.”
16992.The Good Soldier.node.1: The door opens immediately, and the man inside steps out.
16992.The Good Soldier.node.0: At the sound of your approaching footsteps, the coachman’s hand flickers towards his weapon. Turning towards you, he looks you up and down before he relaxes. With an apologetic nod, he gestures you towards the door of the carriage.
16992.The Good Soldier.link.164: "A most intriguing man of honor, and hopefully someone I'll see more of."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.163: "A good soldier doing his duty, nothing more."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.160: "How do you know that I'm not the danger?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.159: "You worry too much, I'll be fine."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.153: "Exhilirating. It's a whole city of luxury, love, and knowledge."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.152: "It's trying. Harsh consequences, but I see the possibility of great rewards."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.151: "Disappointing. This place has been nothing but cruel to me."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.147: "It's not 'winning him back', because I don't think he ever stopped loving me."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.145: "Revenge? I prefer to think of it as justice."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.143: "I've been abandoned by the love of my life, and now I have to find him."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.142: "My fiance's missing, and he was supposed to be there. I'm just looking for leads."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.139: "I don't mean to be rude, but what was an enlisted man like yourself doing at that party?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.135: "Our host felt it was acceptable to victimize me for something my fiance did."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.134: "My fiance has some enemies, they tried to make sport of me. Emphasis on tried."

16992.The Good Soldier.link.41: "I don't mean to be rude, but what was an enlisted man like yourself doing at that party?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.37: "Our horrid host convinced my idiot coachman to abandon me."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.36: "Would you believe that someone tricked my coachman into leaving without me?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.34: "Our host felt it was acceptable to victimize me for something my fiance did."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.33: "My fiance has some enemies, they tried to make sport of me. Emphasis on tried."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.26: "Revenge? I prefer to think of it as justice."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.25: "It's not 'winning him back', because I don't think he ever stopped loving me."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.23: "What made you decide to give a stranger like me a ride?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.22: "Did you have a good time tonight?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.21: "Our horrid host convinced my idiot coachman to abandon me."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.20: "Would you believe something tricked my coachman into leaving without me?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.18: "Our host felt it was acceptable to victimize me for something my fiance did."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.17: "My fiance has some enemies, they tried to make sport of me. Emphasis on tried."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.14: "I've been abandoned by the love of my life, and now I have to find him."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.13: "My fiance's missing, he was supposed to be there, I'm just looking for leads."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.10: "What made you decide to give a stranger like me a ride?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.9: "Did you have a good time tonight?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.8: "I don't mean to be rude, but what was an enlisted man like yourself doing at that party?"
16992.The Good Soldier.link.3: "Please, call me Yvette. I have been beset by grave misfortune and need your help."
16992.The Good Soldier.link.2: "My name is Yvette Decaux, may I trouble you for a ride to my home?"
19140.The Final Sitting.node.51: Elisabeth takes a deep breat, and her next words are almost a sigh of relief. "I'm really proud of this one. I can't wait to get it framed and hung up in my collection."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.50: Everywhere you look in the painting, you are struck by an uncanny perfection that reminds you that what you are seeing isn't real. Yet.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.49: Burdened with internal turmoil, you ascend to your bedroom with a heavy tread. Wearily, you prepare yourself for bed.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.48: With a grin of triumph, and a mind aflame with possibility, you practically dance up the stairs to your bedroom. You can't help but spend a few minutes practicing regal faces in your vanity's mirror before you turn down for the night.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.47: "I can't wait to get this framed and hung up in my collection."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.46:
When Elisabeth returns with the tea and pastries, you waste no time in digging in. 

They taste amazing, but of course, hunger has always been the sweetest spice.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.45: (You have earned a lot of favor with Elisabeth, but you probably already knew that, didn't you?)
19140.The Final Sitting.node.44: Putting down her paints and removing her apron, she walks over to you. "You must be very cold."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.43: "I hope you like it." Elisabeth says sheepishly. "I wanted to make sure that it still feels like you."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.42: "It was really brave of you to ask me to paint you honestly, and I'm proud of the results." Elisabeth smiles, regarding the painting with her hands on her hips.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.41: It's obvious that a tremendous amount of work has gone into this painting. If you squint closely, you can see places where the oil paints have been layered and layered, the result of endless attempts to get some tiny detail just right. It's a labor of love and it shows.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.40:
She turns around the canvas and you see yourself. Well, not just yourself.

It's Elisabeth's version of you, and while she isn't in the portrait itself, you can see so much of her personality in the painting. You look relaxed and confident, but adorned with an enigmatic smile and eyes that seems to be looking somewhere else.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.39:
She turns around the canvas and you see yourself. 

The image is surprising, but in an interesting way. You aren't unattractive by any stretch of the imagination, but like most you often gloss over the details of your own features, preferring the image you see in your head. You almost want to disagree with the painting but you know it's correct. 

It makes you think the way the best pieces of art do. It is a beautiful portrait, in that way that only the unadulterated truth can achieve.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.38:
She turns around the canvas and you see your future.

You asked Elisabeth to give you perfection and she delivered it unto you. Every beauty has been refined, and every flaw erased. You may be nude in the painting, but you feel as regal as any monarch laden with jewels, silks, and ermine.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.37:
"Oh, I almost forgot!" Elisabeth giggles. "I should probably show you the painting that you've been sitting for, all of this time."

With a burst of fresh energy she gets up and walks over to her easel.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.36: "Sorry, I must have finished up half an hour ago." She says with a sly grin. "I just enjoy looking at you like this."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.35:
Elisabeth stops to breathe quietly, slowly regaining her composure. One of her hands plays with the edge of the canvas apron she's wearing over her dress.

"Ok, I'm fine now. Shall we get started? I'm just itching to work!"
19140.The Final Sitting.node.34: She grabs you by the wrist and pulls you inside.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.33: Your mind reels with uncertainty as you carefully ascend the stairs to your bedroom. Still preoccupied with your mixed feelings, you fall into a restless sleep.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.32: Feeling buoyed by the heady thrills of love, you ascend to your bedroom on light feet, and prepare yourself for bed.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.31: You arrive home, still unsure of how you feel.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.30: Outside, you walk home. Compared to the nightmarish hustle and bustle of before, the streets feel almost abandoned. You stroll alone, completely lost in your own thoughts.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.29:
The two of you lounge and chat about the painting for some time. You pace about the studio while you talk, relishing the chance to stretch your limbs after all this time.

Eventually it gets late enough that the two of you have to say your goodbyes. Elisabeth helps you back into your dress.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.28: While Elisabeth is out fetching said refreshments, you take the time to slip back into your foundation garments. You keep your stays tied loosely, because you'd hate to get in the way of your own appetite.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.27:
Some time later, after taking the time to fix your hair and slip back into your foundation garments, you're taking tea and pastries with Elisabeth.

They taste amazing, but that might just be because you're famished.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.26: You have to admit, she is very warm.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.25:
"Fair enough, I'll fetch us some refreshements. You must be famished."

Before you can reply, the rumbling of your stomach speaks for you.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.24:
"Well, the client is always right." She replies with a smirk. 

With the rustling sound of skirts, Elisabeth kneels on the couch and places a hand on the armrest behind you. Gently, she leans forward over you. You crane your neck until your lips meet.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.23: Her finger traces down the outside of your thigh. "How'd you like to warm up?"
19140.The Final Sitting.node.22: She gets up from her easel and walks over to you. "You must be very cold."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.21:
FInally, Elisabeth stands up from her easel with a laugh. "I'm sorry Yvette, but I've been done over half an hour ago." 

She favors you with a sly grin. "I just enjoy looking at you like this."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.20: You squint as you notice that her brush hand hasn't moved in an awfully long time.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.19: You silently roll your shoulders and resettle into your pose. You're not positioned to look at Elisabeth directly, but out of the corner of your eye you can see her leaning away from the canvas to examine you.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.18: "Oh, what?" Elisabeth asks, standing up from her canvas.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.17: Later, you find yourself shifting on the couch again. This has been quite a long session.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.16:
Another hour passes, and you take a break to stand up and stretch. Even with your relaxed pose on the couch, all of that time spent staying exactly still starts to wear on you. 

You return back to your position, and Elisabeth to her art.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.15: Elisabeth returns to her painting, still glancing up at you at regular intervals before squinting down at some particular detail.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.14: With nothing more than a contented smile, Elisabeth returns to her painting, still glancing up at you on ocassiona before squinting down at some particular detail.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.13: "Of course not, this is just for me... and you."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.12: "Now, I need you to stop being so funny for a moment, I can't be gigling during some of these more precise details." The artist says with a mock sternness.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.11:
Elisabeth puts down her brush for a moment and laughs into the back of her hand. "Oh really, is that so?"

(You have gained some favor with Elisabeth)
19140.The Final Sitting.node.10: Elisabeth doesn't say anything for a while, but instead shifts uncomfortably at her easel.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.9:
"Oh really, you trust me?" Elisabeth asks with an arched eyebrow. She's trying to remain aloof, but you can tell that she's actually a little touched.

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
19140.The Final Sitting.node.8: "I wasn't sure you'd even agree to even pose for me. Nudes tend to make clients nervous."
19140.The Final Sitting.node.7: At this stage, she's focusing on specific details of your portrait. Ocassionally, she asks for you to minutely shift parts of your body this way and that.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.6:
With what has become a practiced ease, you disrobe and take your position on the satin couch. 

Elisabeth takes the cover off of your portrait and starts preparing her paints.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.5:
The door creaks open and you can see Elisabeth's angry face on the other side.

"Yvette, if this is a joke, it's not funny. You know my situation." She hisses at you, making significant glances to the shapes of the servants in the windows above.

(You have lost a little favor with Elisabeth)
19140.The Final Sitting.node.4:
"Ah, it's great to see you!" Elisabeth says as she strides into the room, already dressed to paint. "Shall we get started? I'm just itching to work."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
19140.The Final Sitting.node.3: Keeping Elisabeth's previous requests for discretion in mind, you let yourself into her studio. A cool breeze sweeps through the open windows, rustling the cloth that covers the painting-in-progress.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.2: Still thinking of the myriad people who wouldn't get out of your way on the walk over here, you knock sharply on the door.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.1: Still, you manage to arrive at the painting studio without incident or injury.
19140.The Final Sitting.node.0:
It takes a little longer than before to get to Elisabeth's studio today. There's no special event, the streets are simply crowded with throngs of people going about their daily business. 

You resist the urge to scream and shove them out of your way, but just barely.
19140.The Final Sitting.link.50: "Elisabeth is extremely useful. It's good to have her trust."
19140.The Final Sitting.link.29: "It'll take some time before I know how I feel about this."
19140.The Final Sitting.link.28: "That was lovely. Nobody's made me feel the way Elisabeth does."
19140.The Final Sitting.link.23: "In that case, I'd love some tea please."
19140.The Final Sitting.link.22: "Just shut up and kiss me already."
19140.The Final Sitting.link.10: "Don't worry, I would have suggested a nude, even if you didn't."
19140.The Final Sitting.link.9: "Well, as long you don't go parading this in public I'll be fine."
19140.The Final Sitting.link.8: "That's because your clients don't know you like I do. They don't trust you like I do."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.75: None of hte other guests have no context for this display of fury. All they know is that you were willing to come to Madame Gazel's defense in a most spectacular fashion. Even if they don't approve of it, they do seem to respect it.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.74: Still, some part of this stranger remains unconvinced, which makes sense. Your lie was absolutely preposterous.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.73: She's not wrong. You can feel how red your cheeks are.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.72: You can't even remember when the conversation stopped, but both of your wrists are in Madame Gazel's hands, and her lips are drifting so close to yours.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.71: (You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.69: The rest of the evening is a blur. You're not even sure if you did anything else at the party before you headed home. You spend a few hours trying to peice the events together in your journal.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.68:
(You have gained quite a bit of peril)
(You have gained quite a bit of credibility)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.67: Words of purest venom issue forth from your mouth, with such speed and violence that you don't even remember what you said. What you do remember, is the looks on the faces of everyone who heard you say it.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.66: Hurtling from room to room, you come upon her, merrily talking with other guests as if nothing had ever happened. As if she was innocent.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.65: You can't hear anything other than your own breathing and the blood pumping in your ears. The anger is so overwhelming that it's become intoxicating.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.64: Realizing that you've already drawn your fair share of suspicion, the two of you eventually part ways. If nothing else, this has ensured that you've had a lovely evening.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.62: "You know that's not what I meant."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.61: Taking the time to lock the door this time, the two of you resume your same positions as before, and spend some more time together, whispering meaningless nothings and drawing ever closer. The time slips away from the both of you.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.59: (You have gained quite a bit of favor with Madame Gazel)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.58: "I must admit that I never expected you to be the one to defending me, Yvette. In fact, I never really expected anyone to defend me at all."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.56: With that she leaves, and tries to slam the door on her way out. Unfortunately for her, the door gets caught on the carpet and just lazily drifts shut.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.55: "This isn't over." She sneers at you both. "You people can't evade the eyes of society forever."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.54: "But you're free to leave at any time."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.53: "You are at least partly correct." Honorade chimes in. "I too am absolutely disgusted."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.52: "W-well, this is disgusting. In fact, both of you are." The interloper replies with with venom, but far quieter than she intended. The lack of volume seems to rob her of the intended gravitas.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.51: "Well, that certainly got my heart racing." Madame Gazel giggles.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.50: After a few moments, the two of you finally exhale in unison.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.49: The suspicious woman leaves, glancing back at the two of you one last time before she disappears from your sight.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.48: "I suppose that's reasonable." She says, with a strange sense of disappointment about her.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.47: Outwardly she looks calm, but she's squeezing your hand so hard that your fingers are starting to tingle.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.46: Unable to stand this indignity anymore, you stand up in a whirl of finery and fury. You rush out the door to find this interloper and tell her exactly what you think of her disgust.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.45: Alone, you just sit in the room by yourself for a while. You lose track of time as you relive every detail of what just transpired, over and over again. You can't help it. All you can do it relive the moments, picking apart the flaws of every exchange.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.44: You glance around the room. There's nothing here except a low fire, and a sense of heartache.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.43: (You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel... Don't worry, it's not really your fault.)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.42: With that, Honorade leaves, and you are alone.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.41: Suddenly, she stands up, the shine of tears just starting to well up in her eyes. "I'm sorry Yvette... I just need to.. I just-"
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.40: "I know I said that I was in a great mood before, but this is... that was..." She trails off, never completing the sentence. She doesn't need to.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.39: With that, this person leaves as suddenly as they arrived. Yet, the pall they cast over the room remains. Madame Gazel sighs, and stares at the ceiling.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.37: This interloper seems surprised, yet also smugly satisfied. Like weilding this power is what fulfills her.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.36: The two of you sit together in stony silence. Even the crackling of the fire seems muted.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.35: She sneers at you both. "You disgusting people can't evade the eyes of society forever."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.34:
(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.33: Madame Gazel stands up her chair, still holding onto one of your hands. "It's true! My dear friend here is so clumsy. I just have no idea what she'd do without me."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.32: "Oh don't bother with those preposterous lies."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.31: She glares suspicously at you and mumbles "Well, you do look rather flushed."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.29: The room goes silent, and even you are taken aback by the audacity of the woman who just said that. That is, until you remember that the woman who made that comment is you.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.28: After a pause, Madame Gazel agrees. "She's right. It's nothing at all."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.27: "What, exactly are the two of you doing?"
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.26: She looks disgusted by what she sees, but also completely unsurprised. As if she was looking for something.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.25: Suddenly, your spine goes stiff at the sound of the door opening. A woman walks into the room, and the both of you go as still as statues.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.24: "Oh, you ever remain full of surprises."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.23: She drops her hands from your eyes and you turn around to find yourself face to face with none other but Madame Gazel.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.22: "Fortunately for you, I'm already in a great mood, and I'd like to celebrate it with you. First, however, we'll need to find somewhere quiet."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.21: Turning yourself around, you find yourself face to face with none other than Madame Gazel. "In what world do I sound like Armand?"
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.20:
The room goes dark as someone comes up behind you and places their hands over your eyes.

<Black Background>
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.19: The two of you engage in little snippets of conversation, all of them meaningless. Instead, the both of you are focused on each other. The entire party going on in the other rooms fades into the background as you slowly let go of yourself. Let yourself be made lesser than another. Let yourself be controlled.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.18: (You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.17: She entwines her fingers in the hair on the back of your head, and slowly but firmly, Madame Gazel pulls your face close to hers. "And I ever love instilling obedience in you."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.16: (You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.15: Walking off to the side, you grab one of the chairs and drag it in front of her. Comfortably, you take a seat. All Madame Gazel can do is roll her eyes.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.14: Undaunted, you stride up to her, and in a smooth motion you sit on her lap. Surprised, she leans back and lets a wide grin blossom across her face. Her features flicker in the firelight.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.13: Careful to make sure that you don't step on your own dress, you sit on the floor infront of her, your legs curled off to one side and your body propped up on one hand. She looms over you, and she smiles.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.12: "Sit." She commands, pointing to a spot on the floor in front of her.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.11: Finally, the two of you manage to find an empty room in the party, forgotten by the other guests. A low fire burns in the fireplace, but nobody is here. She slowly shuts the door behind you, and takes a seat in a big, overstuffed chair.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.10: You also can't help but notice how many guests' eyes linger on the way she's holding your hand. Nobody says a word, but they do watch.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.9: Your progress through the crowds of the party is surprisingly slow. People keep stopping the two of you to pay their respects to Madame Gazel, and ask her for her opinion on various matters particular to the bourgeoisie.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.8: She grabs you by the hand, and leads you away to a distant corner of the party.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.7: "I'm in a great mood, and I'd like to celebrate it with you. First, however, we'll need to find somewhere quiet."
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.6: (You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.5: (You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)

18496.The Eyes of Society.node.3: "Armand? Really?" The voice asks, as they drop their hands from your eyes.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.2: "Mmm... a mere lucky guess." She replies, but you can hear the smile in her voice.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.1: "Guess who?" A sultry voice whispers in your ear.
18496.The Eyes of Society.node.0: You wander around the party, scanning the room for someone interesting to talk to. You hear some shuffling behind you.

18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.32: (You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.29: (You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.28:
The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling they didn’t believe you.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.27:
“Well, if you did actually grow up there, you must be more familiar with the facts than us.” The older man demures, already pulling his friend away by the elbow. “We would hate to supply you with any misinformation.”

He puts a strong emphasis on the word ‘supply’.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.26:
The younger man examines you carefully before he says “That’s quite an unusual accent you have, for someone who grew up in Grenoble.”

Your mind races, and you’re not sure if you can remember what a Grenoble accent even sounds like.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.25: "I can understand why, madame. It was grizzly enough that the church didnt make any official announcements. The archbishops funeral was closed casket because-"
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.24: During your conversation, you manage to get a few more details about the time of death, who discovered the body, and more. This is exactly what you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Specific details add an air of truthfulness which is necessary for quality gossip. This should be valuable to someone.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.23: “I suppose he’s right.” The younger man admits. “What’s most important is that archbishop’s death was a suicide, and this made the church extremely uncomfortable. This is why they were so quiet about his passing.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.22: You continue your hushed conversation with the two men, and manage to tease out a few more specifics. The three of you eventually go your separate ways.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.21: This is exactly the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Gruesome details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.20: “The archbishop of Grenoble shot himself.” The younger man says flatly. “It was a suicide, and a particularly gruesome one at that. That’s why he was in a closed casket instead of being laid out properly. It was also why the church was so unwilling to divulge the details of his death.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.19: “Don’t worry, such details are unnecessary to understanding the bigger picture.” The older man says in an a patronizing tone.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.18: After a long pause, the older man relents. “Fine, if you must know...”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.17: “I would not want to offend the madame’s sensibilities with such dreadful details.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.16: The older guest stops his friend mid sentence. “I’m not sure if we should continue.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.15:
The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling that you’ll be watched more closely from now on.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.14: Before you can answer, his older friend chimes in. “Perhaps we should take our conversation elsewhere. I doubt that we’ll find any privacy here.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.13:
You hear a throat clear.

“Can we help you, madame?” The younger man asks you, with a suspicious scowl.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.12: However, this does give you the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself isn’t valuable. Details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

Your mind conjures up a gruesome image, entirely against your will, and you wretch internally at it.

18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.9: “For a many of the cloth to commit the cardinal sin? It is the only explanation.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.8: “He must have felt some guilt for everything that happened.” The older man ventures.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.7: You decide against engaging them in conversation, or listening in. While it’s nice to have some reliable gossip, you don’t need it that badly right now. Instead, you spend some time wandering about the party, sipping at your wine, taking in the sights and the sounds.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.6: The men are speaking to each other in low voices, and it’s difficult to hear them over the din of the party. You edge a little closer to listen to them, pretending to scan the party as if you were looking for a friend that got lost in the crowd.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.5: They turn, noticing you for the first time.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.4: If you could learn more, this might be some truly valuable gossip.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.3:
“That he'd killed himself after the riots. Yes, even I found that distressing.”

You’d heard that too, but it was only a rumor. The Church never confirmed this, but why would they?
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.2: The older man replies wearily “Agreed, and the bloodshed was monstrous. Did you hear about their Bishop?”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.1: The younger one sighs, and gestures to the crowd with his wine glass. “Everyone’s talking about reforming the estates as if it’s going to be as simple as making a request. Does nobody remember what happened in Grenoble? They sent soldiers into that town just for trying to hold a meeting.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.node.0: You happen upon a pair of men whispering in a corner together. They’re trying to look as happy and engaged as the other guests, but they’re movements are too stiff. They seem concerned.
18870.The Cardinal Sin.link.15: “Perhaps you are right. It may be too much for me.”
18870.The Cardinal Sin.link.4: “Pardon monsieurs, but I grew up in Grenoble and I never found out what happened. Do you know?”
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.76: You can’t help but grin with satisfaction. This is the lead you were looking for.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.75: You turn the painting back and forth looking for more details, until you hear something metallic shift. Flipping the painting over, you find a note tucked into the frame on the back of painting, along with a key. You don’t recognize the handwriting, but decide against taking the time to read the note now, while illegally trespassing in a condemned building. You carefully fold the note around the key and secret it under your stays.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.74: Armand’s smiling face is looking back at you from the picture, a glass raised in mid toast, and a quill in his free hand. On one side of him is a man you remember from your last night together with Armand. The man is named Isaac. On the other side of him, is a young woman, with strawberry blonde hair, who you’ve never seen before. Her hand is on his shoulder.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.73:
It’s a dining scene, done in a reflected perspective intended to make the actual room feel larger than it really is. All the men and women in the picture are laughing, clinking glasses and looking merry. 

Even Armand.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.71: The rest of the unburned scraps look too small or unclear to provide you with any additional information.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.70: ‘-and de Marbo’, written in familiar handwriting on a fragment of paper. Armand was here, perhaps in this very room. Maybe there’s something else connected to him nearby.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.69:
You pick through the ashes, finding fragments of leather and scraps of unburned paper. The writing on the paper is handwritten, not printed. It looks like a list of names. A membership list?

That’s when you spot it.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.67: You find nothing else of value under the circular table.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.65: While you’re sure this reading list is insightful, it won’t bring you closer to finding Armand.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.64: Eventually, you can deduce a meaning from the scratchings. All the notes are suggested readings, various books and pamphlets. They seem to cover a broad range of texts related to religious or political theory. The authors extend from France to the rest of the continent, and even the Americas.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.63: Stepping over the ash in front of the fireplace, you gingerly take the painting off of its hook and examine it closely. It’s not as carefully detailed as some of the others in the building, but there’s a certain joyful energy to it. Whoever painted this genuinely enjoyed making it.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.62:
You bend down carefully, making sure you don’t kneel in the large swath of ashes in front of the fireplace. A cold breeze blows at your back and you look up at the charred hole in the roof of the building. This fire must have gotten large enough to set a portion of the ceiling ablaze. It’s a miracle this building is still standing at all.

Whoever started this fire didn’t have time to do things properly, they just needed something burned.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.61: You scan the room, deciding what to investigate.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.60: No. Wait. It’s just terrible handwriting.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.59:
You find a small scattering of coins. It appears that, at some point in the chaos, someone must have dropped their coin purse, and nobody noticed it. It doesn’t bring you closer to Armand, but you’ll never turn down free coin.

(You’ve gained +6 Livre!)
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.58: You bend down to investigate under the table, trying to find what caught the light of your lantern and glimmered at you from the dark.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.57: You lean close to the notes on the wall, and squint to read them. None of them make any sense, as if they were written in another language, or some kind of code.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.56: What are you going to investigate?
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.55: Inside, the back room is cramped, mostly occupied by a circular table with some small chairs. Various notes are pinned to the wall, and as you shine your lantern about, you notice a slight glimmer under the table.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.53: You feel like you’ve learned everything you can from the paintings in this room.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.52: Looking at the paintings, you feel like you’ve learned something about the artists here, but nothing useful about Armand. You’ll have to search somewhere he would have spent a lot of time in.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.51: The stairs creak underneath your feet as you make your way to the second floor. The long table and scattered cutlery suggests that it was used as a dining area. A small fireplace occupies one side of the room, with a wide swath of ash spilling out of the fireplace and onto the floor. Above the fireplace itself, a painting hangs on the mantle.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.50: The entrance to the back room isn’t obvious and if Pierre hadn’t told you about it earlier, you might have mistaken it for a closet door. When you go to open the door, you notice that the latch has been torn off. Probably a casualty of the raid.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.47: You feel like you’ve learned everything you can from the paintings in this room.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.46: Looking at the paintings, you feel like you’ve learned something about the artists here, but nothing useful about Armand. You’ll have to search somewhere he would have spent a lot of time in.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.45: The paintings on the wall are all traditional historical pieces, exactly the sort of thing L’Academie exalts as ‘true art’. 19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.44: You rummage through the papers, but it seems like everything useful has already been taken.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.39: You scan the room, deciding what to investigate.

19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.34: Scanning the room, you try to determine what you’ll investigate.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.32: Hansel steps in front of you and whispers. “Now that we have a light in here, it’s only a matter of time before someone spots us. I recommend we move quickly, madame.”
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.31: Now that you have a little more light, you can see that most of the furniture inside is broken, and enough things are missing to make you wonder how much the Guet Royal seized during their raid.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.30:
Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.29: The stairs creak underneath your feet as you make your way to the second floor. The long table and scattered cutlery suggests that it was used as a dining area. It’s also only a matter of time before someone spots you and comes to investigate.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.25: From your position outside, you peer into the gloom and watch Hansel examine the room for a few moments before he gives a satisfied nod, dropping his hand from his weapon. Returning to the window, he grabs you by the waist, and easily helps you into the building.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.24:
He enters the building first, his face frozen in a grim expression that almost makes you feel bad for any dangerous persons you might encounter.

Almost.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.23: You get Hansel’s attention, and he quietly takes down the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.22:
Now that you’re closer, you can see that the door has been nailed shut. Wordlessly, you and Hansel start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.21: The mercenary crouches down and places his hand on the grip of his sabre. You hike up your skirts, and get ready to follow him. On his signal, you quietly dash across the street together, watching for any movement in the windows as your approach.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.20: When you get to the window, Hansel’s hands emerge from the darkness and grab you by the waist, easily helping you into the building.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.19: After what feels like an eternity, you see his hand emerge from the opened window and motion for you to approach. You hike up your skirts and quietly hurry across the street towards him.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.18:
Hansel gazes warily at the building before turning back to you. For a moment he looks like he’s about to object, but your mind is obviously made up. 

“Understood, madame. We go together.”
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.17: Eventually, he finds that some of the boards covering one of the windows are loose, quietly pries them off, and easily hops through the window into the building inside. You catch glimpses of him through some of the other windows as he scouts out the darkened interior.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.16: Crouching as low as his sizeable frame will allow, Hansel advances towards the building with his hand firmly on the grip of his sabre. He glances inside the windows and tries the door, which appears to be have been nailed shut.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.15: “Madame, I’d like to inspect the building first. You never know who’s taken up residence in empty places like this.”
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.14:
Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.13: You carefully ease yourself through the window, making sure none of your clothes get caught on any exposed nails. Once inside, you close your eyes for a few moments, so they’ll adjust to the darkness faster.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.12: Gingerly, you take down each of the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later. Secrets are easier to uncover when nobody knows that you’re looking at all.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.11: Leaning back and craning your neck to examine the roof, you see there’s a hole big enough for you to enter the building through, but you don’t have a ladder, or any way to get up there. 19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.10:
Putting down your unlit lantern, you start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one set of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.9: You immediately notice that the door’s been nailed shut.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.8: Rather than stand around in the middle of a dark street, you hike up your skirts and hurry across the road to the studio.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.7: Glancing around, you don’t see anyone at all, as if the King’s notice somehow closed the entire street.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.6: Before you can step any further towards the closed building, Hansel steps in front of you.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.5: Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. 19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.4: Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. 19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.3: Winding your way through the streets of the 7th Arrondissement, you can’t help but think about how out of the way this place would have been for Armand. Yet, Pierre said that he was still a regular visitor. Despite yourself, you find your heart beating faster and faster as you get closer to the abandoned studio.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.2: You waited for sunset before you headed out, as it feels like these sort of things are better done under the cover of darkness. However, everything still feels too bright. Every hanging lantern, every candle-lit window, feels like an eye staring down at you.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.1: Tugging on the edges of your hood to make sure your face is hidden from view, you glance down again at the hastily scribbled address Pierre gave you in his office. In addition to your regular traveling clothes, you have a small bag hanging off of your shoulder, and a portable lantern with a flint.
19044.The Abandoned Studio.node.0: The front of the building is the painting studio, the floors spattered with pigments, and still littered with the scraps of various art supplies. An ornate desk sits in the front of the room, near the door, with papers scattered all around it. A few finished canvases still remain on the walls, though it looks like a lot of the others were either seized or destroyed.

13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.20: After a brief pause, Camille ventures “Madame, if I may ask, can I have the kitchen to myself? I’d like to start making your lunch.”
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.19: “That’s all I can remember madame. Now… if I may ask, can I have the kitchen to myself? I’d like to start making your lunch.”
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.18: You look down at the green ink used the write the note to Armand. A connection?
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.17:
“However...” Camille straightens up, tapping her finger on her chin. “There was a woman who came by more frequently than the other guests. She had brown hair, and a scar on her chin.
I remember her because she always wore a silver necklace, with the prettiest emerald in the center of it.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.16: “Madame, what would you like me to do?”
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.15: “Understood madame!” Camille replies cheerily. “Armand required his privacy as well, it’s no wonder the two of you were engaged.”
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.14: “I never asked anyone’s names, madame.” Camille admits, looking downcast. “So many of Monsieur Armand’s guests valued their privacy, that I wanted to give them a polite amount space.”
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.12:
Camille looks utterly shocked when you press the money into her hands. “Madame I can’t possibly take this, it’s too much, it’s too…” she trails off as she evaluates your expression, and composes herself a moment later.

(You have given away 25 Livres!)
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.11:
“Know about what?” Camille asks, glancing between you and the bag of coins in your hands. “Was that Monsieur Armand’s? Why would he leave money in the house?”

She seems to be even more confused by all of this than you are.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.10: “I was just about to start making lunch…” Camille says, pointing awkwardly at the stove.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.9: You look up from your sudden windfall to see Camille standing in the doorway to the kitchen. Her eyes are darting between you and the box in confusion.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.8:
You look inside the bag… that’s a lot of coins.

(You have gained 100 Livres!)
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.7: Inside the box you find a magnetic compass, a map of Paris with notes concerning when the guards change at every one of the city gates, and a leather bag heavy with coins.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.6: You pull up the floorboards and fish around in the dark until you find a small wooden box, held shut by a padlock. You open it with the key you found behind the painting.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.5:
Heading downstairs, you walk into the kitchen. It’s clean but cramped, and Camille keeps it well stocked with fresh produce. You find the stove, made of dark iron and standing on a set of clawed feet. 

Alone, on your hands and knees, you feel around until you find a set of loose floorboards.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.4:
You turn over the letter and find no additional writing, no additional context or explanation. 

Who is Marie-Jeanne? How long has Armand known her for? Is she one of the people he’d been writing back home?
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.2:
‘If fortune turns against us, then I want you to flee Paris entirely. I know you’ve objected to the idea before, but it’s the only way for you to stay safe. To aid in this, I’ve secreted a package under the loose floorboards beneath your stove. This key will open it.’

You look at the key. It’s still here, so Armand never received the note.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.1:
‘Dear Armand,

I will always appreciate your commitment to our cause, and I know France will be better for it. However, our chance of being caught grows with every passing day. I will not waste ink painting terrible pictures of the consequences, as you are already familiar with them.’
13094.Stranger and Stranger.node.0: Back home, you finally pull the note and key out from under your stays. Unfamiliar handwriting written in rich, emerald ink.
13094.Stranger and Stranger.link.16: “Who was Marie-Jeanne? How well did she know Armand?”
13094.Stranger and Stranger.link.13: “Who was Marie-Jeanne? How well did she know Armand?”
13094.Stranger and Stranger.link.11: “Looks like we both got lucky today.” (-25 Livre)
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.17: Eyes frowning, mouths agape, the pair just stares at you in shock.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.16:
"What are you, a child?" The inebriated friend manages to ask. You can hear a few chuckles from the crowd around you.

(You have lost a little more credibility)
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.14: The room feels palpably quieter as the two of them stare at you in disbelief.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.13:
Her drunk friend decides that now would be a good time to chime in. "What's wrong? It's not like I made that dress look any worse."

You hear a few people in the crowd chuckle at this clumsy barb.

(You have lost some credibility)
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.12: With a mutter of apology, the pair depart and leave you alone. The crowd takes their focus off of you and returns to the party.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.11:
With narry a backward glance, the two leave, giggling to themselves.

Looking around at the rest of the guests at the party, hoping to find some sort of aid, you can tell that you're being studiously ignored.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.10: With a mutter of half hearted retorts, the pair skulk away, much to the delight of those present. Your dress may be in worse condition than when you started, but at least you got to have some fun at the expense of those who deserve it.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.9: "Ah yes, we'll certainly apologize for you being so careless as to spill wine all over yourself at the slightest nudge."
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.8:
[Success]
Not only are the pair in front of you somewhat taken aback by your firm request, the watching crowd mutters in approval. While the two women don't seem thrilled about having to apologize, they can tell that the room has turned against them in a serious way.

(You have gained some credibility)
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.7:
Before they can even say anything, they're interrupted with laughter from the other guests in this room, who seem to appreciate your biting wit. The pair of women settle on staring daggers in your direction until the laughter subsides.

(You have gained quite a bit of credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.5:
Surprised by your patience and mangnanimity, they get some water and help you blot at the stain before it dries completely. It's enough to get rid of most of the stain, but it's still noticable to those who look for it.

(You have gained a little credibility back)
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.4: "Why did we stop? Where are we going?" She slurs, looking confused.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.3:
Turning around, you see two women, one of them is obviously deep in their cups. The other appears to be trying to prevent her friend from embarassing themselves too much. 

"Sorry about the stain, we were just leaving." The sober one apologizes half-heartedly.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.2:
Looking down, you see an enormous wine stain down your front.

(Your outfit has lost some novelty)
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.1:
Suddenly, you feel someone barge into you, sending you reeling a few steps. While you manage to catch your balance on a nearby table, your chest feels wet, and your wineglass now appears to be empty.

Oh no.
15276.Spilled Drinks.node.0:
Relaxing at the party, you feel more comfortable with your new life than before. Sipping from your recently acquired glass of wine, you notice a fresh batch of hors d'oeuvres being brought out from the kitchen.

This feels right. You could get used to this.
15276.Spilled Drinks.link.16: "That's a good question. Why did you stop? Embarassments like you belong outside." <Peril Icon>
15276.Spilled Drinks.link.4: "It's alright, you're free to go when I get an apology." <Credibility Check Icon>
15276.Spilled Drinks.link.3: "Pardon, I'm not mad, can you just help me blot this stain before it sets?"

18950.Rumor Mongers.node.15: "Well, I suppose that does make sense. I did learn something shocking about a prominent lawyer today..."
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.14: Adopting your best, most vapid expression, you pretend to be utterly fascinated by some flowers blooming near them. The two of them pay you no mind as your approach and crouch low, listening to their exchange.
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.13: Once he finishes up and seperates from his companion, you approach the young rumor monger and offer him a similar exchange to the one he performed with his older compatriot.
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.12: Once he finishes up and seperates from his companion, you approach the old gossip catcher and offer him a similar exchange to the one he performed with his young compatriot.
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.11: They lean in and start whispering to each other. Their voices are too low for you to hear from here.
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.10: His new compatriot chuckles. "Are we? All we have to do is share our gossip between ourselves, then sell it all to different newspapers on the same day. We each make twice the money!"
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.9: The older man puts out his hand, for the other one to stop. "What are you doing? Why, exactly would I share anything I've learned with you? We're competitors in this business."
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.8: "Oh! Anything juicy lately?" The younger man leans in. "I myself, heard the most fascinating things about a certain General in the Military..."
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.7: "Now I sell what I find to a far more reputable clientele."
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.6: You would, of course, rush to Pierre's defense if all those vile accusations weren't so... true.
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.5: "Ugh, yes! I used to sell gossip to that self important drunk. After all, he used to be the only game in town. Frankly, I'm glad to be free of that slimy weasel."
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.4: "I take it you used to work for Pierre Renaudot as well..."
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.3: You break from your increasingly venomous internal accusations, when you hear a familiar name mentioned by someone nearby.
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.2: Still, you have mountains of extenuating circumstances that have brought you to this point! What are their excuses? Have they no shame?
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.1: You wonder to yourself if any of these idle malingerers have jobs, until your remember that you too share a similar, ill-earned but decadent lifestyle.
18950.Rumor Mongers.node.0: During one of your explorations of the city, you find yourself in a fountain square. Groups of people are clustered together, locked in the kind of deep yet carefree conversations that make you wonder what, exactly, these people do all day.

Without Marie Antoinette using her influence to get her way, and without Princess Maria having a great portrait to glorify her, the legitimacy of kings and queens atrophies, just a little.

18030.Pierre's Proposal.node.10: “If you bring me gossip related to all five of the factions in this city, the Crown, the Church, the Military, the Bourgeoisie, and the Revolutionaries, I will tell you where to learn more about your estranged Armand.”

18030.Pierre's Proposal.node.8: “Of course, I cannot work for free.” Pierre admits, shifting awkwardly from foot to foot. “I must support my newspaper, after all. But if you help me with this, I will help you as best I can.”

After all, it’s easier to sell newspapers when there’s something to write about.”

16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.24: There's something special about riding a horse. Being in a carriage, you inspire mystery, as you wind through the streets hidden from view. The public is left to wonder about your identity, your appearance, your intentions.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.23: With a tug of the reins and an enthusiastic yell, Joseph rears up and you grab onto Alex instictively. Together, you take off down the street at a good clip.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.22: (You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.21: (You have earned some favor with Alexandre)
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.20: (You have earned a little favor with Alexandre)
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.19: "Ah! Ever the woman of action! I love it."
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.18: "Well, I was just hoping you'd hold me close, but yes, I do like know you're safe."
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.17: "Don't worry, I'm one of the best riders in my unit. You'll be fine." He replies, unenthusiastically.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.15: You place a hand on the back of the saddle and he grabs you by the middle of your forearm. On the count of three, you jump up, and he pulls you the rest of the way onto the horse. Thankfully, you already know how to ride side saddle, or this would be quite undignified.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.14: (You have earned a little favor with Alexandre)
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.13: Alex affectionately tousle's his steed's mane with a free hand. Joseph gives an appreciative neigh in response.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.12: "I named him Joseph!" He laughs. "I haven't heard any complaints from him yet, so I can only assume he agress."
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.11: (You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.10: (You have earned some favor with Alexandre)
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.8: He looks somewhat taken aback. "I'm not joking. I was hoping to offer you a ride tonight."
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.7: "I was hoping you'd say that." Alex says with a grin, as he adjusts himself further forward in his saddle.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.6: "Madame, you look far too beautiful to be walking the streets. May Joseph and I assist you?"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.5: Alex is already waiting for you outside, astride a brilliant white horse. Everything on his uniform is perfectly in place, and the leather polished to a mirror's shine.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.4: That's when you're greeted by something truly surprising.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.3: With a light step you head downstairs and Camille opens the front door for you.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.2: He turns to you with a mischevious grin. "Yvette, can you check my holster?"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.1: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution by quite a bit)
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.node.0: Getting ready for your rednezvous with Alex, you check your makeup in the mirror one last time. Flawless, as per usual.
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.105: "This champagne is exquisite. You should have taken two bottles."
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.104: "When you steal from theives, it's no longer theft?"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.57: "Will your superiors be happy with you doing all of this with... Joseph?"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.55: "Are you alright, considering all the stuff that happened with your father?"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.41: "Are you sure? How about something to the people of France? To our nation?"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.40: "I like that. To the Crown and to us!"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.39: "Yes, let the Crown and the Bourbon dynasty last a thousand years."
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.38: "Are you sure? Don't you owe your freedom and new rank to the Crown?"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.37: "I like that. To the Revolution and to us!"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.36: "Why stop there? To France ruled by the people, and for the people!"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.35: "To the people of France, and the Revolutionaries!"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.34: "How about... To us, and to your success!"
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.33: "To his Majesty, the King! Long may he reign."
16526.Monsieur L'Humanité.link.17: "Only when you show me just how fast Joseph can go."

18826.Maximin Appears.node.40:
(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
18826.Maximin Appears.node.37: “Your cowardly fiance could have spent his time doing something useful, like echoing the views of his betters. Instead he chose to waste our time with calls to consider lesser, erroneous perspectives. We don’t need to tolerate this kind of intellectual and moral weakness. Both of you should do the right thing and skulk back to wherever you came from, in silence.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.36: “Of course, it’s a shame your loyalty is anchored to such mediocrity, but still...”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.35:
“Your loyalty to Armand is commendable, and exactly the sort of thing we’re striving to bring to this troubled nation of ours.”

A small cheer goes up from some of the crowd.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.34: “It’s been weeks since anyone’s heard from the Baron de Marbo. Originally, I’d taken it as a blessing that we no longer had to deal with his ignorant and uninformed declarations. However, now I find myself face to face with his fiancee, who isn’t just ignorant, but a liar!”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.33: “Unless, of course, he’s not actually sick.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.32: Maximin chuckles, “Of course, this gathering is more of a salon than a party, but I can see why you would be confused.” He reaches out and pats your hand. “Please don’t be embarrassed, I’m sure Armand will be able to explain the differences later, when he’s feeling better.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.31: "I must say that I’m surprised that Armand thinks so highly of true, revolutionary minds.” Murmurs of appreciation and agreement ripple through the crowd, but are quickly hushed by other guests, who are also pretending that they’re not listening in.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.30: “Tell your Baron de Marbo to stay in his sick bed. It is a blessing for all of France that we no longer have to deal with his ignorant and uninformed declarations.” He emphasizes his point by slapping one of his pamphlets against his thigh. “Who knows? Perhaps if the two of you read enough, you might be able to stop embarrassing yourselves.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.29: “You’ve lost him?” Maximin asks, a sudden note of confusion marring his features. “And you came here?”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.27: “I’ve been told that Armand is unable to join us tonight. What has delayed him?”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.26: “Ah, you must be Madame Decaux! I’m not sure if Armand spoke of me, I am Baron Maximin de Termes.” Right as he focuses his attention on you, you can feel everyone in the room watching you out of the corners of their eyes. His opinion must carry a great deal of weight.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.25: “Titles don’t elevate us above consequences. Now, leave my house and never return.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.24: “You are a fool for believing that, and he is a fool for loving you.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.22: “Our associations reflect our character, and you have chosen to associate yourself with an ignorant boor who drags at the heels of true progress in France. I can only assume that you are a craven opportunist who thought that marrying into a title would provide an easy path above her peers. That your life would be easy, if you just found the right person to latch onto.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.20: He takes a step towards you, and you can see that his eyes are filled with hate. “Now still your childish tongue. The adults are talking.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.19: The Baron takes a breath to recompose himself and snort derisively. “Well actually, if you’d taken the time to read any of the materials I just gave you, then you’d know that calls for civility are the enemy of progress.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.18:
“And you…” he continues “I don’t need to investigate you any further to know that you are cut from the same wretched cloth.” 

The room is quiet enough to hear a pin drop.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.17: “The only reason I even invited him was to save myself the time of authoring a pamphlet denouncing him.” Maximin snorts “He, and his regressive calls for moderation and discussion. In a time of such turmoil in our country, only decisive action has any meaning. To believe otherwise is to be a coward, and a bootlick to the enemies of the people.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.16: Maximin’s voice drops low, to a growl barely above a whisper, “Before you speak, I already know what you’re thinking. That somehow, you don’t deserve this…”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.15: “Calls for moderation in our time of crisis can only be seen as treasonous to the people of France. He is an enemy of the revolution, an enemy of the common people of France, and an enemy of mine. The only thing he can do to atone for his miserable views is to take you, and return to the backwards obscurity from whence he came!”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.14: Maximin narrows his eyes until they’re barely more than slits. “In fact, you can practice this virtue now and make sure that he hears this, should you manage to find him.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.13: You hear a collective intake of breath from the gawking crowd. Maximin seems on the verge of a retort, but he stutters for a moment instead.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.12: “I do not know where he has skulked off to, nor am I inclined to find him.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.11: “I invited your dullard fiance in order to denounce him and his views. People as uninformed as himself should not waste their time clouding discussions with their tiresome ignorance. They’re better served by repeating the words of their more revolutionary peers.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.10: “If he’s lost then it means we no longer have to entertain his invalid opinions.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.9: With a flood of realization he laughs “Oh, but of course! You’re just here, at my salon, to find your Armand! I thought you were here for our enlightened discourse but… no, this makes much more sense.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.8: The crowd is no longer making a secret of observing your conversation. They’re gawking.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.7: “In fact, when you do that, I have a message for him. Write this down, if you can.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.6: Maximin chuckles, “Of course, this gathering is more of a salon than a party, but I can see why you would be confused.” He reaches out and pats your hand. “Please don’t be embarrassed, I’m sure Armand will be able to explain the differences later, when he’s feeling better.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.5: “That’s fantastic to hear! I’m surprised that Armand thinks so highly of true, revolutionary minds.” Murmurs of appreciation and agreement ripple through the crowd, but are quickly hushed by other guests, who are also pretending that they’re not listening in.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.4: Maximin pauses, his eyes sweeping the room for a moment. “But please, I must trouble you with a question of my own.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.3:
“In fact, you may both find these useful!” He grabs a jumbled stack of political pamphlets off of his desk and hands them to you. “Discourse moves so rapidly after all, and I would hate for the two of you to have any trouble keeping up.”

A few voices in the crowd murmur in approval.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.2: “It’s great to meet the woman Armand spoke so much of. He said more about you than he did the state of the nation, and you know much he loves that.” Maximin smiles and offers a knowing wink. “Now that I’ve seen you, I can see why he had such muddled priorities.”
18826.Maximin Appears.node.1:
“But please, let us dispense with titles, you may call me Maximin!”

The crowd chuckles, and you can’t help but be surprised by this noble’s informality. This would be downright scandalous in any other circle. The conversations in the various corners of the room die down as people strain to hear your exchange with Maximin.
18826.Maximin Appears.node.0: You notice a tall, thin man dressed in somber, serious colors. The way people are clustered around him, you get the feeling that he’s quite important. He glances up from his current conversation, politely excuses himself, and approaches you.
18826.Maximin Appears.link.21: "I actually don't know, Maximin. I don't even know where he is."
18826.Maximin Appears.link.19: "I'm sorry, but Armand has taken ill. Still, he said that I just had to attend your party."
18826.Maximin Appears.link.7: “Are you even listening to yourself? Because I am, and I wish I wasn’t.”
18826.Maximin Appears.link.6: "You don't know where he is either, then?"
18826.Maximin Appears.link.5: "...if he was so mediocre, why did you invite him?"
18826.Maximin Appears.link.4: “I don’t need your pamphlets to know that you’re being a presumptuous boor.”
18826.Maximin Appears.link.3: "...why invite Armand if you disliked him so?"

19144.Marcelle Appears.node.29: She advances on you, close enough to feel the heat of her breath. “Let me be clear. You and your grasping fiance are not guests in my home, nor will you ever be. I invited him here so I could express my displeasure to him in person.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.28: She pauses before speaking to you in a whisper loud enough for the entire room to hear. “Don’t worry, I don’t expect you to understand this.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.27: “but now, I now have his cast off fiancee, who even had the audacity to lie to my face!”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.26: “Nobody’s heard from your cowardly fiance in weeks, which is especially surprising, since he could never stop pestering his betters.” The crowd, which only seems to be growing, murmurs in agreement. “In fact, it’s been so long that I thought I was rid of him once and for all…”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.25: “I mean, that’s because we both know Armand’s not sick.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.24: “Well I’m so glad you’re here, and I’m sure that he’ll be well soon.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.23: "Oh really, he insisted?" Marcelle trills and her dog yips happily.
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.22: "Trying to look like us? Act like us? Stop. You're just embarassing yourself."
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.21: “Now leave my estate, and never show your face here again.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.20: “Now pay attention, because I’d hate for you to miss the point. If you should ever find your wandering Armand, tell him that he is an unwelcome, conniving weasel. In fact, both of you should go back to your petty little village, and leave Paris to your superiors.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.19: Marcelle studies your face intently for a moment and her voice suddenly fills with concern. “Oh, you poor girl, don’t look so hurt! Think of this as educational. You don’t belong in Paris, the same way that a stray cat doesn’t belong in that dress.” She gestures dismissively at your finery.
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.18: A small cheer rings up from the crowd.
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.17: “Please pay attention, because I hate repeating myself. Your Armand is gone, off somewhere on another one of his foolish little political endeavors. However, if you should ever find him, tell him that he is an impudent weasel, who should go back to whatever backwater he crawled out of, and leave the running of this country to his superiors.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.16: “Your Armand is a conniving, impish, opportunist who sullies the good name of the entire nobility just by being alive. The only reason he even chose a common girl like you to be his wife, is because any lady of good breeding would see him for the weasel that he is.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.15: “but now, I have this commoner, who doesn’t know her place either!”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.14: “Now, not only do I find out that he’s a coward, who’s fled his fiancee, and his responsibilities…”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.13: “Armand, that ambitious little rat, was always reaching above his station. His audacity truly knew no bounds.” Her eyes are focused on you, but she’s speaking to the crowd, who seem to whisper in agreement. Even the dog regards you with malice.
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.11: For a moment, the crowd hushes. You seem to have struck a nerve. Even the dog looks a little undone. “I suppose that when cornered, even a rat will think it’s a lion,” Marcelle whispers, her voice like ice.
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.10: Marcelle pauses to pet her dog. “I don’t know where he is. In fact, it’s a shame that Armand’s already scurried off somewhere. I was really hoping to tell him this to his face, but then again, he always was so good at disappointing people. You’ll have to do.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.9: “Why? While those craven nationalists in their dingy salons like to hide behind their pamphlets and newsletters, people of quality must be brave enough to denounce our enemies in person.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.8: “Yet here you are, with a fresh set of nuisances. Does this ever end?”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.7: “I guess it makes sense that you’re here. Armand could never stop pestering his betters, so it feels rather appropriate that, even when sick, he’d send his peasant fiance to do it for him.” The crowd, which only seems to be growing, murmurs in agreement. “In fact, I almost thought I was rid of him once and for all…”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.6: “I mean, I was hoping he’d show his face here, but you’ll do.”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.5: Marcelle stares at you, concerned and shocked. “You don’t know where he is, and yet you still came to this little event of mine?” She gestures a free hand at the most splendid party you’ve ever seen in your life. “That is so kind of you, of course I’ll help!”
19144.Marcelle Appears.node.4: “That is so sweet of him!” Marcelle trills and her dog yips happily. “You’ve barely arrived from the country and he still wants you to meet all the people he’s been so fortunate to associate with. It’s very kind of you to represent him like this, and I’m sure that he’ll be well soon.”

13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.23: You stop to think about this new information. A mystery servant, who left Maximin’s employment suddenly, and under murky circumstances. It seems fruitful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.21: “Honestly, it’s been a nice change of pace, normally I just spend a lot of time listening to bishops and writing letters back to the Vatican. This has me out and about, enjoying Paris, and getting a feel for its people.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.20: “Haha! Sorry, I’ve always wanted to say something like that.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.18: “While I must go, be warned that tracking this person down will not be easy. I couldn’t find any information about this mystery servant. Not their name, where they live, or even the position they held in Maximin’s home. Still, I will pray for your success.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.17: You’re not sure if Ludovico helping you exact your revenge could really be classified as ‘the right thing’, but you’re not going to complain.
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.16: Ludovico leans in close and whispers in your ear, his voice barely audible. “Madame, Rome chose me as their eyes and ears in France. You didn’t think that they’d sent someone who’s never gotten their hands dirty, did you?”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.15: “Think nothing of it madame, I’m just trying to do the right thing.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.14: “A servant leaving their master, under mysterious circumstances… if Maximin has a dark secret then this is it.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.13: “While it’s nothing solid, I think you’ll be very interested in the fact that Maximin’s household goes through servants quite quickly.” He hands you a list of names, presumably of servants that used to work for Maximin. “There’s the usual complaints about long hours, skipped wages, and general unpleasantness. However, one of them stood out to me, simply because of how few details I could find.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.12: “With that in mind I started asking around about him, seeing if his revolutionary righteousness was real, or a mere facade.” He favors you with a sly smile. “At first I thought it would be difficult to interview so many people, but you’d be amazed at what people are willing to tell a simple priest.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.11: “... is a very good point,” he admits with a defeated sigh. You can tell that he was quite enjoying this air of intrigue, but you need results. Ludovico sits down next to you and composes himself.
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.10: “As I said before, I’m sorry for everything that happened to you. Something about Maximin’s smug demeanour has always rubbed me the wrong way, even ignoring all of his snide remarks about the church.”
13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.9: You find a quiet corner in the square to speak with Ludovico. He opens the book he’s carrying and reads over some sort of list he’s keeping in it.

13410.Ludovico's Lead.node.6: “Is there anything this humble priest can help you with?”

15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.30: True to his word, the captain casts off in three minutes. Just like that, it starts to leave Paris behind.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.29: (You have gained quite a bit of credibility)
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.28: The dock is awash in murmurs as the assembled crowd tries to understand what they just bore witness to. Tensing up, waiting for the sudden backlash, you realize that the people around you think that you must be an extremely loyal and devout Christian, in order to get a priest to react this way.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.26: There's a hesitation in his voice, as he realizes that the entire dock is watching you both. He chooses his next words carefully.
