15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.23: As the boat starts to leave, you're about to turn and head home, until you see Ludovico run to the back of the boat. He starts shouting, loud enough for everyone to hear.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.22: True to his word, the captain casts off in three minutes, and soon it starts to leave Paris behind.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.21: With a downcast gaze, he boards his boat.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.19: You wonder to yourself, is this something lost, or is this just another reason to make sure you survive?
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.18: You stay on the dock for a while, and watch his boat disappear into the distance. Part of you wants to watch him for as long as you can, and another part of you simply isn't ready for the trials of getting home through all of this chaos.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.17: "Attention!" Shouts the captain of Ludovico's boat above the din of the crowd. "We're getting ready to cast off. Those who are not on this vessel in three minutes will be left behind." He says with the finality of someone who has actually abandoned passengers before.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.16: "I love you." He says, one last time before boarding his boat.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.14: You stop for a moment, not because you want to, but because you both need to beathe in order to live.

Those who are not on this vessel in three minutes will be left behind." He says with the finality of someone who has actually abandoned passengers before.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.11: It isn't a painful delusion, because you both know it isn't real. You feel at peace. You feel some of the danger of the last few days slip away, and gain a sort of clarity.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.10: You kiss with that passion which can only come from desperation. You drink deep of each other, unsure if this will be your last chance to ever do so.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.9:
The two of you sit on a the edge of the dock together. You laugh and joke, you talk about which books you've been reading recently. Together, you pretend that nothing is ever going to change.

You pretend as if this moment will last forever.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.8: Unable to restrain yourself further, you grab Ludovico by the wrist and lead him behind a nearby building for one last embrace.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.6: However, his joy quickly fades, as he remembers what you're both here to do.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.5: He pushes through the crowd to get to you. "Yvette! I'm so glad you came. You have no idea how much this means to me."
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.4: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.3: You spot Ludovico walking down from a gangplank, and peering into the crowd. When he spots you, his face blossoms into an exuberant smile.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.2:
Finally, you make it to the docks. Instead of the normal bevy of merchant vessels, you can only see barges taking on people, most of them laden with as many of their world possessions as possible. The barges will likely take these peopel via the river to a proper port city. Most people with a desire to leave Paris, and the means to do so, are leaving France altogether.

You wonder if they have the right idea.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.1: You've already lost a lot of time from having to double back and find new routes. It looks like new barricades are going up every day, and the streets simply don't feel safe anymore.
15364.Ludovico - Epilogue.node.0: You hurry south through the city, trying to make sure that you make it to the docks in time.

15264.Legacy.node.72: "... because my father had made powerful enemies when he left Saint Domingue..."
15264.Legacy.node.70: Trying to ignore the mental images of the lost souls that you so frequently discussed tonight, you trudge upstairs to record the details in your journal, before getting ready for bed.
15264.Legacy.node.69: With memories of the happy evening still in your mind, you head upstairs to record the details in your journal, before getting ready for bed.
15264.Legacy.node.68: "And you enjoyed yourself as well, madame?"
15264.Legacy.node.67: With that, Alexandre excuses himself and heads off into the night.
15264.Legacy.node.66: "I think Madame Decaux here is going to be a little more cautious when agreeing to mysterious invitations from now on, but otherwise I think things went well!" Alexandre jests.
15264.Legacy.node.65: "Bonsoir madame! Bonsoir monsieur! Did you enjoy your evening?"
15264.Legacy.node.64: The sun sets and with nightfall, he walks you home. You find Camille waiting for you outside.
15264.Legacy.node.63: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.62: His body is as still and powerful as a tree, but as you rest your head against his chest, you can hear his heart beating at a furious tempo.
15264.Legacy.node.61: Love is, of course, bigger than its grand romatnic gestures. The two of you spend the next hour watching the sunset, laughing and joking with each other. He regales with stories of daring that grow improbably with every telling.
15264.Legacy.node.60: (You have earned a lot of favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.59: Your lips meet. You fling your arms around his neck and he only holds you closer. Between throes of passion, your eyes open for but a moment, and you glimpse a single tear rolling down his cheek.
15264.Legacy.node.58: You wraps your arms around him and he hugs you close. Tightly and fiercely.
15264.Legacy.node.57: As you crane your neck to bring your lips closer to his, you feel one of his arms sweep behind your knees and he lifts towards himself, almost like a dancer's dip.
15264.Legacy.node.55: He loops his arm around your waist.
15264.Legacy.node.54: "Another day in the place that's been kinder to me than anywhere else in the world. It's given me freedom, education, excitement..."
15264.Legacy.node.53: You look to the horizon and realize that the sun is setting. You glimpse beautiful oranges and purples between the buildings of the Paris skyline.
15264.Legacy.node.52: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.51: (You have lost some favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.50: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.49: He laughs loudly. "Yvette, if that's nothing to you, I can't wait to see what you think a real favor for your friends is."
15264.Legacy.node.48: "I'm sorry, but you should be able to understand why I wasn't comfortable putting some of this in a letter. This has not been easy."
15264.Legacy.node.47: He gives you a theatrical bow "I am in your debt."
15264.Legacy.node.46: "Thank you again. I don't think I could have done that by myself."
15264.Legacy.node.45: You walk outside with him, and notice that the funeral party from before has also finished up. While they still look somber, you can tell that they're also ready to move forward with their lives.
15264.Legacy.node.44: "Yvette, I think we should be on our way."
15264.Legacy.node.43: He kneels down, and with a handkerchief, cleans the smudges of dirt from the headstone. "Farewell father. I shall not return."
15264.Legacy.node.42: He looks at you and grins. "And I am so fortunate, to have people with me, who could help me when I was lost."
15264.Legacy.node.41: "Today, I am Thomas-Alexandre Dumas. I am a man who will help the downtrodden. One who will use his might, in service of right."
15264.Legacy.node.40: He sighs contentedly, as if letting down a great weight. "But none of that matters..."
15264.Legacy.node.39: He leans back his head and shouts "I am Thomas-Alexandre Davy de la Pailleterie, true heir to the title of the Marquis de la Pailleterie!"
15264.Legacy.node.38: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.37: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.36: (You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.35: "I like that idea." He smiles thinly, eyes still fixed on the headstone.
15264.Legacy.node.34: "No." He replies flatly. "I cannot live selfishly. I cannot live, as he lived."
15264.Legacy.node.33: "You're absolutely right. I must fight for others. I must do the things he would have never thought to do."
15264.Legacy.node.32: "I've been trying to live up to a great legacy... that isn't great at all."
15264.Legacy.node.31: "I thought that I should honor his memory, but now I'm starting to think that's wrong too."
15264.Legacy.node.30: "He served in the army as well. I joined up to make him proud, but when he died I realized that there was nobody left to be proud of me."
15264.Legacy.node.29: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.28: You arrive at a gravestone. It's carved from fine marble, but already marred with dirth and soot. It says 'Marquis Alexandre Antoine Davy de la Pailleterie'. A series of battles are listed under the name.
15264.Legacy.node.27: "I wouldn't be here, with all of my advantages, if he hadn't condemned them to that suffering."
15264.Legacy.node.26: (You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.25: "... and because this all hapened nearly a decade ago!"
15264.Legacy.node.24: Seeing your confused expression, the anger leaves him, replaced only by melancholy. "The average lifespan of a working slave in Saint Domingue... is around ten years."
15264.Legacy.node.23: "What am I saying?" He growls, to himself more than anyone else. "It's not a feeling, it's an objective fact."
15264.Legacy.node.22: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.21: "... because they're thousands of miles away, where simple messages take months arrive."
15264.Legacy.node.20: "Yes, I do feel that," he sighs. "I'm glad you understand."
15264.Legacy.node.19: "That's true, I suppose. I never asked him for any of this." He admits.
15264.Legacy.node.18: "It's nice being your father's favorite, but sometimes..."
15264.Legacy.node.17: His next words are difficult, a creaking wheeze. "He sold my three siblings, and my mother. There was no policy set in place to buy them back. He never intended to see them again."
15264.Legacy.node.16: "I wasn't an only child, and my mother never made it to this country."
15264.Legacy.node.15: "... but when I said he sold me to afford his passage to France, I wasn't telling you the whole truth."
15264.Legacy.node.14: "Like so many little boys growing up, my father was my hero. A dashing rogue, a secret aristocrat hiding away with my mother in the distant mountains of a tropical paradise. He sacrificed so much, to give me everything."
15264.Legacy.node.13: Together, you walk through the open gates. Off, in one corner, you see a family gathered together for a funeral. You keep your distance from them, and in return they pay you no mind.
15264.Legacy.node.11: Taking a deep breath, he gestures to the cemetary gate nearby. "This... is where my father is buried."
15264.Legacy.node.10: "I see you chose to observe me before deciding to engage. I can certainly respect that. I admit, I would have done the same in your position. My letter wasn't as clear as it should have been."
15264.Legacy.node.9: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
15264.Legacy.node.8: "Ah, you're here! I'm so glad you came." He admits, with no small amount of relief.
15264.Legacy.node.7: Seeing no other way to get his attention, you playfully tap him on the shoulder.
15264.Legacy.node.6: He looks up at you and approaches. His face wearing the same stony expression of concern.
15264.Legacy.node.4: With his powerful strides, he still looks ever the man of action, even when he's worried. You feel as if you understand him a little better.
15264.Legacy.node.3: Hanging back, you watch him for a while. He paces back and forth in the street like a caged tiger, wearing an expression of deep concern.
15264.Legacy.node.2: You walk up to him with no hesitation, but he has still yet to notice you.
15264.Legacy.node.1: You spot Alexandre before he sees you. He looks pensive.
15264.Legacy.node.0: You draw your shawl a little closer as you're buffetted by another gust of wind. Checking the notes in your journal, you see that you're close to the graveyard where Alexandre wanted to meet you. However, you still have no idea what you're really here for.
15264.Legacy.link.73: "Have you tried to go back for them, to free them?"
15264.Legacy.link.72: "All in all, it was rather morbid, to be honest."
15264.Legacy.link.49: "I just wish you'd warned me what I was getting into."
15264.Legacy.link.48: "Please, I was glad to do it."
15264.Legacy.link.35: "Then be the man you always imagined your father to be. Be the better version."
15264.Legacy.link.34: "That doesn't matter. You must be your own person."
15264.Legacy.link.33: "Take the advantages he gave you, and use them to right his wrongs."
15264.Legacy.link.20: "You feel like you benefitted from their loss?"
15264.Legacy.link.19: "Alexandre, he's the one who made those decisions, not you."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.88: "However, I have my orders and I need to follow them. If I left now, the consequences wouldn't fall on me, but they would fall on my family."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.87: (You have lost quite a bit of favor with Ludovico)
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.86: "However, if you were to find your way to Rome, I would welcome you with open arms."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.85: "I promise this isn't the end. It's merely a delay."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.84: If you make it to the docks today, you'll be able to see him one last time.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.83: (You have gained quit a bit of peril)
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.82:
Is this risky? Yes. 

Will someone be suspicious of Ludovico's sudden change of heart? Yes. 

Is the situation in Paris dire enough for you to just sit idly by and let things play out by random chance? No. Not at all.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.81: You light a candle, and work delicately with a small knife to gently heat and remove Ludovico's seal from his old letter. You then carefully transplant his seal onto your new letter.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.80: (The Church's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution by quite a bit)
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.79: You look out your bedroom window, at a city in turmoil. You look down at Ludovico's note. Even with his hasty writing, his penmanship is immaculate.

17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.65:
You take out some new paper and a quill and write a new letter, mimicing his handwriting. This new letter has Ludovico completely changing his position, and  demanding that the Church immediately cease its current support for the Crown, and to put all of its power behind the Revolution instead.

You smirk, and take the time to admire some of your more evocative turns of phrase regarding innocent souls, and the 'true children of the Lord'.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.64:
You take out some new paper and a quill and write a new letter, mimicing his handwriting. This new letter is far stronger in its language, imploring the Church to intervene on the Crown's behalf wherever possible. 

You smirk, and take the time to admire some of your more evocative turns of phrase regarding loyalty and divine right.

17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.54:
Camille slowly peaks her head into the room, clutching a rolled up peice of paper, sealed in wax.

"Madame, I think Father Sidotti left something on the floor. It looks like a letter." She hands it to you.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.53: He steps close to you and puts his arms around your shoulders. "I promise this isn't the end. It's merely a delay."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.52:
Returning to his senses, he pulls a piece of paper from his bag and scribbles on it before handing it off to you. You see a pair of addresses on it. 

"The first one is the docks I'll be leaving from tonight. The second one is where I'll be staying in Rome. I'll write letters to you whenever I can."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.51: You're not sure how long you stand there, thinking about what just happened. About what this all means.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.50:
He pulls a piece of paper from his bag and scribbles on it before handing it off to you. You see a pair of addresses on it. 

"The first one is the docks I'll be leaving from tonight. The second one is where I'll be staying in Rome. I'll write letters to you whenever I can."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.49: With that, he kisses you tenderly on the cheek, grabs his bags and leaves.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.48:

17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.47: He stares at the floor and frowns. "Let's see... we can't leave on same ship together, as I'm not the only member of the clergy travelling on that vessel. It'd be too dangerous."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.46: (You have gained some favor with Ludovico)
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.44: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.43: "Now, I'm sorry, but I must leave. I have a few loose ends I need to tie up in Paris before I go."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.42:
He pulls a piece of paper from his bag and scribbles on it before handing it off to you. You see an address on it. 

"Those are the docks I'll be leaving from tonight."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.41: "I was afraid of that," he sighs. "I understand your reasons, but I was still dreading this possibility."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.40: He sighs with relief "I'm so glad to hear that."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.39: "Please tell me you're not willing to give up on them either."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.38: "You've shown me wonderful things, Yvette. Things that I'm not ready to give up on, just yet."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.37: "You have to understand, I never wanted to have to make this choice, but we don't always get to control the broad strokes of our own fate. Sometimes, all we can do is choose to confront it with grace."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.36: (You have gained quite of a bit of favor with Ludovico)
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.35: "There is nothing in this world I would like more than that."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.34: He gives you a smile, but it feels forced. "So, unless you find out how to talk your way into becoming the next Pope, I don't think this isn't going to change."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.33: "And, as much as they pushed me into this life, I still can't do something to hurt them."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.32: "But I know that wouldn't be right. I can't just abandon this now."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.31: He rubs the edge of one of this eyes. "I haven't slept properly in days. I just lay awake, thinking about this. Sometimes, I think about discarding my vows altogether.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.30: As if exhaling a great breath, he slumps forward. "I wish I had a better way to tell you this, but I've been recalled to Rome by the Vatican."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.29: You hear the door open, and the muffled murmurings of Hansel conversing with whoever it is.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.27: She sighs, and looks at the floor. "Believe me, I don't want to."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.26:
He doesn't say anything for a while. He just stares at you, and only you.

Like you're the only thing in all of creation.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.25: "They've read my findings, and they want me to board a ship out of Paris, tonight."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.24: As if exhaling a great breath, he slumps forward. "Well Yvette, I wish I had a better way to tell you this, but I've been recalled to Rome by the Vatican."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.23:
She leaves and after a few rushed minutes, you're ready to receive company. You're not perfect, but you're certainly presentable.

Of course, your standards for 'presentable' are admittedly more stringent than most, but that's neither here nor there.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.22: "Anyway madame, I'll take Father Sidotti to the sitting room for some tea and refreshments. That should give you a little time to get ready."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.21: "Of course, I told them that was ridiculous! After all, I should be here with you."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.20: "Would you believe some of them even asked me to come with them? They said it's not safe to be in Paris anymore."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.19: "Now that I'm here, I suppose I should tell you the news."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.18: He grits his teeth and whispers "You must have the patience of a saint."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.17: Ludovico pauses for a moment to compose himself. "I'll take your word for it."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.16: "Do you... do you live with that? Do you listen to that every day?"
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.15: Right before the door shuts, you catch a glimpse of Camille giving you a knowing wink.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.14: "Th- that would be an ecumenical matter." Ludovico desperately replies, as he manages to get her out of the bedroom and into the hallway. "Please take any further questions to your parish priest."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.13: "...but if all the animals started in the garden of Eden with us, how did they get out? Were they supposed to stay there, or were they allowed to leave whenever they wanted to? Did all the animals eat the forbidden fruit too, and they didn't write it down because animals can't read?"
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.12: As you settle into place, Ludovico finally makes his way in. He's trailed by Camille, who is still peppering the poor priest with questions at a breakneck pace.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.11:

Of course, your standards for 'presentable' are admittedly more stringent than most, but that's neither here nor there.

17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.9: "If you need time to get ready, I can stall him with silly questions!"
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.8: "Which makes sense. The city's been a little tense lately, and I have some friends who've already left for the countryside."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.7: "I don't know, but he's carrying a lot of bags with him. He looks like he's ready to go somewhere."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.6: "I don't think he'd be here this early, if it wasn't important, madame."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.5: "Certainly madame! I've already taken him to the sitting room for some tea and refreshments. That should give you a little time to get ready."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.4: "Father Sidotti is here to see you. He looks nervous."
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.3: Camille carefully enters your room, shutting the door gently behind her.
17120.Le Dévot de L'Amour.node.2: You hear the door open, and the muffled murmurings of Camille conversing with whoever it is.

15538.La Maîtresse de Commande.node.95: Getting down on hand and knee, you stoke the embers in the fireplace back to life. One at a time, you feed Madame Gazel's notes into the flames, then muddle the ashes afterwards. Nobody will suspect a thing, she'll simply be unprepared for a meeting, and unable to make herself heard.
15538.La Maîtresse de Commande.node.94: While it's possible to alter the tone of her notes, you could never switch their political sentiments entirely. You cannot have her adding her support to the Crown, which means there's only one solution.
15538.La Maîtresse de Commande.node.92:
(The Bourgeosie has moved towards the Revolution significantly)
(You have gained some peril)
15538.La Maîtresse de Commande.node.91: Discreetly and carefully, you pull a pen from the ink well and start to alter her notes. 17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.node.4:
Elisabeth just laughs, astonished.

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.node.2: "I think I've been going about this all wrong."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.node.1: "About how I've tried to keep them at bay by feigning indifference."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.node.0: After your rendezvous, Elisabeth offers to walk you home. She's walking closer to you than usual, and generally seems more upbeat.
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.59: "Are you sure it's a good idea to dignify them with a response?"
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.58: "Are you sure it's a good idea to dignify them with a response?"
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.57: "Are you sure it's a good idea to dignify them with a response?"
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.56: "Are you sure it's a good idea to dignify them with a response?"
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.55: "Are you sure it's a good idea to dignify them with a response?"
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.42: "Things didn't go as well as I'd hoped."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.41: "It's been a productive evening, my ambitions draw closer."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.40: "Camille, it was filled with the best kind of romance."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.35: "That's really sweet, but I don't think we should risk it."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.25: "Has she considered taking a softer stance against the Revolutionaries?" <Credibilty Check Icon>
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.24: "The Bourgeoisie are the ones paying for everything, try to keep them happy."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.23: "Has she considered the Military? You can't rule France without an army."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.22: "What about the Church? They've always supported the Crown in the past."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.15: "This is your revelation, I've just been observing."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.10: "Are you sure it's a good idea to go on the offensive like that?"
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.6: "Are you sure it's a good idea to dignify them with a response?"
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.2: "Oh God, what happened? Do you need me to slap someone? Because, I'm ready."
17538.La Madame des Beaux Arts.link.0: "... and what do you think now?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.64: He takes your hand in his own. "Though some are certainly smarter than others."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.63: "I have plenty of allies here, even if they aren't always vocal."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.62: "To prioritize one's own comfort like this... it's so selfish. Are we no better than beasts?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.61: With that, he turns and leaves, disappearing almost instantly into the crowd.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.60: "You should write me soon. I'd love to meet you alone, where we can be away from all these half-hearted types." He whispers, gesturing dismissively at some of the other guests.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.59: He pulls a clean, white handkerchief from his pocket and hands it to you. His name and address have been embroidered into it in red thread.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.58: You do your best to maintain a low profile while you search for you next engagement at the party. Associating with someone like that may be necessary, but it rarely attracts the right sort of attention.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.57: Swept up in a heady rush of emotion, you float about the party, searching for your next engagement.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.56: Alone, you look down at the handkerchief in your hand.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.55: (You can now go on rendezvous with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.54: However, you do notice that an address has been embroidered into it, in red thread. It might be very useful if you wanted to write him, or perhaps meet up with Antoine in the future.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.53: He sighs. "It's true. I originally trained in oratory, but my real passion in school was poetry and theater. There's just something special about fiction, myths, and legends."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.52: (You have gained some favor with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.51: "With fiction, we can show people the truth in ways that even the best rhetoric can never accomplish. We can convince them to see the truth themselves."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.50:
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
(You can now go on rendezvous with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.49: Before you can reply, he turns quickly on his heel and leaves. While you're puzzling over what's just transpired, you notice a white handkerchief fell out of his pocket and onto the floor. You pick it up, and are thankful to find that it hasn't been used.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.48: You notice that he's started to shift unsteadily on his feet, as if something is agitating him. Suddenly, he cuts the conversation short with a curt upward nod. "I must go, Madame. There is something pressing for me to take care of."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.47: He smiles intently and says "Wait just a moment. I have something for you."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.46: The two of you chat together for a little while longer, isolated from the crowd.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.45: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.44: (You have gained some favor with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.43: (You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.42: "If I ignore the real problems, I'll be just as useless as that lot. I'll be just another beast waiting to be led, content to beg for table scraps from the powerful and call it progress."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.41: He frowns, then smirks, then smiles. "Perhaps you're right."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.40: "I know you're right, but I'll be damned if I ever stop hating it. These are the very people who have the the ability to make the greatest changes. Instead they're content to beg for table scraps from the powerful and call it progress."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.39: "I simply can't stand it. How they all just choose passivity?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.38: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.37: "I'm surprised that you asked me at all. Most just write me off as a zealot. I think that delusion makes them comfortable." He shrugs before he smiles to you. "I like that you're willing to be braver than that."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.36: He sneers at the now distant crowd. "They want liberty and equality, as long as they get to keep all the things that make them powerful and secure. I have no such obstacles."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.35: "We all view the world through panes of glass tinted by our own experiences. The truth is always obscured from us in some way. Yet, if you give someone an idea wrapped in fiction, they're willing to set down that glass, because they don't think what your saying is real."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.34: He stops, frowns, shakes his head as if to clear it, but frowns again.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.33: (You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.32: He pauses, considering his answer carefully and quickly while he examines your expression. "I have less to lose than they do. They deny the truth of what needs to be done, because most of them are still in positions of wealth, government, or cultural power."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.31: He scowls at your question. "Really? That's what you gleaned from that entire conversation? That I've written a few plays?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.30: "Of course that's how I feel!" He snarls at you. "Have you been paying any attention to what's been going on?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.29: He shoots one last dagger-like glare at his opponent. "This isn't over. It's not over at all."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.28: Slowly, the crowd disperses, leaving the two of you alone together.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.27: As this argument runs its course, the crowd slowly disperses, leaving the two of you alone together.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.25: The crowd murmurs in approval, appreciative of your ability to restore some calm to the situation.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.24: The two continue to 'debate' each other, but it quickly turns into yet another squabbling argument. Like all arguments, it simply goes in circles, with no actual resolution in sight.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.23:
(You've lost a little favor with Antoine)
(You've lost a little credibility)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.22: (You've gained a little favor with Antoine)
16264.Internal Divisions.node.21: "If it pleases you, then yes, I will walk with you."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.20: "Thank you for your help. I was very close to losing my temper."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.19: With that, he departs, leaving you and Antoine together.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.17: "People like you are a danger. Not just to the Crown, but to everyone." He hisses at you.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.16: He grumbles to himself for a while before looking at you. "What is it?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.15: With a sigh of disgust, Antoine storms away from the conversation. You follow after him, but can't help but notice that nobody else attempts to join you.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.14: The crowd disperses, muttering agreeably amongst themselves. However, the constitutionalist remains, staying just to glare fixedly at you.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.11: "Are you mad? I'm not backing down from this patronizing miscreant. Not now, and not ever!"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.10: Slowly, his face softens, and he sighs.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.9: Still in the throes of bubbling anger, Antoine shoots you a vicious glare.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.8: Antoine turns to you, surprised. "Really? You're really going to agree with this tepid nonsense?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.7: Emboldened, Antoine steps closer to his opponent. "You'll see. Soon, the Crown will reveal its true colors. Soon, they'll show just how afraid of the people they really are. Soon, blood will need to be shed and you'll see how right I am."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.6: "I know that one does not make revolutions by half measures."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.5: "What you want is simply not how things are done in a civilized country. I'm a lawyer with a wealth of experience, I know what I'm talking about. As far as I can tell, you're what? A half-succesful playwright? What do you know?"
16264.Internal Divisions.node.4: "You really think you can just vote our problems away? If you play by the nobility's rules, you'll only get an order that they want. The name of our governance will change, but nothing will improve for anyone."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.3: "The second we lose order, everything breaks down." The man replies, as if he were talking to a child. "If we make our case correctly in the General Assembly, we can convince the King that it's in everyone's best interests to adopt a constitutional monarchy. It worked in England, and it can work here."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.2: "No, you don't understand! How can you be so caught up on civility and due process when our own people are suffering this very instant."
16264.Internal Divisions.node.1: On the other side of the room, you spot that intense young man from before. In fact, he's looking especially tense in his conversation with another guest. They've raised their voices and have already attracted a crowd.
16264.Internal Divisions.node.0: You stroll about the party taking in the atmosphere. It's boisterous, lively and bohemian.
16264.Internal Divisions.link.62: "Uncompromising ideologues like him only get more dangerous with time."
16264.Internal Divisions.link.61: "It's rare to find a man that burns with such passion."
16264.Internal Divisions.link.45: "I'm afraid that if you keep dwelling on this, you'll drive yourself mad.""
16264.Internal Divisions.link.44: "They're not all choosing it. You're not alone."
16264.Internal Divisions.link.43: "Choosing means being uncertain. They'd rather keep what they have."
16264.Internal Divisions.link.36: "Antoine, you're so much more dedicated than the others, why is that?"
16264.Internal Divisions.link.35: "Antoine, you're so much more dedicated than the others, why is that?"
16264.Internal Divisions.link.34: "I had no idea you were a playwright. Have you written anything I've heard of?"
16264.Internal Divisions.link.33: "I had no idea you were a playwright. Have you written anything I've heard of?"
16264.Internal Divisions.link.32: "Do you really feel so strongly about all of this?"
16264.Internal Divisions.link.31: "Do you really feel so strongly about all of this?"
16264.Internal Divisions.link.8: "Let's not let our tempers turn us against ourlves. Antoine, let's step away for a moment."
16264.Internal Divisions.link.7: "Antoine, maybe he's right. You can't change laws by breaking them."
16264.Internal Divisions.link.6: "He's right! We can't just expect the nobility to willingly give up their advantages over us."
17828.Honorade's Letter.node.5: Using your map, it doesn’t take long to figure out where this particular fountain is. In fact, you could visit it today if you like.
17828.Honorade's Letter.node.4: ‘Please meet me there as soon as you can, and I will share what I’ve learned. Bien affectueusement, Honorade’
17828.Honorade's Letter.node.3: Honorade goes on to describe a particular fountain deep in the city. She’d like to meet with you in secret, as she’s worried about someone intercepting the letter. Is your enemy really that powerful?
17828.Honorade's Letter.node.2: ‘Chère Yvette, It was truly a pleasure to have your company in the ride home from that otherwise dreary party. Still, I seethe at the thought that our host was allowed to ridicule you. In front of all those people, no less! Such a thing must not go unpunished. Which is why I have been digging in some rather… dark corners of the city. I have some information that you will find quite interesting.’
17828.Honorade's Letter.node.1: Opening it up, you find a letter from Honorade, written in flowing cursive. It might be your imagination, but you think you can smell the slightest hint of perfume on the letter.
17828.Honorade's Letter.node.0: The next morning, you find a letter on your nightstand. Camille must have brought it in while you were still asleep. It’s sealed with a rich purple wax seal, bearing the initials “H.G.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.27: Honorade helps you down from the carriage, and with a crack of René’s whip, her carriage departs and winds its way into the city. You stop to think about this new information. A mystery servant who left Maximin’s employment suddenly, and under murky circumstances. It seems fruitful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.26: Honorade signals to René and the carriage begins to roll to a stop. Pulling back the curtains for a moment, you realize that you’re already outside your home. “While we must unfortunately part ways,” Honorade says as René open the door. “I wish you the best of luck in your quest for vengeance.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.25: “Given what I saw from you that night, I have a feeling that you and I share a flare for the dramatic. I expect that whatever you choose to do will be suitably poetic, considering what he’s done to you.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.24: “I like you, and now that I actually know something about him, I hate Maximin.” Honorade pauses to take a sip of her water. “The idea of you bringing him to some sort of justice is extremely satisfying.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.23: “Of course, you could always just give up, but I don’t think that sort of thing suits you.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.22: “Now you pursue this lead, hatch a plan, and get your revenge. What that requires is really up to you. I’m more than happy to provide you with information, but I think you’ll be better served if you handle the rest yourself.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.21: “Oh my, yes.” She answers, making no attempt to hide how much she is relishing the current situation.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.19: “A servant left Maximin’s service, but keeps their reasons a secret… if that presumptuous rodent has a weakness, then this is it.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.18: “Most of those that left his service were quite vocal about their reasons for leaving, usually citing things like long hours, skipped wages, and other issues. However, I noticed there was one servant who left completely silently. I wouldn’t have given it a second though, if all the others weren’t so loud.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.17: “Speaking of cruelty I started looking into Maximin’s household. If you want to learn something about someone, see how they treat those closest to them. That’s when I discovered that Maximin’s estate hires and fires servants at a prodigious rate.” She pauses to reach into the pockets of her dress and hands you a list of names, presumably of the aforementioned servants.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.16: “While I have nothing against the revolutionary nationalists, per se, I often get the feeling that denouncing those with less informed or extreme views is their preferred way of accruing political currency.” Honorade pauses to stare out the window for a moment. “I prefer money, it seems less cruel.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.15: “It’s possible that you’re more forgiving than myself, but the thought of what happened to you that night still makes me livid. Starting off, I barely knew anything about Maximin, but the more I started learning about him, the less I liked. Knowing what I know now, it doesn’t surprise me that he would be so absolutely vile to you.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.14: You take her hand and get into the carriage. As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive gloom within.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.13: “Besides, this dress is silk and I’m not going to risk falling into a fountain with it on,” she continues and offers her hand to you. Judging from her tone, you get the feeling that disagreeing with her logic won’t get you anywhere.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.12:
Honorade sips at her glass of water and spends a few moments simply looking you over. You’re not really sure what she’s looking for. After a while, she seems satisfied, and continues.

“Since you’re here, I’ll assume that you read my letter.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.11: Honorade follows you inside and takes up her normal seat across from you. With a silent signal to René, the carriage takes off.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.10: As with before, it takes a few moments for your eyes to adjust to the oppressive gloom within.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.9: Honorade laughs with an unexpected snort. “I’m sure that it’s not. However, anyone who wishes to spy upon us already knows who we are. The very least we can do is discuss this in a place where they can’t listen in.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.8: “Je t’en prie,” she replies, before offering her hand and helping you into the carriage.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.7: “Please step inside, I would rather not share this information while in public.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.6: Honorade steps down from the carriage. “Bonjour Yvette, I hope you haven’t been waiting long.”
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.5: After only a few minutes of waiting by the fountain, Honorade’s carriage pulls up and René, Honorade’s trust coachman steps down off of his box to open the door for her. It’s the middle of the day, but the inside of the luxuriously decorated carriage is still shrouded in gloom.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.4: You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with a glamorous widow to learn the secrets of your most hated enemies. If anything, they must have been some good decisions.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.3: Looking around, you can’t spot Honorade anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that she’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.2: Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.1: Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you decided to dress in darker clothes, and stuck to comfortable walking shoes.
17990.Honorade's Lead.node.0: You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Honorade mentioned in her letter to you.
17990.Honorade's Lead.link.8: “Are you sure this carriage is… discreet?”
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.8: Fanning yourself with the letter to drive away some of the summer heat, you can't help but notice the smell of her perfume on the letter again. You idly realize that you could go there today if you wished.
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.7: (La Matresse de Commande is now available to visit in the Paris map)
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.5: 'Here, there will be no chance of us being interrupted. I await your arrival.'
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.4: 'Ch볥 Yvette, As of late, I've been feeling even even better than I did at the beginning of our last fateful encounter. My gardens are doing especially well, and I'd love for you to see them.'
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.3: You open it, and begin the read the letter. The flowing cursive of her handwriting is both beautiful and familiar.
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.2: There's a letter on the bedside table. Judging from the rich purple of the wax seal, as well as the scent of the perfume, it was definitely sent by Madame Gazel.
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.1: Just as you wonder what Camille has prepared for your breakfast, you notice the faint smell of perfume. It's both floral and bitter.
13556.Honorade's Invitation.node.0: You wake up and stretch languidly. You slept well last night and already feel prepared to conquer yet another day.

It seems like this knowledge could be useful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.

13210.Honorade's Clue.node.19: “That gaudy wretch is hiding something about her money. Knowing what she’s like in public, anything she wants to hide must be dark indeed.”
13210.Honorade's Clue.node.18:
“Thirty years is a long time for a single person, but that’s not how the aristocratic families see the world. The Gazel family’s fortune is forty years old and we’re still derided as ‘new money’” Honoroade pauses to sip her water and sneer at some unseen adversary. 

“As if recent success was something to be ashamed of. To put it simply, why would her family pretend their fortune is older than it really is?”
13210.Honorade's Clue.node.17: “During those meetings, I asked about Marcelle’s family investments, and pretended to be very impressed with whatever they told me. However, in that whole time, I couldn’t find evidence that any of her family’s investments were older than thirty years or so.”
13210.Honorade's Clue.node.16: “So, I did what anyone else would do. I held meetings with as many of her business partners as I could, claiming to be interested in investing my husband’s fortune. They, of course, fell all over themselves in order to meet with me and try to part me from my late husband’s money.”
13210.Honorade's Clue.node.15: “It’s possible that you’re more forgiving than myself, but the thought of what happened to you that night still makes me livid. At first, I admittedly knew very little about Marcelle, but the more I started learning about her, the less I liked. Now that I’ve gotten to know her better, I’m not surprised at all that she would be so… contemptible.”

16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.19: Glancing around, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. "Mon dieu Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!"
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.18: "I'm sure he's fine Madame," Camille replies with a tone of voice that doesn't fill you with confidence. "I'm sorry to tell you this, but I haven't seen Monsieur Armand in days. I was hoping he was with you."
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.17:
She’s not wrong. You’re not certain how you’re still upright and awake right now. 
“I’ve already made up your bed Madame, please go inside and let me take care of this.” Camille insists.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.16: While you’re still processing this latest disappointment, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. “Mon Dieu, Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!”
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.15: You flop down on a nearby couch, open your diary, and start to write. You’re tired, disappointed, and perhaps abandoned, but writing things down always helps you make sense of a situation.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.14: You take your diary and leave the heavy lifting to Camille. The inside of the house isn’t much better than the outside. Camille keeps the place tidy, but she can only do such much. Still, you don’t care about that right now, you’re just happy to have a roof over your head.

16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.11: “I’m sure he’s fine Madame,” Camille replies with a tone of voice that doesn’t fill you with confidence. Glancing around, Camille seems to notice your mountain of luggage for the first time. “Mon Dieu, Madame! Did you carry this all yourself? You must be exhausted!”
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.10: Eyeing her worn shoes, you have a feeling the rats didn’t go quietly.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.9: “Impossible, Madame! I’ve taken care of all the rats myself.” Camille replies, emphasizing her point with a playful stomp of her foot.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.8: “I… I was hoping that he was with you.” Camille replies hesitantly. “I haven’t seen him in days.”
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.7: “Ah, bonsoir! I assume you must be Madame Yvette! My name is Camille, Monsieur Armand told me to expect you.”
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.6: Calling the house ‘rustic’ would imply that you were out in the country, not in the center of a city. The neighborhood is nice enough, but you’re worried that if you breathe too hard on the building, it’ll fall over. A well kept woman in the attire of a maid opens the door and approaches you.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.4: You’re getting close to the address. Armand never described his living conditions much, but he’s the son of a Baron and his family was always well to-do, especially compared to yours. You’ve spent a lot of time in that carriage wondering about the home you’d spend your new life in.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.3: You’re overseeing a grand salon, surrounded by poets, musicians, scientists, philosophers, and artists. You are elegant, sophisticated, and respected.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.2: For a brief moment, you’re not a country girl dragging luggage through the streets. You’re the person you feel that you are, when you close your eyes, alone.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.1:
It’s the middle of the night, but the street is still teeming with life. The light from the windows and the street lamps sparkle like the stars. You’re tired and your feet hurt, but still, you can’t help but smile.

This is it. This is Paris. No matter what happens, you’re still here.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.node.0: After waiting around for a few hours, you leave the Orphan’s Feast, dragging your small mountain of luggage behind you. After all, the coach was only hired to take you to the tavern. Armand may not have been waiting for you like he said he would, but you memorized his address from all of the times you wrote it on your letters to him.
16654.Home, Sweet Home.link.19: “Uh… thank you Camille. Do you think Armand’s alright?”
16654.Home, Sweet Home.link.12: “He has a lot of explaining to do.”
16654.Home, Sweet Home.link.11: "Uh... thank you Camille. Do you think Armand's alright?"
16654.Home, Sweet Home.link.10: “Fine. When I’m done, Armand is simply going to wish the rats had eaten him.”
16654.Home, Sweet Home.link.8: "Is this where he lives? Oh God, the rats in there ate him, didn't they?"
16654.Home, Sweet Home.link.7: "Merci Camille, please take me to Armand."

19222.Deconstructive Criticism.node.3:
Taking a moment to acknowledge you with a nod, the painter returns to her conversation. Her reply is calm, almost bored. 

"My clients dress however they wish for their portraits. My role is merely to capture them as they are in their lives. Is it wrong that so many women wish to look like her Majesty?"
19222.Deconstructive Criticism.node.2: "-and furthermore, it must even be obvious to you that your work peaked at the 1783 salon. Why else would all of your portraits of women look the same after that?"
19222.Deconstructive Criticism.node.1:
Before you can think of an acceptable retort, he pivots on his heel and marches from the conversation with his nose held high.

(You have lost a little credibility)

You happen across a man with an arrogant air about him, talking to a woman. Well, it would be more accurate to say that he's talking at her.

14908.Courting Controversy.node.55: You can sense a tension in the air, and it feels like she has something on her mind.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.54: "Oh, who is this delight, Yvette?" Elisabeth asks with a giggle.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.53: "Later on, my career was stalled. The members of L'Académie were blocking my membership. I ran out of options, so I asked the Queen for a favor."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.52: She stutters for a moment at your insistence, trying to weigh her options.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.51: Her eyes glisten, wet. "They took it down on the first day of the show. I thought my career was over."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.50: "I heard it over and over again. 'The Queen made a mistake'."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.49: "I'll remember the 1783 Salon for the rest of my life. I made two paitings. 'Peace Bringing Back Abundance' was there to show I could do more than portraits, but my real focus was 'Marie en Chemise'. I poured my heart into that painting. It was relaxed, calm and kind. It was the Marie I knew. It was the Marie I wanted to show the world."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.48:
She gives you a weak smile that's trying to be strong. "Thanks Yvette, but if should say the whole thing. I think this is good for me."

(You've gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
14908.Courting Controversy.node.46:
With your goodbyes said, you head upstairs and prepare yourself for bed. 

It was a good night, and you feel like you've managed to push events in a very helpful direction.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.45:
After a few minutes of the three of you trading jokes and raised eyebrows, it all winds down enough for you to excuse yourself. With your goodbyes said, you head upstairs and prepare yourself for bed. 

It was a good night, and you feel like you've managed to push events in a very helpful direction.

14908.Courting Controversy.node.43:
Followed by raucous laughter.

14908.Courting Controversy.node.40:

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)

14908.Courting Controversy.node.34:
The rest of the walk home continues in an awkward silence.

After what feels like an eternity, you arrive home.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.33: "Just a maid of all works, madame! Can I get either of you anything?"
14908.Courting Controversy.node.32: You arrive at home, and Camille greets you both with her usual cheer. "Bonsoir mesdames!"
14908.Courting Controversy.node.31:
"Thank you. I haven't been focusing on what's really important."

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
[The Crown has gained a medium amount of power]
14908.Courting Controversy.node.30: "It was L'Académie that hated my painting, not Marie. I put my heart into something for a friend, and she loved it. That's what matters."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.29:
"If this is a joke, it's not a very tasteful one."

(You have lost quite a bit of favor with Elisabeth)
14908.Courting Controversy.node.28:
"That's a great idea, Yvette! I'm going to reach out to some of them soon!"

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
[The Crown has lost a medium amount of power]
[The Revolution has gained a medium amount of power]
14908.Courting Controversy.node.27:
Elisabeth stares at you, mouth agape. 

"Are you serious, Yvette? I've already hurt Marie, I'm not going to make things even worse."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.26: "That might work." Elisabeth says, hesitantly. "The revolutionaries would appreciate my more relaxed and natural aesthetic. In fact, many of them have already rejected L'Académie's views on art, so I wouldn't have to try pleasing people that already hate me."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.24:
She sniffs and wipes the tears from her face.

"Maybe, you're right..."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.23: "I wasn't good enough to do it on my own."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.22: "My rival, Adélaïde Labille-Guiard, became a member that same year. No connections at court, no back room dealing. One of the only other women in that entire academy and she earned it."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.21: "By then Marie had been rejected enough times to be sick of politics and intriques. So, instead she spent her efforts making a simple world of leisure in that chateau. Like a little island isolated from the rest of France."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.20: "Instead I met Marie and her friends at Le Petit Trianon, and joined them in their leisure. I saw them as themselves, not as the masks they wore at court."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.19: "I had a good reputation, and I'd painted nobility before, even a few relatives of the Queen, but those were formal paintings. I would show up, chat with them a little, and try to capture the essence of someone I didn't even know. Marie was something else entirely."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.17: "A few years later, I painted another painting of her, something with her children. I made what the academy wanted to see. More austere, more appropriate, something befitting the mother of the king's children. Since then, Marie and I have lost touch."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.16: "Marie never questioned my motives. She didn't even think about it. She just did it. Suddenly, I was a member." Elisabeth says with a confused shrug.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.15:
"We became friends of a sort."

Elisabeth turns her eyes away from you and to the ground.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.14: Elisabeth laughs "She could never stay on key, but that wasn't important."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.13: "Courtiers spent their lives scheming and lobbying to see Marie-Antoinette, Queen of France and mother of the nation. I got to know the real Marie, gentle and considerate. We would sing duets together after our painting sittings."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.12: A duo of tears roll down her cheeks. "But it wasn't. My infamy only brought me more clients, and the common people loved it. Marie was more damaged by the scandal than I was."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.11: "I was surrounded by all these men, these master artists, whose work I admired. I had to listen to them tear it to pieces. That my portrait was scandalous. That it was insulting. That it was unbecoming of the Queen."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.9: She pauses, for a moment, as if she's not sure if she should continue.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.7: "But Marie loved my work. I asked her for a favor, she asked the King. Suddenly, I was a member." She says with a confused shrug.
14908.Courting Controversy.node.6: "I'd spend the day relaxing with with Marie, Polignac, Rose, and the Queen's other favorites in Le Petit Trianon, only a stone's throw from Versailes. No court, no rituals, no massive ball gowns." She sighs "Just us women. Free to enjoy ourselves on our terms."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.5: Elisabeth sighs "They didn't like me. My husband, Jean, is an art dealer, and said it was a 'conflict of interest'. What was I supposed to do, divorce him?"
14908.Courting Controversy.node.4: "My heart nearly lept out of my chest when I got the invitation."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.3: "Oui, L'Académie Royale de Peinture et de Sculpture... the most important art institution in France. I spent years trying to get in, but could never quite make it."
14908.Courting Controversy.node.1: The artist glances at you for a moment "Did I ever tell you what it was like to paint the Queen?"
14908.Courting Controversy.node.0:
After your day together, Elisabeth decides to walk you home. You sense that she feels much more comfortable with you now. 

(You have gained a little favor with Elisabeth)
14908.Courting Controversy.link.47: "It's alright if you don't want to talk about it."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.46: "Have you considered reaching out to the nationalists? They might accept you." <Credibility Check>
14908.Courting Controversy.link.45: "Elisabeth, you'll never heal this hurt with silence. Reach out to the Queen, as a friend."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.35: "You two seem to be getting along quite well. Should I be worried?"
14908.Courting Controversy.link.34: "I'm sorry to cut this short, but I am exhausted. I must retire for the evening."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.33: "Nothing for now Camille. Elisabeth, thank you, this was a great night."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.22: "Maybe this is a sign you don't belong there. Have you considered talking to the nationalists?" <Credibility Check>
14908.Courting Controversy.link.21: "The Queen never turned against you. Reach out to her again, as a friend."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.20: "This isn't your fault. Those guys hated on you because they didn't want a woman in their midst."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.19: "This isn't your fault. Those guys hated on you because they didn't want a woman in their midst."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.18: "This isn't your fault. Those boors just couldn't tolerate a woman in their special club."
14908.Courting Controversy.link.1: "I know she loved your work. Is that why she pushed for your membership to L'Académie?"
18676.Coffee Run.node.22: Out of options, you part ways and head home. Things didn't work out today, but perhaps they'll go more smoothly tomorrow.
18676.Coffee Run.node.20: Eventually, the day winds down and you head home. You're tired, but glad that things managed to work out.
18676.Coffee Run.node.19: "Thanks again for your help." Marguerite says to you for the umpteenth time as she passes you during one of your deliveries.
18676.Coffee Run.node.18:
The cafe waitress shrugs. "Don't worry madame, I'll think of something." 

Her eyes don't portray the same optimism as her words.
18676.Coffee Run.node.17: (You have gained a decent amount of credibility)
18676.Coffee Run.node.16: Someone jokingly calls you two 'The Angels of Steam'. The nickname sticks, at least for the day.
18676.Coffee Run.node.15: You're not exactly sure how you get caught up in everything, but you're soon helping Marguerite ferry kettles of boiling water back and forth from the cafe for a few hours. It's exhausting, but you're met with a cheer from the patrons every time the two of you burst in the door with a new pair of kettles.
18676.Coffee Run.node.14: Someone in the crowd hurriedly escorts you into a tavern where they work. Immediately, Margueritte sets up her kettles on a roaring stove.
18676.Coffee Run.node.13: Perhaps there's something else that you can do...
18676.Coffee Run.node.11: Your impassioned plea falls on deaf ears, as people in the crowd simply shuffle by. Admittedly, it is an odd situation, but you still curse the strangers for their inaction. It doesn't take long for you to notice that some of the people nearby have even grown suspicious of you.
18676.Coffee Run.node.10: Hearing your impassioned plea, someone in the crowd hurriedly escorts you into a tavern where they work. Immediately, Margueritte sets up her kettles on a roaring stove.
18676.Coffee Run.node.8: All the same, she smiles warmly to you "Thank you for trying. That's already more than anyone else here has done."
18676.Coffee Run.node.7: "The stove in the Cafe is broken and I have a lot of thirsty customers!"
18676.Coffee Run.node.6: It's amazing how indecisive everyone in the crowd was, until money entered the equation.
18676.Coffee Run.node.5: Some members of the crowd turn to listen as you make an impassioned plea for this poor working woman beset by misfortune. She needs no money, no supplies, merely a stove with which to heat her water!
18676.Coffee Run.node.4: She's happy to hear this until you start giving her directions. Her face falls and replies. "Non madame, I'm sorry but that won't work. You live too far away. The water will be cold by the time I reach the cafe. It has to be somewhere nearby!"
18676.Coffee Run.node.3:
"Does anyone have a stove I can use? This is an emergency!" It's Margueritte, from the cafe! She's holding a bunch of kettles and looks absolutely frantic. 

Nobody is rushing to help, in fact they're trying to stay out of her way.
18676.Coffee Run.node.2: Behind you and to the right, you hear a commotion, you turn and spot a familiar face.
18676.Coffee Run.node.1:
You are momentarily lost in a reverie imagining what life would be like if coffee tasted as good as it smelled. Would we ever drink anything else? 

It would be a jittery world, indeed.
18676.Coffee Run.node.0: Wandering around town, you realize that you're near Cafe Principe, but you can't smell the familiar scent of roasting coffee beans. Which is a quite a shame, because the scent is absolutely heavenly.
18676.Coffee Run.link.24: "I'm sorry Marguerite, I can't think of anything else."
18676.Coffee Run.link.14: "I will pay ten livres to the first person that lets us borrow their stove for the day!"
18676.Coffee Run.link.13: "Please! Can anyone let us use your stove? She needs it for work!"
18676.Coffee Run.link.6: "I will pay ten livres to the first person that lets us borrow their stove for the day!"
18676.Coffee Run.link.5: "Please! Can anyone let us use your stove? She needs it for work!"
18676.Coffee Run.link.4: "Marguerite, over here! Why don't you use the stove at my home?"
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.188: "But if you must know, you would say Ludovico è molto intelligente."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.187: "It's a bit rude, but it feels good for you. You always seem to be in the right place at the right time."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.186: "However, I would also say that the pleasure has been all mine."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.185: He clears his throat. "Uhm, if you really wanted to say that, all you'd have to say is-"
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.184: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.183: "Oh..." Ludovico flushes red as your question really dawns on him.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.182: "Puttana means, 'whore'." He says, trying to keep his laughter under control. "And 'figlio de puttana' means 'son of a whore'. It's a very useful word, you see."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.181: You have to admit, he's very fun to toy with.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.180: (You have gained quite a bit of favor with Ludovico, if that wasn't already obvious)
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.179: (You have gained a good amount of favor with Ludovico)
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.178: You chat together for another hour or so, but you quickly realize how drained all of that sneaking about has left you, and get ready to leave.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.177: (You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.176: "Ah yes, that does sound reasonable." He says with an embarassed smile. "We've had enough close calls tonight as is."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.175: Ludovico tenses up the moment your lips meet, but slowly his tension melts away. He places a hand in the middle of your back and brings you closer.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.174: "Yvette, could you- I mean would you like to-"
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.173: He stares at the ground awkwardly.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.172: You walk home, careful and contemplative. You don't feel afraid, but you have a certain clarity of mind that makes considering your options feel easier than ever.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.171:
You walk home with an exagerated elegance in your stride as you lose yourself in a fancy. In it you are bold, dangerous, perhaps the greatest temptress of all time.

The night lanterns seem brighter than ever, and you wonder if it's a mere fancy, after all.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.170: Tonight ended much more intensely than you had anticipated.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.169:
Later on, your find yourself outside and getting ready to head home. You look up at his apartment window and spot Ludovico waving to you.

You wave back, because as devilish as you are, you're not a monster.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.168: You have to admit, he's very fun to toy with.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.167:
Your hands wander over each other's bodies, and you can feel Ludovico slowly grow bolder with his touch.

Quite bold indeed.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.166: Your lips meet in the dark, and you can feel his entire body tense up, before that tension slowly melts away.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.165: You give him no reply, instead there's only the sound of your breathing in the close, intimate confines of your hiding place.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.163: A devilish smile blossoming across you lips, you throw the door open and grab Ludovico by the wrsits before pulling him into the wardrobe with you. The doors swing shut behind him.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.162: His hand grasps onto the latch of the wardrobe door.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.161: Eventually, he notices the wardrobe and starts to creep over to it. He slow, stalking steps are both awkward and adorable.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.160: He hunts around the room, looking under the bed, and even checking to see if the window's been opened. You titter to yourself, knowingly.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.159: "Yvette, are you here? Am I... supposed to find you?" He asks, trying to remain serious but you can hear him supress a giggle.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.158: The two clink glases and drain them. You can hear the bishop cough and sputter from the strength of the grappa.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.157: "Ah, yes. To fealty and truth." Ludovico replies weakly.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.156: "If something so lovely is already passing into lips, let us choose something suitably noble to pass from them. Let us drink to fealty and truth!" The bishop proclaims with no shortage of vigor.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.155: "Oh, of course your excellency!" Ludovico replies. You can hear him pour out two small glasses of the potent liquor. "What shall we toast to?"
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.154: "Would you mind if I partook of a little myself?" The Bishop asks with a quiet mischeif. "The journey back is going to be most tiresome."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.152: "Ah yes, that..." Ludovico replies. "I brought the grappa from Rome. I suppose it helps me pass the time alone."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.151: "I see you've been deep in your cups, and some strong stuff by the smell of it..."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.150:
"Oh... w-what is what?" Ludovico asks, poorly concealing the dread in his voice. 

You try to sink further back into the wardrobe, but your shoulderblades are already rubbing against the back wall.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.149:
"But oh ho! What is this I spy?" The Bishop suddenly asks with a disapproving chuckle.

Your heart stops in your chest.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.148: The sound of your sigh of relief is thankfully muffled by the clothes you're hiding behind.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.147: "Ah, magnifique!" the Bishop replies with a tone of releif. "Thank you again, Ludovico. Much as I would like to stay, I must leave immediately."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.146: "I believe this is what you're looking for." Ludovico pronounces proudly, presumably as he produces something suitably impressive looking from his desk.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.145: "It certainly does that," Ludovico agrees. You can hear him rummaging through his desk.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.144: "Ah yes, time spent in solitude and contemplation is good for the soul. It helps one realize the folly of worldly desires."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.143: "Please, don't worry yourself." Ludovico replies with a forced cheeriness. "I was merely spending my time here, alone. To be truly honest, it's been nice to have this time of peace."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.142: The footsteps are getting louder, and you can hear them right outside the door.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.141: However, upon closer inspection you realize that the bed is too low to the ground for you fit underneath it.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.140: Getting down on your hands and knees, you prepare to hide under the bed in the corner.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.139: You search the room for an adequate place to hide.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.137: Cursing under your breath, you wrack your brain for a new plan, as you hear footsteps ascending the stairs.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.136:
Right as you open the window, you notice a carriage in the streets right outside. The carriage is dectorated with the livery of the Church, and the coachman is smoking a pipe, looking directly at the place where you would land if you lept from the window.

This won't work.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.135: Your heart hammering in your chest, you jump in the wardrobe at the absolute last minute.

19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.122: (You have gained some favor with Ludovico)
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.121: Carefully stalking up the stairs, you find Ludovico's room, where the door has been left ajar. He's bent over a desk, illuminated by the light of a few candles.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.120: With a sigh, you walk home in the dark, eyeing each shadow with guarded suspicion.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.119: You smile and stroll home with an easy step. Everything in life is a mixture of its ups and downs. Fortune is but a wheel, and those on the bottom may find themselves on the top in half a spin.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.118: Walking home, you mull over the evening's hospitality, and your proximity to disaster.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.117: Later, after some protracted goodbyes, you find yourself outside. You look up at Ludovico's window, and see that it's gone dark.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.116: "Buona notte, Yvette, and sorry again for all of the... danger."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.115: After about an hour, you realize how drained all of that sneaking around has left you, and get ready to leave.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.114: You manage to have half a drink and settle back into your chairs, and your conversation restarts, but slowly.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.113: "Ah, yes. It did spoil the mood somewhat..."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.112: I have to admit, it certainly added an element of drama to the proceedings.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.111: "How are you feeling? Are you alright?"
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.110: "Ah, there you are! I don't know about you, but I don't think my heart has managed to slow down at all."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.109: Caught up in the moment, you decide to have some fun with Ludovico and stay hidden in the wardrobe.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.108: You announce yourself and step out of the wardrobe, making your exit look as elegant as possible, despite the situation.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.107: "Well, that could have gone a lot worse than it did." Ludovico announces to the room at large, before mumbling a prayer of thanks.  "Now, where did you manage to hide?"
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.106:
The Bishop's footsteps recede out of the room, and eventually you hear the crack of a whip and the sound of his carriage departing into the night.

The silence afterwards is long and tense
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.105: "But, as I said earlier, I really must be off. Enjoy yourself and try not partake too much. Too many spirits are rarely good for the spirit."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.104: "Ha ha, a fine jest! It didn't realize you were so funny Ludovico."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.102: "Ah yes, that..." Ludovico replies. "I suppose that the grappa helps pass the time alone, and the second glass... well it felt improper to toast alone."

19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.88:
"Oh... w-what is what?" Ludovico asks, poorly concealing the dread in his voice. 

You try to sink further back into the wardrobe, but your shoulderblades are already rubbing against the back wall.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.87:
"But oh ho! What is this I spy?" The Bishop suddenly asks with a disapproving chuckle.

Your heart stops in your chest.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.86: "Ah, magnifique!" the Bishop replies with a tone of releif. "Thank you again, Ludovico. Much as I would like to stay, I must leave immediately."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.85: "I believe this is what you're looking for." Ludovico pronounces proudly, presumably as he produces something suitably impressive looking from his desk.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.84: "It certainly does that," Ludovico agrees. You can hear him rummaging through his desk. Ocassionally, you can hear your drinking glasses clinking together on the desk as it shifts back and forth.
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.83: "Ah yes, time spent in solitude and contemplation is good for the soul. It helps one realize the folly of worldly desires."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.82: "Please, don't worry yourself." Ludovico replies with a forced cheeriness. "I was merely spending my time here, alone. To be truly honest, it's been nice to have this time of peace."
19776.Clandestine Meetings.node.81: "I'm dreadfully sorry for disturbing you," The older man says with that tone of voice which implies that his rank is so much greater than Ludovico's, that even the apology is a mere courtesy at best. "Once I realized I'd forgotten that treatise, I hurried back as soon as I could."
