16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.10: "Now, where are you looking to go?"
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.9: He walks away to rejoin his friends, who appear to be even deeper into the wine than he is.
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.8: "Madame, I have escorted you up and down. We have sought your Armand to no avail. I have done my duty." He says simply, and shrugs. "Now if you excuse me, I must return to my compatriots."
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.7: With a wave that is barely as polite as decorum requires, he departs to seek the affection of a different young woman.
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.6: "Madame, I believe this is where we part ways." Your newfound guide says, gently pulling away from you.
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.5:
His brow furrows and he turns up his nose. "Madame, I'm just trying to help. There's no need to be so rude."

You didn't think that refusing an invitation from a stranger was rude, but perhaps he was raised to think otherwise. Judging by the stares of the other patrons in the tavern, they seem to feel the same way as yourself.

(You have gained a little credibility)
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.4: The surprised man's face broadens into a happy grin as you reach out and take his arm. "Why it appears that I arrived just in time!"
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.3: Your turn around to find yourself face to face with an unfamiliar young man. He's well dressed and handsome enough, but it's the middle of day and he already smells like two bottles of wine. "Pardonne-moi madame, but I can never ignore the sight of a woman in need, and you appear to be lost."
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.2:
"... something I offered to help you do." The man grimaces, and begrudgingly holds out his arm. You take it happily as he conducts you about the tavern, visiting all the places that you suspect Armand might be. A few of the patrons smirk at your clever ploy.

(You have gained a little credibility)
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.1: "May I... escort you?" His smile is broad and cocky.
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.node.0: You look around the unfamiliar tavern, trying to find Armand. Your eyes scan for his chestnut hair, your ears strain to hear the sound of his infectious laugh.
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.link.23: "Monsieur, I'm so glad to hear you can't refuse a woman in need! I need you to help me find my fiance."
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.link.7: "I am trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo. Can you help?"
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.link.6: "Oh, nowhere in particular, just around the tavern with you."
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.link.4: "What happened to be unable to refuse a woman in need?"
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.link.2: "Non monsieur, you may not. I am fine by myself."
16396.An Amorous Inquiry.link.1: "Oh, you are so kind! Please do!"
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.20:
(You have lost some favor with Louis Antoinne de Saint-Just)
(You have gained some favor with Elisabeth Vigee Le Brun)
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.19: You grace the voyeurs with a haughty sneer before leaving towards your own carriage.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.18: Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a mysterious stranger.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.17: You consider the extravagant carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.16: Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to an honorable stranger.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.15: You consider the bold carriage for a moment, is this who you’d like to ride with?
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.14: Settled in your decision, you set out, ready to entrust your fortune to a modest stranger.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.13: You consider the humble carriage for a moment. Is this who you’d like to ride with?
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.12: The carriage to your right is richly decorated, yet somber. Swags of black crepe hang from the roof of the carriage, leaving only glimmers of the gold underneath. The decidedly feminine bent of the decorations indicates that the occupant is a woman, but all of the black suggests that she’s in mourning.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.11: The carriage in front of you is obviously being used by a soldier of some sort. The driver is leaning intently towards the passenger compartment, waiting for orders. You recognize the insignia of the Queen’s Dragoons on the side of the carriage. It feels noble and proud, but also capable.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.10: The carriage to the left of you is of foreign design, and features a gilded crest as its only ornamentation. This crest is emblazoned with a motto in latin, and appears to belong to a priest of some description. The curtains are drawn, but someone appears to have lit a lantern inside. Judging by the occupant’s silhouette, it looks like he’s reading.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.9: However, there appear to be three other carriages waiting to leave, each of them quite different. Perhaps one of them can help?
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.8:
Before you can even respond, he gets his carriage moving, leaving you alone with yet another indignity. 

Going back to Maximin is obviously unacceptable, it’s too far to walk home, and most of the other guests have already left.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.7:
You check to make sure that you’re in the right place, but to no avail. The carriage you hired is simply not there.
 
“He went home!” a passing coachman says helpfully, while adjusting the harness on a particularly grumpy horse. “Doorman came out about an hour ago, and told him you wanted the coach to leave without you. Seemed real important, so he went home.”
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.6: Scanning the faces of your new audience, you see the glaring, unamused faces of the various party guests. You’re certain that your hatred of Maximin, the Revolution, and everything else he stands for is going to be well known throughout the city soon enough.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.5:
However, when you arrive at the place where your carriage is parked, you quickly find out that… it isn’t. 

It’s gone.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.4: Boiling over with anger, you turn and rain insults upon the house. In fact, you consider throwing your shoe through one of their windows, before you remember how much you like that shoe. It’s then that you notice that several of the carriages have stopped, just to watch your display.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.3: Choosing to take the high ground, you straighten your posture and hold your head high, striding towards your carriage as if it was your intention to leave like this all along. While you make a great effort to haughtily avoid eye contact with all of those watching you, you can tell that some of them are quite surprised by your decorum in this dire situation.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.2: The only thing left to do is go home.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.1:
When you finally get to the door, you feel a brutish shove, and you stumble out into the courtyard, barely keeping your balance in your heels. The area is equally crowded, with various persons entering their personal carriages. 

You can hear somebody snicker, but you have no idea who it was.
15108.An Absent Carriage.node.0:
Before you can reply, a valet grabs you roughly by the arm and drags you from the study. People like your loathsome host don’t need to do their own dirty work, they have servants for that. It takes far longer than you’d like to get outside, as the entryway is crowded with guests preparing to leave.
 
You can feel their eyes weighing heavily on you.
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.19: "Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.18: "A wealthy widow, helping a lost soul in need? It works in the books. Let's go."
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.16: "Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.15: "He's a man of honor, sworn to protect France. I'm the next best thing to that. Let's go!"
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.13: "Perhaps not, I'll examine the other carriages."
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.12: “A priest should be willing to help a poor, innocent woman like myself. Let’s go.”
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.10: <Inspect the extravagant carriage to the right>
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.9: <Inspect the bold carriage in the middle>
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.8: <Inspect the humble carriage to the left>
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.3: "That's some big talk about titles, from a man who can't even do his own dirty work!"
15108.An Absent Carriage.link.2: *Sigh* "This has been a night. I'll just leave."
15082.Alexandre's Letter.node.5: Using your map, it doesn’t take long to figure out where this particular fountain is. In fact, you could visit it today if you like.
15082.Alexandre's Letter.node.4: ‘Please meet me there as soon as you can, and I will share what I know. Très cordiales salutations, Alexandre’
15082.Alexandre's Letter.node.3: Thomas-Alexandre goes on to describe a particular fountain deep in the city. He’d like to meet with you in secret, as he’s worried about someone intercepting the letter. Is your enemy really that powerful?
15082.Alexandre's Letter.node.2: ‘Chère Yvette, I’m truly glad that I was fortunate enough to meet you all those nights ago. However, I cannot stand that it came at the cost of such injustice being committed against you by that treacherous host. To that end, I’ve spent the last few days gathering intelligence and believe that I have found something that you will find quite interesting.’
15082.Alexandre's Letter.node.1: Opening it up, you find a letter from Thomas-Alexandre, written with a precise penmanship that makes you think of expensive tutors, diligent practice, and military discipline.
15082.Alexandre's Letter.node.0: The next morning, you find a letter on your nightstand. Camille must have brought it in while you were still asleep. It’s sealed in blue wax with the initials “A.D.”
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.46: Everything seems that way with him. Larger than life heroes, in a perpetual clash against evil. Great people sacrificing themselves for the weak.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.45: "The next time we see each other, I'd be more than happy to tell you more, if you'd like."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.44: "Don't worry. I will find you again."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.43: He leaves as quickly as he came, already striding over to the guests in the other group.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.42: The two of you chat a while longer. While his main interests are political, you find that he knows a surprising amount about poetry and theater, especially when it comes to legends and heroic epics.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.41: You spend the next few minutes walking around the party, wondering what to do next. Yet, your thoughts keep coming back to that distressing young man. There's something dark inside of him, you're certain of it.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.40: You spend the next few minutes walking around the party, wondering what to do next. Yet, your thoughts keep coming back to that fiery, beautiful man.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.39: (You have gained some favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.38: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.37: However, you quickly run out of things to say, and Antoine takes the time to glance over his shoulder. He notices that some other guests of the party are waiting patiently for him. "It appears I am needed elsewhere, madame. I must go."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.36: Antoine glances over his shoulder and notices that some other guests of the party are impatiently waiting for him. "It appears I am needed elsewhere, madame."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.35:
The two of you chat a little longer. While his mind is often focused on politics, his zeal manages to stop it from becoming tiresome. In some ways, you see quite a bit of Armand in him.

Of course, Armand's passion seems far less violent, so that's something to consider.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.34: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.33: (You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.32: (You have gained some favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.31: He smiles, caught a little off guard. "Well, I did study oratory in school, until I found my teachers wanting."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.30: He grunts dismissively. "The old order must be cast aside as soon as possible, lest we allow more people to become victim to its repression and cruelty."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.29: "Oh, that I can guarantee." He replies. His gaze is unflinching, but he can't help but smile.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.28: "Will we stay and be incinerated, or develop the courage to jump into the waters below?"
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.27: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.26: (You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.25: "Right now, the people of France stand at the edge of a cliff, a raging forest fire burning at our backs."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.24: (You have gained some favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.23: "The rest of us cannot afford such a privelege."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.22: He looks into the distance and sneers. "You sound just like them. France's future matters for all of us. We cannot afford to be polite with what's at stake."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.21: You follow up your statement by demurely batting your eyelashes at him. He doesn't seem to notice, instead nodding along thoughtfully. "Humility is a virtue. I respect that."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.20: "That's exactly it!" He growls. "Politics is not some civil debate where, at the end, everyone gets to simply agree to disagree. It is real decisions, with real consequences, for real people! The nobility can pretend to sit above it all because they're isolated from those consequences."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.19: "They don't want me involved with the Revolutionaries. They don't understand the importance of our times."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.18: "Of course, as much as I love the character and the people of the countryside, it's probably for the best that I'm here. My relationship with my family has been rather... strained, as of late."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.17: (You have gained some favor with Louis Antoine de Saint-Just)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.16: He leans back and reappraises you, a smile forming on his lips. "Oh really? Your caution is wise. One can never be too careful."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.15: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.14: (You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.13: "I can tell from your accent that you're not from around Paris either. I'm only in the city for a few months from Blérancourt. Someone invited me here, and I'm using the opportunity to try to get one of my plays published."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.10: "However, I've already heard of your escapades, and I don't think I've like what I've heard."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.9: "Thankfully, I've already heard of your exploits, and I must admit that I like what I've heard."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.8: Pausing to breathe deeply, his expression visibly softens. "My apologies. With everything that's going on, there's always the concern of the Crown putting spies in our midst."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.7: "But please just call me Antoine. I would rather not share my name with tyrants."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.6: He eschews the customary bow for a quick upward nod of respect. "My name is Louis Antoine de Sant-Just."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.5: "Well Madame Decaux, we already have enough people in our midst who are 'just observing'. What this country needs is action."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.4: "Well, it's nice to have you with us, Madame Decaux. Welcome to our meeting of the minds."
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.3: "Who are you, and what exactly are you doing here?"
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.2: Suddenly, you notice a young man heading straight towards you throug hthe crowds. Frankly, he's beautiful, but he radiates a dangerous intensity.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.1: Right now, however, you're simply content to watch events unfold from afar.
15634.A Young Firebrand.node.0: Keeping a distance from the crowds, you examine the attendees of this so called 'Revolutionary Salon'. All in all, they seem quite the ecclectic bunch, a mix of stern scholars, opinionated lawyers, and outrageous bohemians. The mood is both tense and energetic.
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.47: "Zeal, passion, and energy. He's certainly not boring."
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.34: "That's quite a line. Have you been practicing it?"
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.33: "If our homes are being incinerated, then I'd wish to stay and save them."
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.32: "It all depends, are you diving with me?"
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.24: "Are you sure? Politics isn't for everyone, after all."
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.23: "I don't know much about any of that, but I'd love to to learn."
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.22: "Then they're fools. The writing is on the walls, everywhere you go. We must care or die."
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.15: "I'll answer that once I know who I'm dealing with. Who are you?"
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.4: "I'm Yvette Decaux and I'm just observing, nothing more, nothing less."
15634.A Young Firebrand.link.3: "My name is Yvette Decaux, and I'm just woman who's excited by revolutionary ideals."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.56: "And I think that any relationship we have moving forward, would be more pleasurable if you referred to me by that title."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.55: She examines you carefully before continuing. "Because any relationship with another is about more than who they are. It's also about who that other sees you as."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.54: "I hope to see you again soon."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.53: "Think nothing of it, then." she says, staring into her glass. "It was a mere, passing fancy."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.52: "Merveilleuse" she replies. "Thank you for indulging me, Yvette."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.51: "I think that I'd prefer for you to call me 'Madame Gazel', from now on. Could you do that for me?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.50: "When we first met, I introduced myself as Honorade." She says with a devilish smile.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.49: "Before I go, would you mind doing me a favor?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.48: Eventually she notices him. "Ah, that's my servant René. I'm sorry Yvette, but I'm needed elsewhere."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.47: You find yourself feeling pleased, but otherwise unphased by the encounter. After a few moments collecting your thoughts, you move on to the rest of the party.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.46: You take a moment to get your bearings, before you move on to the rest of the party. All the same, you can't quite get this woman out of your head.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.45: Then, in a dramatic swirl of black tafetta, she turns and leaves.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.43: "Ah, that's my servant René. I'm sorry Yvette, but I'm needed elsewhere."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.42: Out of the corner of your eye you notice a man in the livery of a servant, wearing a small black armband trying to politely get Honorade's attention.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.41: Out of the corner of your eye you notice a man in the livery of a servant, wearing a small black armband, trying to politely get Honorade's attention. He seems to be having quite a difficult time pulling her attention away from you.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.40: The two of you continue to chat together for a while, but eventually the conversation peters out on its own.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.39: The conversation continues for quite a while. It's delightful, romantic and edgy. It's almost theatrical in its over the top-ness, but you get the feeling that's just how Honorade is.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.38: "However, I would caution against putting too much faith in the trappings of a good life. No amount of trappings will ever make the heart of something whole, but that's up to you to discover for yourself."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.37: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.36: "Far too many people are caught up in a world of numbers, theories, and treatises. All the grandest ideas in the world mean nothing without a life well lived."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.35: (You have gained some favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.34: (You have lost a little favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.33: "All you'll have is the consequences of your retreat, whatever they may be. That's no way to live at all."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.32: "Really? How unfortunate," she sighs. "If you let yourself be driven by an aversion to something, you'll never get what you really want."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.31: "Ah, you are a woman after my own heart. A love of feeling is such a rare trait in this so called 'age of reason'."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.30: "An ambitious one are we? I can appreciate that sentiment. There is certainly some allure to the finer things in life." She rplies, running the back of her hand against the sumptuous taffeta of her dress.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.29: "What are your passions, Yvette? What drives you?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.28: "However, obligations are tiresome conversation. I'd rather speak of passion."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.27: "Of course, that's no longer possible, but we all have our obligations." She sighs and sips her water.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.26: "You see, I tend to prefer more intimate gatherings," she explains. "My husband attended these parties in my stead."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.25: (You have gained some favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.24: "I like your adventurousness, but be careful. It might get you hurt."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.23: "Of course, I can't blame the other guests for not speaking with me. After all, most of them have never seen me before."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.22: (You have lost a little favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.21: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.20: "Well, I'm glad it brought you over, instead of driving you away. I can already tell that you're quite intriguing yourself."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.19: She looks you up and down. "Judging from you appearance and the latest rumors, I can safely assume you are the infamous Yvette Decaux, non?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.18: "Walked directly into the spider's web, have we?" She says with a wicked smile.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.17: Her laughter is quiet and deliberate. "I do have a tendency to do that, don't I?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.16: "Well, I should warn you. I'm not here for other people's amusement." She says with a scowl.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.15: "Though I wonder, what inspired you to come speak with me?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.14: "I'm glad you came over, I was starting to grow bored, and life is too frightfully short to allow for such a thing."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.13: "My name is Honorade Gazel, but you may simply call me Honorade."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.12: She looks you up and down. "Judging from you appearance and the latest rumors, I can safely assume you are the infamous Yvette Decaux, non?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.11: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.10: (You have lost a little favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.9: (You have gained some favor with Honorade)
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.8: "I may be alone, but it doesn't bother me at all. Still I appreciate your concern."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.7: "I'd rather prefer if you actually answered my questions first. Be that as it may, I am Honorade Gazel. Just another person attending this party."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.6: "Ah, merveilleuse! It's nice to meet someone equal parts straightforward and adorable."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.5: She cuts you off right as you're about to introduce yourself. "And who might you be?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.4: However, just as you start walking towards her, she stares at you with a surprising intensity, like she's studying you. Feeling a little unnerved, you're starting to understand where all of this intimidation business is coming from, but you can't stop now.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.3: You shrug and take a healthy sip of wine. After all, this all sounds to you like an absolutely perfect reason to go talk to someone.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.2: You scrutinize the other guests, their darting glances and concealed whispers. Someone attempts to approach her, but suddenly thinks better of it. Are they intimidated by her?
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.1: An elegant woman in black is standing off to the side of the party by herself. Her presence is obvious and while nothing about her seems outwardly wrong, you can see that the other guests are making an effort to avoid her.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.node.0: You're taking a moment to yourself, listening to the party's exquisite string quartet, when you notice something odd.
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.68: "I don't think I'm comfortable with seeing you that way, Honorade."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.54: "I don't think I'm comfortable with that."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.48: "Interesting, but I don't know yet what to make of her."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.47: "That was far more... intriguing than I expected. Hopefully I'll be able to see more of her."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.35: "To be honest, I'm just here because I wanted to get away from home."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.34: "Passion itself is what drives me. I want excitement. I want to feel."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.33: "I want what I deserve, and I'll do anything to get it."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.30: "What do you mean, no longer possible?"
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.16: "The other guests are afraid of you. I found that intriguing, and wanted to learn why."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.15: "You stood out from the crowd, I found it intriguing."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.14: "I was growing bored too, and was hoping you could fix that."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.6: "Just another party guest who's wondering why you're all alone."
18504.A Wealthy Widow.link.5: "I'd rather know who you were first."
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.14: After the woman leaves, you question a few more of the guests, but none of them seem willing to talk about Armand.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.13: There’s no sign of him, not even an open tab with the tavernkeep.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.12: With the woman gone, you question a few more of the guests, but to no avail. None of them seem willing to talk about about Armand.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.11: After a long pause, she continues “Tread carefully. Talents like yours are most valuable, and valuable things tend to attract danger.” The voice of another guest calls out behind her, and she quickly excuses herself before disappearing into the crowd.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.10: “I’m sorry, but I don’t think I can help you find your Armand.”
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.9: The woman barks out a laugh of genuine surprise. “If this is what you do for fun, I can’t wait to see what you do when you’re being serious.” She pauses to sip at her wine again, finding her glass to be empty. “I’m sure I’ll see you around,” she says, before slipping into the crowd.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.8: “I get the feeling that you’re going to fit in here just fine,” she remarks with the faintest hint of bitterness before disappearing into the crowd.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.7: A look of shock ripples across her face for a brief moment, before return to polite neutrality “Ah, I see.”
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.5: “So, let me be more specific. What are you trying to do here, Madame Decaux?”
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.4: “You just walked in, swept an entire room of strangers off of its feet, and made it look easy. Not only that, you did it without a single one us managing to learn anything about you. I know your name, and nothing more.”
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.3: “Yes, you said that,” the woman observes idly. She sips her wine again, examining you. “I’m just having a hard time figuring you out. You’re obviously a girl fresh from the countryside, but you do not conduct yourself like one… at all.”
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.2: She sips her wine, patiently. Intently.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.1:
You feel a tap at your elbow and turn around, finding yourself face to face with a woman from one of your previous conversations.

“Who are you? I mean, who are you really?” she asks.
13016.A Surprising Woman.node.0: The conversation finishes as all the others had, with the various guests walking away from you, charmed and satisfied. A few days spent cooped up in a carriage have done nothing to dull your skills.
13016.A Surprising Woman.link.9: "I just moved here, so I'm trying to get a feel for Paris."
13016.A Surprising Woman.link.8: "I just moved here, so I'm trying to get a feel for Paris."
13016.A Surprising Woman.link.7: "I'm trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo."
13016.A Surprising Woman.link.6: "I'm trying to find my fiance, Baron Armand de Marbo."
13016.A Surprising Woman.link.3: "Pardon moi, I'm not sure I understand the question."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.91: All in all, it was still a good evening.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.89: "A life of fencing, riding, and bravery? It's like I was made for it!"
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.87: "After my father claimed his title and bought me back, he made up for the indignity with a veneagnce."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.86: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.85: "Most fathers would have disapproved of my behavior, but not him. In fact he delighted in my adventures. Sometimes, I think he was trying to live through me."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.84: Wanting to get home before the warmth of the Malaga wears off, the two of you take the quickest route available. It's a short trip, but you get home safely nonetheless.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.83: The two of you take a longer and more scenic route back to your home. It gives you more of a chance to talk, and to bring extra details from his mysterious past to light.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.82: (You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.81: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution somewhat)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.80: "Still, it doesn't matter. Yes, I was born into unjust bondage, but I was also born into nobility. How many would kill for what I have? I can't just throw that away, Yvette."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.79: "You're absolutely right! I was born into a noble title, but I was also born into unjust bondage. That's what the revolution is about, freeing people from the circumstances of their birth."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.78: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown, even more)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.77: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.76: "Merci, Yvette. It's nice to know that someone like you has confidence in me."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.75: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.74: (You have lost a little favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.73: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.72: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution, even more)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.71: "Still, it doesn't matter. Yes, I was born into a noble title, but I was also born into unjust bondage. That's what the revolution is about, freeing people from the circumstances of their birth. Why can't you see that, Yvette?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.70: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown somewhat)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.69: "You're absolutely right! I can't betray my legacy just because of how I feel for a moment."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.68: That familiar smile is suddenly back in place. "Thank you for joining me on this little stop! I think I'm ready to do what I actually promised to do, and walk you home. Sorry again for boring you with all of that."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.67: With a great swig his finishes off his wine and drops some coins on the counter. You finish off yours as well, but in a more refined fashion.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.66: "I suppose that's true." He admits. He stares at the lamp on your table, considering your point.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.65: "And vive la roi to you as well!" He laughs with a mock salute. "I didn't expect you to be such a commited monarchist. Still, you're absolutely right."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.64: "With an endorsement like that, how can I say no?" He laughs. "I must admit, I never took you for such a firebrand."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.63: "I suppose it's true that I was born to a noble title." He admits. He stares at the lamp on your table, considering your point.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.62: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution somewhat)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.61: Alexandre sighs and shakes his head. "Je suis désolé. That was all a little more serious than I'd intended."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.60: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown somewhat)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.59: "You know what? You're absolutley right. All over Paris, commoners cry out for freedom. Me, and my compatriots should be the ones to give it to them."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.58: "Merci, Yvette. It's nice to know that someone like you has confidence in me."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.57: "You know what? You're absolutley right. I have a duty to defend my birthright, if not for myself, but for any children that I should have."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.56: "I was so confident that I'd prove him wrong. That I'd take all the things he'd given me and make him proud, even as a simple soldier."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.55: "Then... he died less than a fortnight later. I never claimed his title."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.54: "So, I enlisted. Father wasn't happy, but I didn't it anyway. At his insistence I did so under a different name, so as not to bring shame upon our legacy. To not bring shame upon him."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.53: As he sips his drink, you catch a glimmer of something in his eyes. Was that doubt?
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.52: "These days, I feel closer to the common people's struggle for freedom."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.50: "These days, I feel closer to the Crown. I'm a child of nobility, shouldn't I serve that tradition?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.49: "Now, I look at everything happening the city, I and don't know how to feel. Am I even a real noble? Or am I just a commoner whose had more advantages than most?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.48: He pauses to examine his hand in the candlelight, as if his skin could answer some long, unanswered mystery. "Of course, it happens that men like me need four generations of documentation to prove their link to nobility, something we didn't have."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.47: "I'm not sure if I told you this, but what spurred me to enlist was that I wanted to show my father that I was a good as any other noble."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.46: "However, to answer your question, yes. As his eldest legitimate son, I'm the heir to his land and titles, should I choose to claim them... from his wife."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.45: "The only thing that's wrong are the laws that let people be bought and sold at all."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.44: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.43: "Don't worry, it was only a few months before he bought me back, and brought me here. The second I set foot on French soil, I was a free man."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.42: "He needed money to pay for his return to France, and claim his fortune and title. That's why he sold me, to pay for the trip over."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.41: "So yes, it just was a temporary inconvenience."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.40: "Once I arrived, he hired tutors to make up for lost time in my education. I learned how to fence, how to ride, even how to play an instrument. All of the things that make one a proper gentleman."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.39: "In the eyes of the law, I was always a nobleman, even when I was a slave."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.38: "What? Absolutely not! He did what he could to help me."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.37: "I'm glad you liked it!" He laughs, clinking glasses with you.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.36: "Once my father got his fortune, he bought me back."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.35: "Once his parents died, he could come out of hiding and claim his inheritance. But first, he needed to get to France to prove his legitimacy. So, he temporarily sold me to pay for passage on a ship, so he could claim his title."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.34: "My father owned my mother, so I was born his slave."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.33: "Let's say that he had a falling out with his brothers that lasted a few... decades."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.32: "Because you can still sell slaves in the colonies, and I was one." He says, like it's the most obvious thing imaginable.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.31: "Well, he was forced to it," Alexandre explains. "Even though he was the eldest son, and the heirs to our fortune, everyone in the family thought my father was dead."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.30: "Exactly!" He replies excitedly, almost grateful for your agreement.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.29: "So my father sold me. Well, technically, he pawned me off..."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.28: "Of course, to get that pleasure for himself, he first had to get us from his hiding place in Saint-Domingue to the the family estate in France." Alexandre punctuates this with a long sip of wine.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.27: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.26: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.25: "He didn't disapprove at all, in fact he delighted in my adventures. Sometimes, I think he was trying to live through me."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.24: "As fun as it sounds, I was just another jobless scion of nobility, living off of my father's largess."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.23: "He'd lived a nobleman's life of ease, and he wanted the same for me. To be honest, I was more than happy to take him up on his offer."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.22: "When I first moved to Paris, I spent years as a typical, unscrupulous rake. Strutting about the Palais-Royale, finding romance in the booths of Nicolet's theater, spending far too much money on fine clothes and finer drink."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.21: "Oh, the usual. Wine... women... other people's money."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.20: "Me? You flatter me." He chuckles. "You should have seen me a few years ago."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.19: "If that's the case, maybe we should have met a few years ago." He smirks as he takes another sip.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.18: "Then again, he often went to great lengths to obtain his pleasures."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.17: "Malaga was always a favorite of my father. Even when I was growing up in Saint Doaminue, he would leap at any chance to get a bottle of it."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.16: Alexandre pauses to contemplate the charms of his glass of Malaga by the light of your table's lamp. His eyes seem focused on something distant.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.15: You clink glasses with him, and sip the fortified wine. It's sweet, and strong. The chill inside you melts away, almost instantly.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.14: Raising his glass for a toast, he says "To quick decisions and life's little joys."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.13: Stopping at the tavern's entrance, he holds the door open for you. "After you then, madame."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.12: Both of the drinks arrive and he fills your glasses before his own.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.11: Alexandre orders a bottle of Malaga from the barmaid. You ask for a pitcher of water to accompany it. If one isn't careful, the hangover from these sweet wines can be absolutely debilitating.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.10: (You have gained a little favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.9: Stopping at the entrance, he holds the door for you. You sigh, and hope this doesn't drag on for too long.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.8: Inside, the tavern is small, but cozy instead of cramped. You can feel the heat from the fires in the kitchen, and a young man atop a small stage is tuning his violin.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.7: (You have gained some favor with Alexandre)
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.6: "Madame, have you met us before? That's hardly a possibility." He replies with a wink. Stopping at the entrance, he holds the door open for you.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.5: "Why in fact, it does!" He laughs, mostly to himself.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.4: "I see we're in agreement!" He replies with a grateful laugh.
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.2: "It's so brisk, that I'm feeling up for a drink to stay warm. If you're interested, I know of a decent tavern nearby."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.1: "Merci, Yvette. It's nice to know that someone like you has confidence in me."
18186.A Storied Lineage.node.0: Alexandre is once again walking you back home after your rendezvous. It's unusually chilly tonight, so you both walk close together, arm in arm, to help stave off the cold.
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.95: "Don't sell yourself short, this has been great. I appreciate you trusting me like this."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.85: "It sounds like you already have your answer. Trust your heart."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.73: "It sounds like you already have your answer. Trust your heart."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.68: "Yet, weren't you also born a victim of that same tradition? The Revolution needs you."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.67: "Of course you should! You're only defending your birthright."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.66: "Of course, your heart burns for freedom, just like theirs. Support the Revolution."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.65: "Weren't you born a noble? Shouldn't you support the Crown?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.62: "I've never met someone better prepared to fight for the common good. Support the Revolution."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.61: "Trust your heart, you're a child of both places."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.60: "You were born a noble and nothing changes that. The Crown needs you."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.43: "Does this mean you're actually a nobleman?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.42: "Alex, your father sold you like property. That's monstrous."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.41: "Temporary or not, it's still an amazing story."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.39: "Does this mean you're actually a nobleman?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.38: "Alex, your father sold you like property. That's monstrous."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.37: "I have to say, that's an amazing story."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.32: "I'm sorry, he... uh... sold you? How? Why?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.31: "How could your father do that to you?"
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.30: "Well, at least you got to France."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.19: "He sounds like my kind of person."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.4: "Alright, as long as we don't completely lose our heads."
18186.A Storied Lineage.link.2: "Warmth, good drink, and even better company? I love all of those."
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.17: Over your shoulder, you hear an older womans voice call out. A brief glance reveals an elegant older woman, bedecked in jewelry, gesturing insistently with her fan. "Ah, pardon moi madame, duty calls."
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.15:
(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.14: You two stand together, swaddled in tense silence, before you decide to slink away.
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.13: “In fact, I find your story… rather hard to believe.” He replies, icily. “I would go so far as to say that it’s quite rude to lie about your relationship to the hostess. Marcelle would certainly not appreciate this, if she were to find out.”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.12: You talk and laugh with him for a while longer, before you eventually part ways, in order to see what else is going on at the party.
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.11: “Perhaps later on, you’ll be able to put in a good word for me?”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.10: “Ah yes!" He says, suddenly perking up. "I remember her saying something about a summer home in the south of the country. For you to be here now, you must have quite the close bond with our hostess."
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.9: With a polite nod, he exits the conversation to mingle in the rest of the party.
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.8: With a polite nod, he exits the conversation to mingle in the rest of the party.
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.7: The older man chuckles drolly at your blunt assessment. “I would recommend that you do. Once the Viscountess de Foix has it in mind to hate someone, nothing will ever change her mind.”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.6: “Exactly! Marcelle has many qualities, but humility and forgiveness are not among them.”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.5: “Does that help clarify things at all?” He asks.
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.4: “However, with her current level of favor at court, any suitor would have to be influential indeed in order to attract her notice. She also happens to be rather particular about her appearance, and in all my years of knowing her, I have yet to see her forget anyone who has slighted her.”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.3: “Ah! The Viscountess inherited her title a few years ago, and her father’s vast fortune with it. She’s currently unwed, though a few suitors certainly appear to be trying to court her.” The older man rapidly lists the hostesses’ qualities with the same tone that one might use to describe a horse they were trying to sell.
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.2: "Oh, really?" He leans back and appraises you anew. "I've never heard Marcelle mention you before."
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.1: “How do you know our hostess, the Viscountess de Foix?”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.node.0:
Looking for someone to talk to, you approach an older man who seems to be standing by himself and appraising the room. He nods politely to you as you approach.

“I don’t think I’ve seen you here before.”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.link.6: “Wealthy, vain, and somewhat vindictive? I’ll keep that in mind.”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.link.5: “A monied woman of fashion who tolerates no fools? Interesting.”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.link.2: “I’ve actually never met her before. What’s she like?”
14704.A Splendid Hostess.link.1: “Oh, Marcelle? Her family used to summer near mine in the south. We’re old friends.”

13372.A Small Wager.node.73: The ball spins frantically in the wheel. The gamblers go quiet, all watching the ball with such intensity, as if there was nothing else in the world.

13372.A Small Wager.node.63: "Of course it won't!" He laughs. Some of the other gamblers laugh with him, and shout words of encouragement to you.
13372.A Small Wager.node.62: Happy to keep your coin, you return to the rest of the party.
13372.A Small Wager.node.61:
Deciding that this is not your forte, you decide to leave the gamblers to their games of chance and depart to the rest of the party.

18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.18: The Estates General hasnt even convened yet, but hes already expressed his support for the Third Estate and a new, enlightened France.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.17: You manage to mumble a few polite words of thanks before you decide to slink away.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.16: “Don’t lie about your relationship to the host. Maximin has no time for the ridiculous intrigues of courtiers, and I’m sure he would certainly not appreciate this, if he were to find out.”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.15: “In fact, the only way this could be true, is if we had attended all the events the other one had missed, for years. Which would be convenient indeed!" She replies cheerily. "Since we've exclusively attended such different events, I have some helpful advice for you."
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.14: Eventually, the two of you part ways to explore the rest of the party.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.13: The two of you chat and joke for a while. During the course of conversation, you maintain the lie so flawlessly that, for a brief moment, you have to remind yourself that you don’t actually know the Baron.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.12: “Perhaps later, you would be able to introduce us?” She asks, with some trepidation. “I’m sure he and I would have a lot to… discuss.”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.11: “Then again..." She continues with uncertainty. "I know the Baron also hosts his own private gatherings like this one, and this is my first. That makes so much sense, I’m sorry for doubting you. I had no idea you were so familiar with the Baron.”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.10: The next few minutes pass in awkward silence, punctuated only by bouts of glaring and the occasional upturned nose. Eventually, you walk away to explore the rest of the party.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.9: You two talk and joke for a while, and eventually part ways. If you get a chance to speak with the Baron de Termes, you’re absolutely certain that you’ll have a lot to talk about.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.8:
Her expression immediately sours.

“Well, that’s not how I would have put it, but I suppose one could say that…”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.7:
“Oh, he most certainly is!” She replies happily.

You get the feeling that her interest in the Baron strays beyond the strictly ideological, but that’s none of your business.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.5: “Of course, he has made a few enemies. The Baron has already had to denounce some of his associates for not properly embodying revolutionary ideals. Thankfully, his reputation has only thrived because of his bravery!”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.4: “Oh, Baron Maximin de Termes is a cut apart from the rest of the nobility! He host salons, sponsors pamphlet printings, and associates with our heroes who fought in the American War for Independence.” She clasps her hands together and gazes off into the distance.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.3: It appears that nothing would please her more.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.2: "Really?" She asks, her voice dropping to a low whisper. "I dont mean to be rude, but I've never seen you before, and I attend many of the salons."
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.1: “How do you know our host, Baron Maximin de Termes?” She asks.
18844.A Revolutionary Host.node.0:
You approach a woman who’s standing by herself. She’s looking around at the party, and just seems extremely pleased to be here.

“Isn’t this magnificent?” She beams. “So many revolutionary minds in one place, all brought together by one man.”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.link.6: “So, he’s a political hobbyist, who advances himself by condemning others? Did I get that right?”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.link.5: “A baron willing to reject the very system that benefits him? He sounds like a man of principle.”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.link.2: “This is quite embarrassing, but I don’t know much about our host. Could you tell me more?”
18844.A Revolutionary Host.link.1: “Maximin and I kept running into each other, at various salons and readings. We’re old friends now.”

(You have gained a little credibility)
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.21: "So, this Armand of yours, what brought him to Paris?"
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.20: He departs, leaving you with your thoughts, and more questions.
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.19: Without another word, he drains his wineglass and leaves.
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.18: "Thank you for your understanding madame." He says with a polite nod before he drains his wineglass. "Now it appears that, I must go. I have an urgent appointment."
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.17: "I'm sorry madame, I must go. I have an urgent appointment." He says very brusquely.
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.16: "If that is why you are here, you might want to seek out those associated with the church. Love and tradition are very much on their minds."
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.15:
"Allow me to suggest that you take some time to speak with members of the army, and their supporters. They come from backgrounds both high and low, yet they're all willing to sacrifice so much to raise their station just a little." 

(You've gained a little favor with members of the Military)
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.14: "Are you here in the city alone?"
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.13: "Sorry, madame. I simply... haven't been here long enough to know enough about him."
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.12:
"I think you'll fit in well with the merchants, lawyers, and physicians of the Bourgeoisie." 

(You've gained a little favor with members of the Bourgeoisie)
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.11: “And what has brought you to this bustling metropolis?”
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.10: “Seeking the finer things in life? Well, you’re in the right place for it. Fashion is a way of life here."  He gestures around the tavern and you can see that even the people of more humble means have chosen their attire carefully.
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.9: "Ambition, advancement, and glory? Such things are not easy for a commoner like yourself. However, you are correct, Paris is the place best for those looking to raise their station."
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.8:
"You've travelled all the way here for your fiance? Such love and devotion remind me of when I was your age." His eyes have a far off look for a moment. 

"Never let yourself lose sight of such things."
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.7: “Et vous, madame? What has brought you to Paris, so far from home?”
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.6: “But of course, the harvest has not been so good this year, which is what brings me to Paris. I’m searching for a way to revitalize our estate. Back home, I tried new farming techniques, imported tools, and I even built a shrine to Saint Isidore himself! Yet, it was to no avail. So I am here, in search of a solution.”
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.5: "The Baron de Marbo?" He pauses to think, scratching his chin. "Why does that name sound so familiar?"
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.4: “Well, madame you are in luck, for you have arrived in the most significant city in all the world.”
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.3: “Do not worry madame, I’m sure you’ll be able to return there soon enough!” He replies with a warm laugh. “I myself came a few months ago from similar, idyllic surroundings in Brittany.”
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.1: “Ah, bonjour madame! You must have just arrived in Paris as well.” He says affably.
16366.A Reason for Travel.node.0: You approach a man standing by himself. His wig is slightly dishevelled, and he has fresh mud on his boots.
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.33: "Are you sure you can't remember anything?"
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.28: <Grab his wrist> "Please monsieur, you have to tell me where he is."
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.27: "I'm not, but I'd like to keep some business to myself."
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.24: "No, I'm here to see my fiance, the Baron de Marbo."
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.23: "Well, he's the Baron de Marbo, and he's here for the Estates General."
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.13: “This is the only place where I can achieve the status that I deserve.”
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.12: “Paris is a hub of trade, wealth, and craftsmen. It’s where I can get the lifestyle I want.”
16366.A Reason for Travel.link.11: "I'm in Paris because my fiance, Armand, is here."

16366.A Reason for Travel.link.3: “It was nowhere significant, I’m happier to be here.”

16776.A Missing Carriage.node.12: The carriage to your right is richly decorated, yet somber. Swags of black crepe hang from the roof of the carriage, leaving only glimmers of the gold underneath. The decidedly feminine bent of the decorations indicates that the occupant is a woman, but all of the black suggests that she’s in mourning.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.11: The carriage in front of you is obviously being used by a soldier of some sort. The driver is leaning intently towards the passenger compartment, waiting for orders. You recognize the insignia of the Queen’s Dragoons on the side of the carriage. It feels noble and proud, but also capable.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.10: The carriage to the left of you is of foreign design, and features a gilded crest as its only ornamentation. This crest is emblazoned with a motto in latin, and appears to belong to a priest of some description. The curtains are drawn, but someone appears to have lit a lantern inside. Judging by the occupant’s silhouette, it looks like he’s reading.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.9: However, there appear to be three other carriages waiting to leave, each of them quite different. Perhaps one of them can help?
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.8:
Before you can even respond, he gets his carriage moving, leaving you alone with yet another indignity. 

Going back to Marcelle is obviously unacceptable, it’s too far to walk home, and most of the other guests have already left.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.7:
You check to make sure that you’re in the right place, but to no avail. The carriage you hired is simply not there. 

“He went home!” a passing coachman says helpfully, while adjusting the harness on a particularly grumpy horse. “Doorman came out about an hour ago, and told him you wanted the coach to leave without you. Seemed real important, so he went home.”
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.6: Scanning the faces of your new audience, you see the glaring, unamused faces of the various party guests. Your views on Marcelle, and the Crown in general, have not gone unnoticed. The coachmen and valets on the other hand, think you’re hilarious.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.5:
When you arrive at the place where your carriage is parked, you quickly find out that… it isn’t. 

It’s gone.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.4:
When you finally get to the door, you feel a brutish shove, and you stumble out into the courtyard, barely keeping your balance in your heels. The area is equally crowded, with various persons entering their personal carriages. 

You can hear somebody snicker, but you have no idea who it was.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.3:
Boiling over with anger, you turn and rain insults upon the house, upon the host, even upon her dog. In fact, you consider throwing your shoe through one of their windows, before you remember how much you like that shoe. 

It’s then that you notice that several of the carriages have stopped, just to watch your display.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.2: Choosing to take the high ground, you straighten your posture and hold your head high, striding towards your carriage as if it was your intention to leave like this all along. While you make a great effort to haughtily avoid eye contact with all of those watching you, you can tell that some of them are quite surprised by your decorum in this dire situation.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.1: The only thing left to do is go home.
16776.A Missing Carriage.node.0:
Before you can reply, a valet grabs you roughly by the arm and drags you from the room. People like Viscountess de Foix don’t need to do their own dirty work, they have servants for that. It takes far longer than you’d like to get outside, as the entryway is crowded with guests preparing to leave.
 
You can feel their eyes weighing heavily on you.
16776.A Missing Carriage.link.19: “A priest should be willing to help a poor, innocent woman like myself. Let’s go.”
16776.A Missing Carriage.link.18: “Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
16776.A Missing Carriage.link.17: “A wealthy widow helping a lost soul in need? It works in the books. Let’s go.”
16776.A Missing Carriage.link.15: “Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”
16776.A Missing Carriage.link.14: “He’s a man of honor, sworn to protect France. I’m the next best thing to that. Let’s go.”
16776.A Missing Carriage.link.12: “Perhaps not, I’ll examine the other carriages.”

16776.A Missing Carriage.link.0: *Sigh* “This has been a night. I’ll just leave.”

16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.48:
At that moment, a dour and unsatisfied looking man enters the room, his brow knit in a permanent furrow.

"I stand corrected." Father Sidotti mumbles to you.
16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.47: Your brow furrowed in concern, you take a moment to compose yourself before you leave the now abandoned room to explore your other opportunities at the party.
16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.46:

(You have gained some favor with Ludovico)

"I'm sorry for that madame, his words were completely uncalled for. Unfortunately, I'm not really in a position to start scolding important contributors, no matter how boorish they are."
16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.44: Your stomach churns at the thought of doing anything this man tells you to do, but you step away from the conversation and let the two of them finish their interview. 16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.43: He leaves, grumbling something about 'feminine inconstancy' or the like.
16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.42:

(You have gained a little peril)

16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.40: Puzzling over the question of this priest, you leave the now abandoned room to explore your other opportunities at the party.
16848.A Lovesick Priest.node.39: With the priest on your mind, you leave the now abandoned room to explore your other opportunities at the party.
